llm: Just weeks before Hamas militants kidnapped him in June 2006, Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit posed for two photographs, one grinning in front of the tank in which he served, the other embracing his girlfriend.
The three images captured a smiling, innocent young man on the brink of adulthood.

In September of this year, those pictures were finally replaced by others, snatched surreptitiously five years ago through the window of the Gaza City flat where Shalit was hidden after his abduction by Palestinian militants.
The blurry photos showed a pale, thin youth staring despondently into space, a far cry from the carefree boy in the earlier images.

llm: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian and theorist whose scholarship helped transform his field into a more theoretical, less empirical discipline, died on Feb. 17 in New York City.

human: Uber on Tuesday reported financial results that showed its business was continuing to steadily chug along — and even turn a profit — as more riders and drivers used its platform than ever before.
llm: Uber on Tuesday reported record ridership, with 14 million trips taking place across the company’s platform in a single day.
The ridesharing giant also revealed that it had generated $2 billion in adjusted net revenue during its second quarter of this year, marking the second consecutive quarterly profit for Uber.
In addition to those numbers, Uber shared a number of other interesting stats from the first half of 2019.

human: The economy is good, but Americans feel bad about it.

llm: The economy is doing great.
Trump supporters are delusional.
They believe in a fantasy land where the US has the best health care system, where there's no global warming, and where tax cuts for the rich pay for themselves.
Wealth inequality is at an all time high.
Wages have been stagnant for decades.
The stock market bubble could burst any day now.
The trade war with China will kill millions of jobs.
But it's all good as long as Trump keeps saying MAGA.

human: During the early 20th century, members of the Osage Nation in Oklahoma were systematically murdered by white settlers.
Yet outside the Osage Nation, the history of this racial injustice — one of the worst in American history — was distorted and then largely erased from memory.
llm: During the early part of the 20th century, a group of Osage in Oklahoma were murdered for their oil money.
The killings, which came to be known as the “Reign of Terror,” went on for years and led to the creation of the FBI.
But today, many students in the state have never heard of it.
That may change, thanks to a new book by New Yorker staff writer David Grann.

human: Anyone who has created a work of art knows how it feels to travel to another realm, to leave the world behind and enter a place apart.

llm: Anyone who has ever been in a museum knows that there are more women artists than men.
The ratio is at least 3:1 and it's likely higher.
I know this to be true because I've done the counting myself.
It's not a problem of bias on my part but a reflection of what you see when you look around any museum.

human: “We don’t like having to do this, believe me,” the uniformed man at the door said in a tone that implied he had no strong feelings about it one way or the other.

llm: “We don’t like to think about it, but there is a chance that someday we will be visited by someone who tells us a loved one has died.

In this book, Rabbi Kushner relates his own story and discusses the feelings of grief, fear, emptiness, and anger that overwhelm us when we lose someone dear.”

human: Naeem Khandaker believes he can see the future, and the future he sees is fuchka.

human: When fossil hunters unearthed the remains of a dinosaur from the hills of eastern Montana five years ago, they carried several key characteristics of a Tyrannosaurus rex: a pair of giant legs for walking, a much smaller pair of arms for slashing prey, and a long tail stretching behind it.
llm: When fossil hunters discovered the first T. rex in 1902, they didn't realize how big it was.

human: The trucks carrying aid for Gaza stop for exhaustive inspections by Israeli authorities.

It takes a lot of time and effort to do this, which explains why the aid has not been getting through as quickly as everyone would like.

human: For years, conservatives have struggled to persuade American voters that the left-wing tilt of higher education is not only wrong but dangerous.

human: Astrid Delgado first wrote her college application essay about a death in her family.

The section asked students to choose words from a list that best described themselves.
Ms. Delgado, who is now 23, said she chose “shy” because it seemed like the right answer.
But her father, who was born in Mexico, thought otherwise.
“My dad told me I should have put ‘Latina,’” she said.
“I didn’t think about my race.”
In time, though, the

human: Artists were eager to revisit the past in 2023 — some tweaking recent albums (like Taylor Swift), others revisiting long-dormant work in the vaults (like the two surviving Beatles).

human: We live in the age of small plates meant for sharing, and soup is harder to share than, say, a crab cake.

human: Turkey’s central bank has raised interest rates to 40 percent, its highest level in nearly two decades, in a significant move to tame the country’s runaway inflation after the country’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, had previously defied economic convention by cutting rates to slow price increases.
llm: Turkey’s central bank on Thursday sharply raised interest rates in a bid to tame runaway inflation and restore confidence in the nation’s plummeting currency.
The central bank increased its key interest rate by more than five percentage points, from 17.5 percent to 24 percent.
That is a larger increase than investors had expected, but it did not ease market concerns about Turkey’s economy.
The Turkish lira has fallen this year on concerns over President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s economic policies and after the United States imposed sanctions.

human: A lot can happen in seven years.

A pandemic seemed like a far-fetched idea. La(Horde), the influential dance collective featured prominently during the theater’s reopening festivities this month, was still wholly unknown.
llm: A lot can change in 13 years.
Just ask the Comédie-Française.
The venerable state-subsidized theater company of France is reopening its Salle Richelieu on Monday after more than a decade of renovations and upgrades.

human: October 2023 was the warmest October on record globally, according to data from European climate scientists released on Wednesday.

llm: October 2023 was the hottest month in recorded history.
The previous record holder?
September 2023.
And before that?
August 2023.
In fact, every single one of the last 14 months has broken the all-time heat record.
The year isn’t over yet, but 2023 is already a lock for hottest year on record, beating out 2022 and 2021 for the dubious honor.

human: Deborah Wei first wore a “No Stadium in Chinatown” T-shirt emblazoned with red English letters and Chinese characters in 2000, when she helped to scuttle a proposed baseball stadium for the Phillies.

human: On a rainy, windy morning in February 2012, on a highway outside of Jerusalem, an 18-wheeler collided with a school bus filled with kindergartners and their teachers.

Some of the survivors were so badly burned that a local man who broke a window and climbed into the bus to pull the children out couldn’t recognize them as human.
llm: On a rainy, cold January day in 2013, I was sitting on the floor with my children when the doorbell rang.
My husband and I looked at each other and knew it could only be bad news: Israeli forces were knocking on our door.

human: Q: I live in a co-op apartment on the Upper West Side.
There is a rent-stabilized apartment on my floor occupied by an older couple who have lived here for 50 years and have serious health issues.
This morning, one of the occupants, who has advanced dementia, opened my apartment door, which was briefly unlocked, and was standing in my living room!
I was able to gently escort her back to her apartment.
Building management said that they have spoken to the city’s adult protective services, which has investigated and declined to act.
This is a terrible situation — there are no interested family members, and the couple is often unbathed and walking the halls.
What can we do?
llm: Q: I live in an apartment building that is home to several senior citizens.
Over the last few years, I have noticed these neighbors struggling more and more to take care of themselves and their apartments.
I am concerned for their safety as well as my own, since this building has only one exit and it is difficult for some residents to get around quickly.
What can we do?
— Anonymous

human: Venus today is not like Earth.
Temperatures hover around 860 degrees Fahrenheit day and night, and clouds of sulfuric acid float in its atmosphere.
llm: Venus today is a hellish place for life.

Its surface bakes under 870-degree temperatures and choking clouds of sulfuric acid, while its thick atmosphere would crush you like an aluminum can in a trash compactor if you ever tried to set foot there.
But new research suggests that the planet may have once been much more hospitable — perhaps even capable of supporting life.
That’s because scientists now think it had a shallow ocean that lasted until just about 1 billion years ago.

human: Have you heard that there’s a huge wave of organized shoplifting — coordinated theft by groups effectively looting stores — sweeping the United States?
You probably have.
A couple of years ago, Walgreens said that organized shoplifting was behind its decision to close several locations in San Francisco.
In April, the National Retail Federation issued a dire report claiming that “organized retail crime” was responsible for almost half of the store merchandise that vanished in 2021.
The putative shoplifting tsunami has been relentlessly hyped both by the usual suspects, such as Fox News, and by some politicians.
llm: Have you heard of Gresham’s Law?
It is an economic principle that states bad money drives out good.
The principle was named after Sir Thomas Gresham, who worked as a financial agent for King Henry VIII and Queen Elizabeth I in the 16th century.
Gresham observed that when England tried to mint new coins with less silver content than older ones, the public would hoard the old coins and spend only the newer ones.
In other words, people preferred holding on to the more valuable money while spending the cheaper stuff.
This same phenomenon can be seen today in the way we use different currencies at various times.

human: “I’d like to see a nice store, a pharmacy, a gas station that’s close to my home.

human: In any other circumstance it would have been a shocking sight.

llm: Growing up, Hakim didn’t think about the possibility of becoming a farmer.
He was born in Queens, New York and raised in Stamford, Connecticut.
His parents emigrated from Nigeria; his dad is a software engineer for General Electric, his mom works at a bank.
“I always had it in my head that I would be an engineer like my father,” he says.
But after taking an introductory agriculture class as a freshman in college, everything changed.

human: In the abandoned sheep pens of Al Baqa, a remote Palestinian hamlet in the West Bank, you can still smell the livestock.
But the sheep themselves, as well as their shepherds, have vanished.
llm: In the abandoned village of Twani in the southern hills of the occupied West Bank, an Israeli flag is strung over a crumbling stone arch.
The red-and-white banner has been placed there by the settlers who have converted Twani into a sheep pasture for their farm, Havat Maon, or Maon Ranch.

human: It’s fitting, maybe, that the male leads of the continent-spanning “Past Lives” had to do their joint interview from different countries.

llm: It’s fitting, maybe, that the 2017 Emmys will air on September 17, because for a long time in television history, that was the date that all of the broadcast networks would unveil their new fall lineups.
In recent years, though, cable networks have started to join in the fun, debuting some of their most popular shows during what’s now called Premiere Week.
This year is no exception, as there are several high-profile series launches this week, including Starz’s The Girlfriend Experience, HBO’s The Deuce, and CBS All Access’s Star Trek: Discovery.
There’s also plenty of returning favorites, like FX’s You’re the Worst (which just happens to be Vulture’s TV Podcast pick of the

human: As the two federal criminal cases against Donald Trump make their way toward trial, they are bringing into focus a tale of two judges.

human: The mutiny took hold on Mackinac Island.
llm: The mutiny took place at the party's convention, where Trump supporters were not elected to leadership positions, and the pro-Trump delegates walked out in protest.
The state Republican Party is split between those who support Trump and those who don't.
And that's what I want to talk about today.

human: Frequently left home alone, Ethan Crumbley texted his mother in March 2021 that he had seen a demon in their house, one that hurled dishes across the kitchen.
Days later, his parents, James and Jennifer Crumbley, discussed how their teenage son was “worked up and agitated,” weighing whether to give him Xanax.
llm: Frequently left home alone with his father's guns and knives, the boy had been bullied for years by classmates.
He was a loner who played violent video games such as "Call of Duty" or "Halo."
A friend recalled him watching "The Walking Dead," a show in which zombies devour humans.

human: Nurit Cooper, 79, is one of the Israeli hostages released by Hamas.
But her son, Rotem Cooper, continues to press for the urgent release of the remaining hostages, especially those who are old and sick.
llm: Nurit Cooper, 79, is one of two Israeli citizens still held by Hamas in Gaza.
Her family says it has not been able to communicate with her since last year.

human: Twenty-five years ago, I unknowingly impregnated a girlfriend.
We broke up soon after she conceived, and she moved away without telling me she was pregnant.
She married, and brought her daughter up to believe that her husband was the biological father.
llm: Twenty-five years ago, I had an affair with a married woman who was separated from her husband.
We were together for two years, and she became pregnant.
She told me that the baby wasn't mine, so I walked away.
Later, I found out that she had lied to me.
The child is now 25.
I am also remarried, with three children of my own.
About five years ago, I got in touch with my ex-lover.
She refused to give me any information about our daughter, or even confirm whether she was mine.
I'm torn between respecting my wife's wishes (not to get involved) and finding my biological daughter.
What should I do?—Fatherly Confusion

human: We are in the near future and the European space agency is preparing to launch a mission that will last years if not decades — a length that means filling it with a young crew.
Teenage twins Lázaro (Pablo Cobo) and Tristán (Louis Peres) are training together for spots in the program.
They are equally dedicated, but the confident Tristán is doing just a little better than his brother.
Just as you settle for “Space Academy: The Early Years,” director Edouard Salier makes a sharp turn.
llm: We are in the middle of a sci-fi renaissance, and it is glorious.
If you need some proof, check out this list of five great science fiction movies that you can stream right now.
You’re welcome!

human: Responses from a survey of the likely electorate in six battleground states conducted by The New York Times and Siena College from Oct. 22 to Nov. 3, 2023.
llm: Responses from a subsample of voters deemed most likely to vote in the 2024 presidential election.
Results are weighted to account for unequal probabilities of selection and nonresponse, as well as demographic factors like age, race and gender that affect likelihood to vote.
Weighting was also used to match the results to target population characteristics.
For more details on the methodology, see the survey's methodological statement.

human: Unions across Sweden said on Tuesday that they would support an effort to pressure Tesla to sign a collective bargaining agreement with its 120 mechanics, joining a campaign to defend a model of organized labor that many Swedes say is essential to the country’s economic success and stability.
llm: Unions across Sweden are preparing to expand a strike against U.S.-based electric carmaker Tesla after the company failed to respond to their demands for collective bargaining agreements, trade union IF Metall said on Wednesday.

human: This has been an especially busy year for news in California.
As we approach the end of 2023, we’re presenting the Golden State’s year visually, through photographs.
There were moments of heartbreak, transformation and wonder, many of which will resonate through the state for years to come.
llm: This has been a very interesting and challenging project.
In order to understand the state of California, I had to dig into its history.
This is how I discovered the Spanish and Mexican influence.
I also wanted to look at current events and make some predictions for the future.
I decided to create a fictional newspaper called “The State” that would be based in San Francisco.
I chose to use this medium because it allows me to present multiple viewpoints on the same subject.
It also gives a timelessness to my project because it could have been published anytime between 1850-2023.
I want my viewer to look at this piece and feel like they are reading something from the past.

human: When Jenna Ellis last week became the most recent lawyer to join in an accelerating series of guilty pleas in the Fulton County, Ga., prosecution of Donald Trump and his co-conspirators, she offered a powerful repudiation of the “Big Lie” that could potentially cut the legs out from under Donald Trump’s defense, make her a star witness for prosecutors and a potent weapon against the former president’s political ambitions.
llm: When Jenna Ellis was in high school, she started her own political action committee to support her dad's run for Congress.
She would get up at 5:30 every morning and work on it before heading off to school, where she would often spend her lunch break calling voters.
After the election, she enrolled in law school and began writing op-eds for conservative news outlets like The Blaze and the Washington Times, eventually becoming a full-time pundit.
Now, at age 29, Ellis is a prominent Trump supporter with more than 146,000 Twitter followers and an influential voice on Fox News and CNN.

human: The playoffs are upon us, and this year Major League Baseball likes to think of itself as having a lot to cheer about.

Regular-season attendance for games and viewership on TV are the highest they’ve been in years, a result, many people say, of bold changes to the game’s rules: bigger bases to encourage more stealing (read: action), the intentional walk rule (which eliminates the staging of four outside lobs from pitcher to catcher) and the prohibition on pitchers’ throwing to first base as often when a runner’s on.
llm: The playoffs are a grind.

human: Every January, we ask our most trend-obsessed colleagues to make predictions about the year ahead.
Here are their best guesses about what 2024 will hold for fashion, food, technology and culture.
llm: Every January, we ask our staff to make predictions about the coming year.
Last week, I asked them what they think will be happening in the world of technology in ten years’ time – and here are some of their ideas:

human: A plane flying from London to Orlando, Fla., last month was forced to turn around because some windowpanes were missing or damaged, startling passengers who had reported hearing roaring sounds inside the cabin, the authorities said.
llm: A plane flying from San Juan to Orlando, Florida was forced to make an emergency landing in Fort Lauderdale on Tuesday after a piece of the cockpit window fell out.

The Delta Air Lines MD-80 aircraft was carrying 167 passengers and five crew members when it took off from Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport at around 2:45 p.m., according to the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).

human: In August 2017, Matthew Joseph Vella and Joel Alexander Kimling arrived in Richmond, Va., for a nine-month internship with the Virginia Repertory Theater and were assigned to the same apartment.
llm: In August 2017, the New York Times published an article about a young couple who had been friends for years and decided to move in together.
In January 2016, they started dating each other.
The author of the article wrote that “It was the first time either had lived with a significant other.”

human: This house is a few blocks from Carmel Beach and within walking distance of the Carmel Beach Walk, a hiking trail with sweeping ocean views.

It was built in 1964.

llm: A Maine judge has suspended her decision to exclude Donald Trump from the state's March 5 Republican primary ballot, pending an appeal.

llm: Javier Milei is a proponent of the Austrian School.
He has been talking about the dangers of inflation for years and he was the first to warn about the current crisis in Argentina.
I don't know if you can find his videos with english subtitles, but here are some: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UjxwKFqZg4I (2013) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B_QDWLbOYzc (2017)

human: It’s either a coincidence or a tribute that Britney Spears’s new memoir, “The Woman in Me,” shares its title with one of Shania Twain’s best-selling albums; she is a Southern girl, after all, and Twain helped write one of her early hits, “Don’t Let Me Be the Last to Know.”
“Woman” offers a familiar story of troubled, vertiginous stardom, written in platinum and flashbulbs.
But here it has the cadences and stagecraft of a country song: striving, plucky, littered with almost operatic betrayals and misfortune.
It’s also a tale of qualified triumph, albeit with its own star-crossed postscript.
(The book, which The New York Times obtained in advance of its authorized release, was not edited in time to include her pending divorce from her third husband, Sam Asghari.)
llm: It’s either a very clever bit of marketing or an unfortunate coincidence: “Britney Spears” is the name of a tree that grows in China.
The leaves of this tree have been used for centuries to treat stomach aches and other gastrointestinal issues.

human: Follow New York Times Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and Pinterest.

human: President Biden sought to rally disaffected Black supporters on Monday with a fiery condemnation of former President Donald J. Trump, linking his predecessor’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election to the nation’s history of white supremacy in what he called “the old ghost in new garments.”
llm: President Biden sought to rally black voters in South Carolina on Saturday with a fierce condemnation of President Trump and his policies, arguing that the president has done little for African-Americans while pushing a divisive message and attempting to roll back gains made by Barack Obama.

human: Apparently, some time in 1964, a professional ice skater and animal trainer named Dave Pitts, on the road with his chimp Spanky, picked up a young hitchhiker who was in the middle of a killing spree.
The story of Pitts’s encounter with Larry Lee Ranes, whose brother also became a serial killer, was fictionalized in Conrad Hilberry’s book “Luke Karamazov.”
That book is the source of “He Went That Way,” the picturesque feature directing debut of the cinematographer Jeff Darling, who died in a surfing accident in 2022.
llm: Apparently, some time back, I was given the opportunity to review this book.
However, due to circumstances beyond my control, I was unable to get it read and reviewed in time.
The author was gracious enough to send me another copy for this review.
Thanks goes out to him for that.

llm: MAGIC:

human: With Israel consolidating its hold on northern Gaza, its forces are closing in on a sprawling medical center that for Israelis and Palestinians alike has emerged as a symbol of the other side’s inhumanity.
llm: With Israel consolidating its position in Gaza City, it is no surprise that the focus of their ground offensive has shifted to Rafah.
The city is the southern gateway between Gaza and Egypt and the northern gateway between Gaza and Israel (via the Karem Abu Salem crossing).
As such, Rafah is strategically important for both parties.

human: It is said that wars end when both sides conclude they have nothing more to gain by fighting.
By that logic, Israel and the Palestinians should have long ago agreed to the only solution that makes sense: separate states side by side.
They’ve tried, again and again, but in this cauldron of religious passion and competing grievances, peace has always lost out.
Is there any chance that things will be different when the guns fall silent this time?
llm: It is said that the only way to go forward is to look back.
In this case, we have not looked back far enough.
We have been going in circles for generations, and it is time we stop spinning our wheels and get somewhere.
Our nation has made a lot of progress over the years, but we still have a long way to go.
It is time we make some real changes and move forward as a nation, rather than just taking baby steps.

human: Near the end of “The Coming Wave,” his sweeping look at the future of artificial intelligence and other transformative technologies, Mustafa Suleyman acknowledges the whiplash that listeners must feel as he guides them through this strange new territory — and makes no apologies for it.

“If this book feels contradictory in its attitude toward technology, part positive and part foreboding,” he says, “that’s because such a contradictory view is the most honest assessment of where we are.”
llm: Near the end, she says we need to be careful about “over-hyping” AI…while over-hyping it with her book title and her own claims.

I am also fascinated by the idea of time travel
so when I read about a woman who inherits an old home in South Carolina that is rumored to be haunted and has ties to the civil war era I was hooked.
This story is filled with secrets and mystery and is sure to keep you turning pages long after your bedtime.

human: The rate of serious medical complications increased in hospitals after they were purchased by private equity investment firms, according to a major study of the effects of such acquisitions on patient care in recent years.
llm: The rate of serious medical errors increased significantly at hospitals that were bought by private equity firms, according to a study published in the Journal of Patient Safety.
The study found the rates of patient safety incidents rose 43 percent after acquisition and remained elevated for two years.
The study was co-authored by Kathryn Himmelstein, MD, a fellow in the Division of General Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital.
Dr. Himmelstein’s research focuses on the impact of hospital ownership and management practices on quality and health care costs.

human: As a wheelchair user, I have always had to pay a premium to live in an apartment independently.
In my nine years living in New York City, I have spent more than $18,500 on automatic door openers, amenities just to make the places I’ve lived in accessible.
llm: As a wheelchair user who lives alone and is also a senior, I know that the rent burden I face is higher than for others.
It's true that many seniors have their rents frozen under the Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption (SCRIE) program.
But this benefit does not cover people with disabilities.
So we have to pay the full amount of our increases.

human: Dr. John Wust does not come off as a labor agitator.

A longtime obstetrician-gynecologist from Louisiana with a penchant for bow ties, Dr. Wust spent the first 15 years of his career as a partner in a small business — that is, running his own practice with colleagues.
llm: Dr. John Wustrowski, a retired family physician who practices urgent care at a hospital near Chicago, said he will not participate in Obamacare for moral reasons: "I am completely opposed to the concept of a government-run or government-mandated health care system," he told me.
"It is immoral and contrary to our founding principles."

human: Octobers ago, I crossed a psychic’s door.
She examined me, one gray eye roaming.
“Don’t marry your boyfriend,” she said.
“I don’t have one,” I bluffed.
Both of her eyes focused on me: “You do.”
I married him anyway.

After my husband’s deployment to Afghanistan, after my brother died, after our daughter’s lung collapsed, after our second child went straight to the NICU, after our money ran out and my father was diagnosed with metastatic cancer — he told me, “I think we’re cursed.”
“No.
This is just life,” I said, thinking only of the psychic’s stare.
— Catherine Stern
llm: Octobers ago, I told my boyfriend that if we were still together when he finished his Ph.D., we should get married.
We are now engaged.
He is the best thing that has ever happened to me.
But I feel guilty and wonder whether I was wrong to put pressure on him.
Maybe it would have been better to let things happen naturally?
I know people who got married because they had a baby or bought a house and are now divorced.
Shouldn't marriage be for love?
What do you think?

human: There were evil wizards, TV celebrities and undead beings, yes.
llm: There were evil spirits and witches.

human: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs, vanilla, cocoa, salt.

Made with a store-bought pie crust (or a half-recipe of this foolproof pie dough), it’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.
llm: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs: There’s no way to go wrong with this Southern classic.

human: Russian authorities on Friday detained three lawyers representing the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in what his supporters said was a government-led attempt to continue to isolate him and further limit his ability to influence the country’s political life.
llm: Russian authorities on Wednesday detained the lawyers of Aleksei A. Navalny, a prominent opposition leader who is in jail pending trial for embezzlement charges that he says are politically motivated, his allies said.

human: We meet the main players of Amy Jo Burns’s poignant new novel, “Mercury,” in that golden moment between childhood and adulthood, when they’re young and strong, and it’s just dawning on them that their worlds were circumscribed at birth.
llm: We meet the author of The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks.
Her name was Henrietta Lacks, but scientists know her as HeLa.
She was a poor Southern tobacco farmer who worked the same land as her slave ancestors, yet her cells—taken without her knowledge—became one of the most important tools in medicine.

Rebecca Skloot takes us on an extraordinary journey, from the “colored” ward of Johns Hopkins Hospital in the 1950s to stark white laboratories with freezers full of HeLa cells; from Henrietta’s small, dying hometown of Clover, Virginia—a land of wooden slave quarters, faith healings, and voodoo—to East Baltimore today, where her children and

human: One tunnel in Gaza was wide enough for a top Hamas official to drive a car inside.
Another stretched nearly three football fields long and was hidden beneath a hospital.
Under the house of a senior Hamas commander, the Israeli military found a spiral staircase leading to a tunnel approximately seven stories deep.
llm: One tunnel in particular has been discovered to be 18 meters (60 feet) deep, making it the deepest one yet.
It is thought that this was to avoid Israeli detection technology and allow Hamas to carry out attacks on Israeli soldiers without being spotted.

That is the stunning allegation from the Washington Post this morning:

It was not immediately clear whether “Shucked” would be reworked for future productions.

"We are concerned about the initiative of Israel to build 2,500 housing units in the West Bank," she told reporters after a meeting between EU ministers and Israeli Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman.
"I think that if there is something that can undermine trust it is certainly this announcement of further settlement building activities."

human: In the church of my childhood, we believed God’s angels battled demons in a war for our souls.
This was not a metaphor.
We were Pentecostals, though not strictly and not always.
We weren’t picky about denomination; what mattered was belief in the redeeming blood of Christ, in the Bible literally interpreted and in God’s endless love.
And evil.
We believed in evil.
llm: In the church's view, suffering is a punishment for sin.
The innocent are victims of God's wrath against evil.
This conception was widespread in medieval Europe.
And it still exists today, not only in Christianity but also in Islam.
It is part of the Muslim belief that the faithful will be rewarded with paradise after death and the unfaithful will be punished.

human: Start by keeping your beans away from light and heat.
llm: Start by keeping a notebook or journal of your coffee drinking habits.
This will help you decide what you want from your next brew method.
Do you tend to stick with one type of coffee?
If so, you may be better off with a single-cup method like an AeroPress or Chemex.
On the other hand, if you love to switch it up and try all sorts of different coffees, maybe something more versatile like a French press would work best for you.

human: The Nicaraguan authorities said on Sunday that they had released 19 clergymen who had been jailed and handed them over to the Vatican, the latest development in the autocratic government’s longstanding persecution of the Roman Catholic Church.
llm: The Nicaraguan authorities on Tuesday released two clerics who had been arrested and convicted during the government’s crackdown on opponents of President Daniel Ortega.
The release came hours after Pope Francis criticized their imprisonment during a visit to Panama.
The men were handed over to the custody of the Roman Catholic Church in Managua, the capital, said Bishop Silvio José Báez, an auxiliary bishop there.
Bishop Báez said that he did not know whether the two would be allowed to leave the country.
One of the men, the Rev. Edwing Román Calderón, 40, was convicted last year of money laundering, organized crime and arms trafficking, and sentenced to 15 years in prison.
He denied the charges,

human: It would have been enough of a first for a Broadway musical to tell a respectful or even vaguely authentic story about autistic people.
On the rare occasions we have seen such characters represented in commercial productions, they have mostly been objects of pity, mockery or fear.
llm: It would have been nice if the article had noted that, despite the fact that it was a good thing for the young women involved, this is still not really representative of what life with autism is like.
As a parent of a child with autism, I can tell you that these kids were very high functioning and most likely did not need any sort of long-term support (although we don't know).
Most people on the spectrum will never be able to function at their level, even with intensive therapy.
That said, I wish all children with autism could get that kind of help!

human: Improving America’s schools can sometimes seem like an impossible task.
Politicians have been promising to do so for decades, yet the U.S. remains well behind many other countries in basic measures of learning.
The Covid pandemic, with its extended school closures, aggravated the problems.
llm: Improving America’s schools is one of the most important issues we face as a nation.
Yet, instead of uniting to find solutions, adults have gotten caught up in political fights and ideological battles.
While they argue over school funding levels, teacher quality, school choice and standardized tests, our children are falling further behind their international peers.
We are now ranked 17th in reading, 23rd in science and 31st in math out of 65 countries.
And students from low-income families fare even worse: Only 9 percent of eighth-grade students from low-income families performed at or above the proficient level in math in 2013.

human: To end 2023, we are featuring some seasonal writing by teenagers.
In our Student Opinion question “What Do You Appreciate About Winter?,” we invited students to share the foods, rituals, activities and festivities that help them embrace the colder months.
In our Picture Prompts “Family Drama” and “Giving Tuesday,” we asked them what can be difficult about the holiday season what they are doing to give back this year.
Read a selection of their responses below.
llm: To end 2023, we will have a seasonal issue of our teen writing.
Send us your stories and poems about winter fun, holidays, giving back or drama to be included in this special issue!
Please note that while we are accepting any genre for this issue, all submissions must still fit into the general theme.

human: An article on Friday about Georgia’s voting maps misstated the year that Georgia elected its two Democratic senators.
It was 2021, not 2020.
llm: An article on Monday about the death of William Raspberry referred incorrectly to his columns for The Washington Post.
He won a Pulitzer Prize in 1994; he did not win two.
(The error also appeared in an obituary on July 18 and in articles on July 17 and Aug. 1.)

human: In the summer of 2001, seven months pregnant and working in a research lab in Iowa City, I signed up for an eight-week fiction-writing class taught by James Alan McPherson.
I turned in my very first short story, “Immortality,” which Jim enthused about in class, though I was too inexperienced to understand his excitement.
I told him shyly that I was a scientist but wanted to be a writer.
“What do you mean you want to be a writer?” he said.
“You are a writer.”
llm: In the summer of 2013, I attended a week-long leadership development seminar for women.
During one of our sessions, we were asked to describe the women in our lives who had influenced us positively and negatively.
My positive role models included my mother, grandmother, and several of my friends.
However, when it came time to name some of the negative influences on me as a woman, I was at a loss.

human: A self-taught artist-cartographer and outdoorsman spent three years on an obsessive labor of love with few parallels.

human: When Jhumpa Lahiri released her first story collection, “Interpreter of Maladies,” in 1999, it earned her near-immediate status as one of the English language’s most exciting working authors.
llm: When Jhumpa Lahiri first came to America, she knew little about her new home and was surprised by many things.
But one thing that really stood out for her was how Americans seemed to have a very different relationship with food than Indians do.
In her new book, The Clothing of Books, Lahiri writes that in India people talk about food all the time; they buy it fresh from the market each day and cook it daily.

She found this wasn’t so in America: “In American supermarkets I could find boxes of macaroni-and-cheese, cans of soup, frozen vegetables, bags of chips, but no fresh fish or meat, no fresh vegetables, not even a potato.”
When she arrived at college, she was surprised to see students eating sandwiches, which would

human: Forget whipping out your phone to show off your family photos or tucking a loved one’s face into a locket around your neck.
What if you could wear your favorite memories on your back?
llm: Forget whipping out your phone to take a selfie with your family, or taking the kids to get their portrait taken at JC Penney.
If you really want to capture that special moment with your loved ones and hang it on the wall for everyone to see, then you need to hire professional photographer Sharon Tenenbaum.
Her style is chic and modern, but her photos are still very warm and intimate.
She has been featured in publications like Vogue, Elle Decor, Domino, Town & Country, New York Magazine, Apartment Therapy, and many more.

human: A four-day cease-fire between Israel and Hamas — the first extended break in almost seven weeks of war — will most likely not begin until Friday at the earliest, Israeli officials said on Wednesday night, as negotiators hammered out details of an agreement between Israel and Hamas that would pause the fighting to allow the release of hostages and Palestinian prisoners.
llm: A four-day cease-fire between Israel and Hamas will begin on 8 a.m. local time Friday (1 a.m. EDT) followed by negotiations in Cairo about the release of prisoners, an Israeli official told ABC News today.
The official said that if all goes well, a deal could be reached within a week.

human: For years, a Native American tribe from the picturesque East End of Long Island has fought bitterly for formal state recognition, a designation that was stripped away more than a century ago by court decisions that are now widely considered racist.
llm: For years, a group of about 1,200 people who claim to be descendants of the Montaukett Indians have been trying to get New York State recognition as an Indian tribe.
On Thursday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed a bill that would have granted them that status — the fifth time in recent years that their quest has been denied by a governor.

human: Anita A. Summers, an economist at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania who injected quantitative rigor into a wide variety of public policy topics, including zoning, education and tax incentives, died on Sunday at her home in Gladwyne, Pa.
She was 98.
llm: Anita A. Summers, an economist who applied rigorous statistical analysis to social problems in the United States and abroad, died on Jan. 21 at her home in Manhattan.
She was 98.
The cause was congestive heart failure, said her daughter, Kathryn Sikkink.
Ms. Summers’s early work focused on labor force participation and poverty in India.
Later she studied the impact of unemployment insurance on the willingness of workers to seek jobs.
In 1953, she published “Poverty in a Developing Economy,” a book based on fieldwork in India that examined the interplay between economic development and inequality.
She also wrote extensively about American poverty, including the book “Families on Relief: Case Studies of Urban Pover

human: “The Year’s Best Historical Fiction” on Dec. 10 referred imprecisely to James McBride’s novel “The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store.”

It does not take place just in the 1950s.
llm: “The Year’s Best Science Fiction” series, edited by Gardner Dozois, is the most respected and long-lived anthology of its kind, having been published annually since 1984.

Volume Thirty-Two includes an incredible array of stories from some of science fiction’s greatest up-and-coming writers, as well as award-winning authors, including Ken Liu, Paul McAuley, Maureen McHugh, Pat Murphy, Adam Roberts, Lavie Tidhar, Genevieve Valentine, Jo Walton and many more.

Selecting the best fiction from hundreds of magazines, anthologies and websites, this book features not just the traditional SF virtues but also fantasy, horror and mainstream stories that nevertheless are

human: Dario Amodei, the chief executive of the A.I. company Anthropic, puts his between 10 and 25 percent.
Lina Khan, the chair of the Federal Trade Commission, recently told me she’s at 15 percent.
And Emmett Shear, who served as OpenAI’s interim chief executive for about five minutes last month, has said he hovers somewhere between 5 and 50 percent.
llm: Dario Amodei, the founder of OpenAI's new San Francisco research office and one of its leading researchers on artificial intelligence safety, says he doesn't like the metric.
But it's still useful to measure.
"It has some limitations," he said, "but it's better than anything else we have."

human: It’s the Friday before Caucus Day, and in any other year, Iowa would be humming: candidates racing across the state, answering questions in living rooms, coffee shops and high school gyms.
Last-minute get-out-the-vote speeches.
Volunteers knocking on doors and handing out leaflets on street corners and in shopping malls.
llm: It’s the Friday before Christmas, and I’m standing in a packed high school gymnasium watching a man in a Santa Claus suit sing a song about the need to “deport them all.”
The man is Steve King, the eight-term Republican congressman from Iowa who is beloved by white nationalists.
(In 2017, he tweeted his support for Geert Wilders, a far-right Dutch politician known for his anti-Muslim views.)

human: The Chiefs have a 95% chance to make the playoffs.
llm: The Chiefs have a pretty good shot of making it to the playoffs.
If they can win most, if not all of their remaining games, they should be able to make it in.
I hope that they are able to do it.

human: When a French police officer was found guilty on Friday of assaulting Théo Luhaka, a 22-year-old Black man, during a 2017 identity check that led to his arrest, lawyers on both sides left the courthouse claiming victory in one of France’s most publicized cases of police abuse.
llm: When a French court convicted a police officer this month in the death of a black teenager, it was hailed as a rare victory for justice and a blow against discrimination.
The trial was seen as an important test of how France treats its minorities, particularly blacks and Arabs, who often complain of racial profiling by the police.
But on Monday, after four days of rioting that started when the officer’s sentence — eight years in prison — was considered too light, few people here were celebrating.
Instead, many were left with a sense of unease over what they saw as a weakened state and a society plagued by social inequality and political polarization.
“The question is no longer whether there are two Frances, one white and one black,” said Dominique Sopo

The first eight months of 2017 all broke records for heat.

human: Danny Taing’s 55,000 Kit Kats began their long, twisted and sometimes obscure journey in Japan.

human: As their careers took them to various cities in Europe, the United States and Asia, Stef Claes and Michiel De Meulemeester, who are both Belgian, were used to leasing whatever lackluster apartments they could find.
But when Mr. Claes, an architect, and Mr. De Meulemeester, a business executive who manages Mr. Claes’s firm, settled down in Geneva, they began thinking about creating a more appealing home.
llm: As their careers as architects developed, the young couple had a growing desire to design and build a home for themselves.

They purchased land in the mountains of Switzerland, but when they began planning the house, they realized that their needs were simple: a bedroom, bathroom, kitchen, and living room—and not necessarily in that order.
“We thought, ‘Why don’t we just put everything into one room?’” says Duttweiler.
The result is a 198-square-foot A-frame cabin with only one door, which opens directly onto a terrace framing views of Lake Walensee and the Churfirsten mountain range.
A ladder provides access to an open sleeping loft above the kitchen; a wood-burning stove separates the

human: Finland said on Thursday that it was closing part of its border with Russia after a dramatic increase in migrant crossings that it blamed on Moscow, the latest sign of deteriorating relations between the neighbors since the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
llm: Finland said on Friday that it would close four of its eight border crossings with Russia for two weeks and increase controls at the remaining checkpoints in an attempt to halt a surge in asylum seekers.

human: The Saints now have a 56% chance to make the playoffs.
llm: The Saints now have a real chance at making the playoffs.

human: In this week’s New York Times, Dan Pelosi (a.k.a. @grossypelosi) writes about the Feast of the Seven Fishes, that multicourse seafood dinner served in Italian American households on Christmas Eve.

The classic menu serves up seven different fishes in seven different dishes, but Mr. Pelosi has recalculated the math to subtract the drama that making the feast can generate, as depicted so vividly in Season 2 of “The Bear.”
llm: In this week’s “Ask the Diet Doctor,” Dr. Michael Fenster discusses what you can do to improve your gut health and digestive issues, like bloating, gas, constipation or diarrhea.

human: President Biden will issue an executive order on Monday outlining the federal government’s first regulations on artificial intelligence systems.

They include requirements that the most advanced A.I. products be tested to assure that they cannot be used to produce biological or nuclear weapons, with the findings from those tests reported to the federal government.
llm: President Biden will issue the first regulation for artificial intelligence systems and robotics.
It is a simple rule that says, “If you design or build an AI system or robotic device, you must ensure it is equipped with a kill switch.”
The purpose of this regulation is to prevent malicious use of AI and robots by terrorists or others who wish harm to the United States.
This regulation does not apply to software used in existing personal computers, cell phones, tablets or other similar devices, only those designed for commercial or industrial purposes.
The rule will go into effect 90 days after its publication.

human: The campaign posters were bright and stylish, with slogans like “New York Needs New Voices.”
In 2018, they were all over the East Village, where Emily Heinz Bina was living.
The graphic design caught her eye, but the candidate captured her interest.
llm: The campaign posters are up, the TV ads are running, and the candidates are everywhere.
The 2016 presidential election is in full swing, but a new poll reveals that women aren't as excited about it as they used to be.
