human: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance that you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead.
But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.
llm: On any given night, there are usually about a dozen meteors (also called shooting stars) streaking through the sky.
But this weekend, as Earth passes through the debris trail left behind by Comet Tempel-Tuttle, you can see dozens of meteors in just an hour or two.
That’s because the comet left plenty of material in its wake—as many as 100,000 particles per square kilometer!
The annual shower is known as the Leonid meteor shower since it appears to originate from within the constellation Leo.

human: After the well over 1,000 Israelis killed on Oct. 7, and the thousands more Palestinians in Gaza killed in the war against Hamas, it may appear unseemly to focus on the relatively small and sadly familiar clashes between settlers and Palestinians in the West Bank.
But it would be a mistake to overlook the danger of the escalation in settler violence over the past month.
llm: After the well-publicized settler attacks on Palestinian villages in the West Bank, including the recent torching of a mosque in the village of Yasuf near Nablus, Israel's President Shimon Peres said that he is "ashamed" and that such violence cannot be ignored.

human: Outrage has rippled through the Arab world over a blast that killed hundreds at a hospital in Gaza.

President Biden, on a wartime trip to Israel, firmly backed the Israeli government’s assertion that Israel did not cause the hospital explosion, which U.S. and Israeli intelligence officials said appeared to be the result of an errant rocket fired by Palestinian fighters.
llm: Outrage has rippled through the social media world over a Facebook post by one of the jurors who found George Zimmerman not guilty in the shooting death of Trayvon Martin.
According to ABC News, the woman identified as Maddy tweeted that she “wanted to slap the sh-t” out of Rachel Jeantel and that she felt sorry for Trayvon’s mom because “she raised a little thug.”
The tweets have since been deleted but not before being captured by screen grabs.

human: Uncovering the unlikely story behind the singer’s first album.
llm: Uncovering the unlikely genesis of the Irish singer-songwriter’s most powerful album.

human: It’s easy to be blasé about a new exposé of Fox News.
There have been many, going back at least as far as Al Franken’s best-selling 2003 book “Lies (And the Lying Liars Who Tell Them): A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right.”
Fox News, at this point, resembles a car whose windshield is thickly encrusted with traffic citations.

Yet this car (surely a Hummer) manages to barrel out anew each day, plowing over six more mailboxes, five more crossing guards, four elderly scientists, three communal enterprises, two trans kids and a solar panel.
llm: It’s easy to get caught up in the “he said, she said” nature of our current media landscape and lose sight of the fact that there is such a thing as objective truth.
The facts are out there; it’s just harder and harder to find them.
As the title of his new book suggests, Brian Stelter understands this better than most.

human: Around the world, authoritarianism is ascendant and democracy is in decline.
llm: Around the world, a rising tide of authoritarian leaders is targeting civil society organizations with burdensome laws and regulations.
This is not simply a reaction to a global crisis in democracy: it is an attack on civil society as the infrastructure of democracy.

human: As Israel prepares this week to face accusations at the International Court of Justice that it has committed genocide in the Gaza war, it has appointed one of the country’s most prominent jurists as the ad hoc judge to sit on the bench on its behalf.
llm: As Israel prepares to take Iran before an international court on charges of genocide, the country has chosen a 91-year-old judge who is himself a Holocaust survivor to lead the legal team.

human: It’s divisible by four.
It’s a leap year.
It’s a Summer Olympics year.
llm: It’s divisible by four.
And that’s about all it has going for it.

human: Radcliffe Bailey, a Georgia-based artist whose collage paintings and sculptural assemblages incorporated family tintypes, African figurines, disassembled piano keys and other objects in an exploration of both his personal history and the broader sorrows and joys of the Black experience, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Atlanta.
He was 54.
llm: Radcliffe Bailey, a painter and sculptor who explored the African diaspora through richly layered works that combined found objects with paint, printmaking and photography, died on Aug. 13 in Atlanta.
He was 54.

human: The poet Cornelius Eady took out his phone the other day and clicked to a black-and-white group photo that was taken 43 summers ago when he was a fellow at Bread Loaf, the famous writers’ retreat held each year in Vermont.
Eady is easy to spot — he is the only Black person in the picture.
llm: The poet Cornelius Eady, who was the first executive director of Cave Canem, said that the workshop’s founders were “very aware” of the fact that there had been a few black poets in each generation who managed to become successful.
“But we wanted a place where everybody could be successful,” he told me over the phone recently.
“We didn’t want to see people lose themselves in their desire to get ahead.”

human: This winter, for the first time in recent history, it’s possible to ice skate underneath the Brooklyn Bridge.
llm: This winter, for the first time in 10 years, the Dufferin Grove rink house will be closed.
The city is renovating it over the summer to make room for a commercial kitchen that will allow the park to host more events and sell food.
For the first couple of months, the park’s ice-making equipment has been relocated to a temporary trailer.
But starting this week, the entire operation—including the compressor room and skate lending program—is being moved to a new spot: the old horse stable.

human: Our affinity for sheet-pan dinners is downright Seussian.
We like a sheet pan with salmon and potatoes.
We like a sheet pan with feta and tomatoes.
We like a sheet pan with chicken and bok choy.
A sheet-pan bibimbap?
That’s pure joy.
Now Melissa Clark has a new recipe for sheet-pan turmeric chicken and crispy rice, a dish inspired by Persian tahdig, Korean nurungji and Spanish socarrat.
Lemony, gingery chicken legs with golden, chewy-crispy rice make a richly flavored dinner that’s very easy and very nice.
llm: Our affinity for sheet pans knows no bounds.
We use them to make whole roasted fish, vegetables, and chickens, but we also use them to bake cookies and brownies.
This recipe is a bit of an anomaly:
It's not really a sheet pan dinner per se—there's no rice involved, so it doesn't have the one-pan appeal—but it does call for some browning in the oven, which we can get behind any day of the week.
The result is a deeply flavored chicken thigh that gets a little crisped up on top from its time under the broiler.
A squeeze of lime juice and a sprinkling of cilantro at the end adds brightness to this otherwise mellow dish.

human: The United States is entangled in an emotional debate about antisemitism and free speech on college campuses.
The latest speech debate in China is about a chef’s video on how to make egg fried rice.
llm: The United States is not alone in its current struggles to strike a balance between free speech and security.
While some countries, like Russia, are moving to limit online freedoms, others have recently taken steps toward greater Internet freedom.
On July 1, a new law went into effect in Tunisia that guaranteed freedom of information online.
And on June 30, the European Court of Human Rights ruled against Turkey for blocking access to YouTube.
The court found that the Turkish government had violated Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which protects the right to freedom of expression.
This is an important victory for free expression in Europe.

human: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota, a Democrat who began a long-shot primary challenge to President Biden last month, said on Friday that he would not run for re-election next year.
llm: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota said he would not run for re-election in 2020, leaving behind a competitive district.
The move will open up the Minneapolis suburbs to an array of potential candidates from both parties.

human: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees!
Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum.
There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
llm: TUESDAY — Hi!
I'm here to talk about the upcoming production of The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee, which will open on February 16 at the Kelsey Theatre.
This is a very funny musical with some catchy tunes and lots of humor.
There are only six characters: four students who are competing in the spelling bee (and one adult), a hostess for the event, and a comfort counselor.
But the cast is also joined by audience members who volunteer to come on stage as guest spellers.
It should be a lot of fun.
I hope you can join us for this special show!
-Director Frank Ferrara

human: In the aftermath of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s assertion that “agents” of the Indian government were involved in the shooting death of a Sikh leader in British Columbia, my colleagues Norimitsu Onishi and Vjosa Isai looked into growing tensions within the Indian diaspora in Canada, ones that reflect divisions in India that have been fueled by Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu nationalism.
llm: In the aftermath of the attack, Mr. Trudeau said, he learned something about his Sikh heritage that he had not known before.
“The reason I wasn’t targeted is because there were so many people who stepped forward and said ‘No, we are all Sikhs,’” he said.
“I didn’t realize until then how deeply my father was embedded in the psyche of the community.”

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kyle Chayka.
Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
llm: Every Tuesday and Thursday, the J-school has a series of workshops called "Tech Tuesdays" and "Thursday Tech Talks."
These workshops are meant to help students navigate the new digital age and all it entails.
It's also a great way to get to know your fellow classmates as well as faculty members outside of the classroom setting.

human: This has been updated to reflect news developments.
llm: This has been a week of cease-fire diplomacy, and the results have not been encouraging.
The Lebanese government is unable to meet in Beirut because it fears Hezbollah rocket attacks.
The Israeli cabinet was unable to agree on any terms for a cease-fire until Israel’s security needs are met.
In other words, the Middle East continues its descent into warfare as usual.

human: Up a steep and grassy windblown hill, in the top row of what’s known as the new graveyard, the playwright Brian Friel lies buried under a dark, glossy slab etched with an image of a St. Brigid’s cross, a traditional Irish symbol woven from rushes.
llm: Up a steep hill, past the old Catholic church and up some more, we came to a small cemetery on the outskirts of Glenties.
It was here that Brian Friel found the grave of his great-uncle, which inspired his play “Dancing at Lughnasa.”
The grave is unassuming, but there is a plaque commemorating its place in history as well as the playwright’s family connection to it.

human: The word obscurity has appeared in 146 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 26 in “A Mongolian Marathoner’s Secret Weapon?
Staying Power” by Scott Cacciola:
llm: The word obscurity is a noun.
Obscurity means (1) an unclear or indistinct idea, (2) the quality of being difficult to perceive, (3) the state of being unknown; lacking fame or acclaim.
The Quisto editorial staff has evaluated these websites and placed them in the Obscurity information category.

human: With two election cycles after the decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization under our belts, it cannot be denied: Abortion rights are the dominant issue in American politics.
And when supporters of abortion rights — a clear majority of Americans — see a connection between their votes and protecting what was once guaranteed by Roe v. Wade, they are more likely to vote.
llm: With two election cycles to go before the 2016 presidential election, we're already getting a glimpse of what's going to be on the political agenda for the next three years: abortion.

In fact, it seems like every time you turn around there's some new controversy over the procedure and its politics — from Wendy Davis' filibuster in Texas, to North Carolina's omnibus anti-abortion bill, to the recent Supreme Court decision striking down Massachusetts' buffer zones.
The latest?
A federal appeals court ruling that says states can legally ban abortions after 20 weeks, even if the mother's life is at risk.
It's an alarming precedent, and one that could be used

human: After a historic vote to remove Kevin McCarthy from the speakership, House Republicans agreed last night to spend the next week without a formal leader.
That means that no votes will be held, no legislation will be passed and the House of Representatives will be effectively powerless until a new speaker is elected.
llm: After a historic and stunning election, the Republican Party is poised to control both houses of Congress for at least two years.
But that power will be constrained by the fact that there are no clear leaders on either side of Capitol Hill.
The Senate has just elected its majority leader, Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), and its minority leader, Harry Reid (D-Nev.).
In the House, John Boehner (R-Ohio) was reelected speaker by a wide margin over Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) on Tuesday, but it was not without dissent.

human: Patients including babies at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza are dying because of a lack of power, medical staff said amid conflicting accounts from Israel and health authorities in Gaza over why a badly needed fuel delivery for the besieged and crumbling facility had been held up.
llm: Patients including babies and the elderly were given potentially fatal doses of painkillers, a report reveals.

human: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week.
They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay.
We know this can be daunting for newer solvers.
If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use.
We recommend ctrl + f
the number of the clue you’re looking for.
You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.
llm: Friday crosswords are always a little easier than the rest of the week, and this one was no exception.
I did not have any trouble with it.
I did get caught up in 24A (Pie) at first.
I thought that maybe "pie" would be something like "Cut" or "Slice".
I'm glad I didn't take the time to go looking through my dictionary for some obscure synonym for "piece."

human: Russia’s hard-liners are rattling the nuclear saber vigorously these days, on television and in academic journals, arguing that an atomic blast — in Ukraine, in Europe, or maybe in a test over Siberia — is the only way to restore the West’s fear of Russian might.
llm: Russia’s hard-liners are making a nuclear comeback.
A new generation of leaders is taking over in Moscow, and it has discovered that nuclear weapons are useful for more than just deterrence.
They are an instrument of policy, too.

human: Concerned about the effect on diversity, many colleges have stopped requiring standardized tests.
New research suggests that might be a mistake.
llm: Concerned about the growing influence of standardized testing, a group of colleges and universities formed the anti-SAT organization FairTest in 1985.
The group has since grown to more than 700 members, including dozens of schools that no longer require applicants to submit their scores from the ACT or SAT.

human: “In the fight against dragons, we have to be cautious not to become dragons ourselves.”
llm: “In the fight against Russia, it doesn’t really matter who is president.
In the fight against corruption, it matters a lot.”

human: Whenever I decide to cook straight from the pantry, one of two things usually results: pasta or beans.
llm: Whenever I decide to make a meal that's packed with protein, one of the first things I think about is pasta.
(Yeah, yeah, carbs aren't really considered a protein source.
Just let me have this one.)
This dish has all the best parts of a protein-packed meal: It's easy to prepare, it can be made in bulk, and it takes only a few ingredients to bring together.
The star of this dish is undoubtedly the beans.
They're mixed with pasta, fresh herbs, and a splash of red wine vinegar for an extra pop of flavor.
It's a simple recipe but one that will leave you full and satisfied.
Ready to give it a try?
Keep

human: Including titles by Siddhartha Mukherjee, Jemele Hill, Kelly Link and more.
llm: Including titles by Helen Phillips, Kiese Laymon, and Carmen Maria Machado.

human: Wildfires caused by drought, warmer-than-normal temperatures and, in a few cases, possibly arson have been ablaze for days in several Southern states.
The threat has led officials to enact burn bans and to stop issuing safe-burn permits.
llm: Wildfires caused by drought and strong winds are burning across the South, including this one in Bastrop County, Texas, on Oct. 16, 2015.

human: You hear the superlatives now with disorienting regularity: the largest protests in American history, in European history, in Latin American history; the largest since Black Lives Matter, since the Women’s March; the biggest since Occupy and the Tea Party, since the Arab Spring or the Pink Tide or the global rallies against the Iraq war in 2003.
llm: You hear the argument all the time: "Protests don't achieve anything."

human: Six years ago, an executive from Suniva, a bankrupt solar panel manufacturer, warned a packed hearing room in Washington that competition from companies in China and Southeast Asia was causing a “blood bath” in his industry.
More than 30 U.S.-based solar companies had been forced to shut down in the previous five years alone, he said, and others would soon follow unless the government supported them.
llm: Six years ago, a small California company called OptiSolar built an assembly plant in Hayward for making solar panels.
It failed after just two years, but not before collecting nearly $50 million in federal and state subsidies.

human: Shlomo Avineri, an Israeli political scientist, historian and former government official whose pessimism about resolving the conflict with Palestinians did not stop him from advocating measures to ease it, died on Nov. 30 in Jerusalem.
He was 90.
llm: Shlomo Avineri, an Israeli scholar who was a leading voice of the Israeli left and a skeptic about peace with Palestinians, died on Sunday in Jerusalem.
He was 90.

human: “Gutenberg!
The Musical!,” a comic meta-musical about two talentless dolts pitching a show about the father of the printing press, wraps up its limited Broadway run on Jan. 28.
llm: “Gutenberg!
The Musical!,” a 2006 Off-Broadway musical, tells the story of two men who set out to write a blockbuster musical about Johann Gutenberg.

human: Yesterday, we went inside Donald Trump’s campaign for president, to understand how he’s trying to turn a mountain of legal trouble into a political advantage.
Today, we turn to the re-election campaign of President Biden.
llm: Yesterday, we went to the polls in our little town of Franklin and voted for the candidates that we wanted.
Today, I learned that my preferred candidate had lost by a few hundred votes.
My heart sank for a minute.
But then I thought about how lucky we are to have this privilege as citizens in this country.
Not everyone gets to vote.
Some people live in countries where their votes don't matter because they only get one choice.
And some people would like to be able to vote but aren't allowed because of their race or gender.
As Americans, we can feel proud that we get to make these decisions for ourselves.
So today, instead of being sad about who won or lost an election, let's just be happy that we all have a say in it!

human: Five medical students found dead inside a vehicle, their bodies bearing signs of torture.
llm: Five medical students, two men and three women, were ambushed in a mountainous area.
Their bodies were found on the side of the road with evidence that they had been tortured before being shot to death.

human: Hours after Hamas gunmen crossed the border into Israel, slaughtering and kidnapping soldiers and random civilians alike, Palestinians in Gaza knew what was coming next.
llm: Hours after Hamas and Islamic Jihad terrorists fired a barrage of 50 rockets at southern Israel, the IDF launched an operation to destroy cross-border tunnels built by the terrorist groups.

human: After suspending the public release of youth unemployment rates last year, China started distributing the information again on Wednesday, using different measurement criteria that lowered the figure significantly.
llm: After suspending the release of its monthly unemployment rate in March, China has restarted the practice.
The official jobless rate for urban residents between 25 and 39 years old was 4.01% in June, according to data released on Wednesday by the Ministry of Human Resources and Social Security.
That’s lower than the 4.1% recorded a year earlier.
[Source]

human: In the wake of Sandra Day O’Connor’s passing, I saw a photo of her with my father, Ronald Reagan, after he had nominated her to be the first woman on the Supreme Court.
They were outside on the grounds of the White House, walking side by side, smiling, obviously in the midst of a conversation.
These were two people who were athletic, strong, driven to make a difference in the world.
llm: In the wake of Sandra Day O'Connor's announcement that she is stepping down from the Supreme Court, I've been reading up on her life and work.
As a feminist, I am deeply grateful to Justice O'Connor for what she has done for women in this country.
But as a straight ally, I was particularly moved by one of her remarks on the subject of marriage equality:

human: Workers can be barred from wearing religious garb, such as head scarves, in the offices of public administrations, a European Union court ruled on Tuesday, tapping into a charged debate in Europe about expressions of faith in public institutions.
llm: Workers can be barred from wearing religious symbols at work, the European Union's top court ruled on Tuesday, saying that bans could help companies maintain a neutral working environment and protect workers who might otherwise feel pressured to wear such emblems.

human: Former President Donald J. Trump attacked Vivek Ramaswamy, who is most closely aligned with him in the race for the Republican nomination, accusing the wealthy entrepreneur of engaging in “deceitful campaign tricks.”
llm: Former President Donald Trump has turned on Ramaswamy Venkatraman, just days before the Iowa caucus.

human: The big moments of the holiday season are whizzing by, and next up are Noche Buena and the Feast of the Seven Fishes, both on Christmas Eve and both occasions for amazing food.
We have a new Seven Fishes menu that published yesterday with recipes from the wonderful Dan Pelosi — a.k.a.
GrossyPelosi of Instagram fame and the new cookbook “Let’s Eat.”
(And since I won’t see you before then, here are recipes for Christmas dinner and Kwanzaa, too.)
llm: The big moments in life are sometimes the ones you don’t see coming.
I know that sounds like a line from a movie, but it’s true!
Sometimes it takes looking back to realize just how much has changed, or how different things are now.
It could be something as small as moving across town, changing jobs, getting a new car—or something as huge as becoming a parent or buying your first house.
But the point is this: those changes can have a ripple effect on your life, and they often bring other, unexpected changes along with them.
In my case, some of the biggest changes in my life have happened in my kitchen.

human: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States.
These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend.
As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
llm: In the Where Y’at Magazine “Best of the Big Easy” 2017 edition, we were honored to be chosen for Best Crawfish Etouffee and Best Place to get Fried Chicken.
We also made the list for Best Place to Brunch (with our Sunday brunch) and Best Muffaletta.

human: Homelessness surged this year to the highest level on record, the federal government reported on Friday.
llm: Homelessness surged this year to the highest level on record in Los Angeles County and across most of Southern California, driven by soaring housing costs and stubbornly high rental vacancy rates, according to a new report released Wednesday.

human: Good morning.
It’s Monday.
We’ll find out what drives the trucks on the stage in “Carmen” at the Metropolitan Opera.
We’ll also get details on subway service on the 1, 2 and 3 lines after the derailment last week on the Upper West Side.
llm: Good morning.
It’s Friday, May 31, and the sun is shining in New York City.
Here are some of the stories we’re following today.

human: A federal judge ruled on Tuesday that a conservative group’s efforts to challenge the eligibility of hundreds of thousands of voters in the Senate runoff elections in Georgia in early 2021 did not violate the Voting Rights Act under a clause outlawing voter suppression.
llm: A federal judge ruled Friday that the conservative group Judicial Watch can depose members of a state agency as part of its lawsuit over voting challenges ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

human: Helen Mirren declared herself to be “in love with them,” and Gabrielle Union said that “they might be the most comfortable shoes I have ever worn in my life.”
Julia Roberts, Viola Davis and Drew Barrymore have worn them to Hollywood premieres.
Queen Camilla owns 13 pairs and wears them at almost all of her public engagements.
llm: Helen Mirren declared herself a fan.
"I've been wearing them for years," she said, noting that her favorite pair is the low-top black sneaker from the brand's Classic collection.
"They are so comfortable and elegant.
I wear them with everything!"

human: “The Sweet East,” a shape-shifting satire about modern American subcultures, is a curious — occasionally delightful — object.
Its doe-eyed leading lady, Lillian (Talia Ryder), is like the reincarnation of her ostensible namesake, the silent film star Lillian Gish.
Both are blank canvasses filled out by different kinds of American dreams.
Not the gooey, aspirational sort, but the delusional kind that makes you question humanity’s worth even though you can’t look away.
llm: “The Sweet East,” a new play by Stephen Metcalfe, is set in a time and place that are no longer with us.
It was the late 1960s, when the world was still ruled by men who wore suits to work and didn’t leave their wives for younger women.
It was also a time of relative innocence; one character describes it as “a sweet east wind that blew across America.”
That wind has now changed into something darker and more destructive — an ill wind that blows nobody any good.
Read More…

human: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Monday that Google’s power in online search was so ubiquitous that even his company found it difficult to compete on the internet, becoming the government’s highest-profile witness in its landmark antitrust trial against the search giant.
llm: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified at a Senate hearing on Tuesday that the company has been harmed by what he described as Google’s unfair and anti-competitive search practices.

human: China is installing about as many solar panels and wind turbines as the rest of the world combined, and is on track to meet its target for clean energy six years early.
It is using renewables to meet nearly all of the growth in its electricity needs.
llm: China is installing a new coal-fired power plant every 7 to 10 days.

human: Anyone who has an urge to design a house but lacks architectural training should take courage from Hun-Chung Lee.
llm: Anyone who has ever built a house knows that the architect can be a problem.
The architect may want to build what he wants to build rather than what you want.
And there's always a tension between the budget and the design; in the end, something is compromised.

human: When the Opinion columnist David Brooks was growing up, he was emotionally detached, he says.
Over the past several years, he’s worked to change that.

In this audio essay, Brooks shares what he learned opening up with others on his journey to become a fuller human being: that better conversation could help save America from its “social and emotional breakdown.”
llm: When the Opinion columnist David Brooks wrote recently that “the real tension is between freedom and connection,” he was talking about the tensions in America, but it could just as well be read as a mission statement for his own life.

His new book, “The Second Mountain: The Quest for a Moral Life” (Random House), is an argument against living for career status or material success and in favor of the deep relationships that help us live fuller lives.
In his Op-Ed this weekend, he explains how to get there.
Here we talk with him about what he learned on his own journey toward connection.

human: Millions of birds fly over Chicago during the fall migration season, and a number of them die after being confused by bright lights or after trying to fly through a window, but the carpet of bird carcasses outside a convention center on Thursday morning shocked people who have been monitoring birds in the city for decades.
llm: Millions of birds die each year by striking buildings.
One of the most common species killed is the white-throated sparrow.
Photo: Wikimedia Commons

human: Hey, it’s election season!
Think about it: A year from now, we should know who the next president is going to be and …
llm: Hey, it’s election day.
How about a little something to think about?

human: A devastating fire engulfed a multistory shopping center in the Pakistani port city of Karachi on Saturday, killing at least 10 people and injuring dozens more, officials said.
The disaster drew attention to the continuing fire risks in a densely populated city where building codes are often ignored.
llm: A devastating fire at a shopping mall in Lahore, Pakistan's second largest city, killed at least ten people and injured more than twenty on Sunday.
The blaze started on the fourth floor of the four-story building that houses the popular Shabo shoe store.
According to reports from Reuters news service, some of the victims were trapped by metal security gates in front of the store.
Others who tried to flee through the emergency exits found them locked.
At least two dozen people are still unaccounted for, and the death toll is expected to rise.

human: Good morning, dear connectors.
Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
llm: Good morning, dear friends.
I hope you all had a wonderful weekend and that you are enjoying the fall weather.
It is gorgeous here in Florida right now.
I have been working on this piece for several weeks and it's finally finished.
I am so glad to be able to share it with you today.
The background was inspired by a beautiful picture of a sunset over the ocean at night.
I love the colors in the picture.
I decided to use the same colors as the picture, but with a different technique.
I used a black gel pen to draw a border around the edge of the canvas.
Then I painted the whole canvas with white acrylic paint.
When that dried, I drew a series of circles with a pencil.
Next I went back and filled each circle

human: It’s hard to walk a block or finish a morning coffee without encountering some system that attempts to tell you what to read, what to buy, how to lose weight or prevent dementia or tweak your decisions in other specific ways.
My watch constantly buzzes with “relax reminders.”
The number of calories appears next to every menu item at fast-food restaurants.
llm: It’s hard to miss the irony here.

“The Science of Sin” is all about how people aren’t as rational as they think, and yet in this case the New York Times seems more interested in a good story than actually thinking through the evidence presented by the article.
The Times article has already been picked up by other news sources like MSNBC.com, which ran it under the headline, “Sinfulness may be part of human nature.”
The headlines themselves are misleading, because as I’ve pointed out, the article doesn’t say that sin is necessarily an innate trait.
Rather, it says we often make decisions without being fully aware of our own motives.
But even if you believe that some behaviors are innately “sinful,” the New York Times article isn’t

human: Jesse Armstrong didn’t always know how “Succession” would end.
But he knew how that ending would feel.
“It was always a bit about human mortality and the mortality of these kinds of media operations,” he said.
As early as the pilot, he added, “I knew what the tone of the ending would be.”
llm: Jesse Armstrong didn’t set out to make a show that was about Donald Trump.
It just happened that way.

human: Fifty years into the history of hip-hop, street to stage transfers remain tricky.
Hip-hop dance is diverse and globally dominant, but when it’s put on concert stages, something often gets lost.
llm: Fifty years into its history, hip hop dance is one of the most influential and popular forms of American dance.

As it has evolved from street dance to concert stage art form, hip hop dance has been presented in various ways: as battles between crews, as commercial entertainment, and as aesthetic works of choreography.
This article focuses on how hip hop choreographers are bringing their work to the concert stage.
I examine three concert dance works that were created by prominent hip hop artists, and explore how these works fit within the larger context of hip hop culture.
Using the lens of the anthropologist Clifford Geertz’s concept of “thick description,” I consider each piece within its cultural setting, including the venue and audience.
In doing so, I illustrate how these

human: When it came time to find a salon for her daughter with coiled hair, Aude Livoreil-Djampou discovered what many women with curly or textured hair in Paris already knew.
llm: When it came time for the haircut, Ms. Guizien sat me down and examined my hair.
She asked what products I used at home — I told her none — and then she took out her comb.
It was an oddly shaped thing, like an oversize teaspoon with teeth.
As she drew it through my curls, it made no sound but left behind a trail of smoothness.

human: The European Central Bank held interest rates steady on Thursday for the first time in over a year as policymakers moved into their next phase of fighting inflation amid signs the region’s economy has weakened.
llm: The European Central Bank (ECB) decided to leave interest rates unchanged at 4 percent as expected.
The central bank has now raised borrowing costs four times since mid-2007 bringing the benchmark rate up by 100 basis points.

human: Shortly after she became governor of New York, Kathy Hochul made an announcement that caught the higher-education world off guard: The state, which has generally regarded all its public universities as equals, would start treating two universities as “flagships.”
llm: Shortly after she became chancellor of the University of Massachusetts at Boston, J. Keith Motley was dismayed to find out that his campus had been ranked 10th in the United States among colleges that are “easiest to get into.”

human: More than at any other time since World War II, liberalism is under siege.
On the left, some people insist that liberalism is exhausted and dying and unable to handle the problems posed by entrenched inequalities, corporate power and environmental degradation.
On the right, some people think that liberalism is responsible for the collapse of traditional values, rampant criminality, disrespect for authority and widespread immorality.
llm: More than at any other time in history, mankind faces a crossroads.
One path leads to despair and utter hopelessness.
The other, to total extinction.
Let us pray we have the wisdom to choose correctly.

human: My mother, who is in her early 70s and was widowed about a year ago, has been struggling to adjust to life without her husband.
As her only child, I have also been struggling to find ways to be helpful.
Finances have been a particular challenge for her; one concern is the cost of her cable and streaming subscriptions.
llm: My mother, who is a widow in her mid-70s, has begun spending exorbitant amounts of money on pornography and sex toys.
She is still physically attractive and lives in an active senior community where she socializes with friends.
Although we have never discussed it, I assume that my father’s death two years ago has left her feeling lonely, but this seems like a bizarre way to cope.
How do I address this issue?

human: The Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill to fund the federal government through mid-November.
See how each senator voted.
llm: The Senate overwhelmingly voted to move forward with a stopgap spending measure that would keep the government open until February 8, but it was still unclear whether the House of Representatives would vote in favor of the measure before the current funding bill expires at midnight.
The final vote on the measure was 79-18.

human: On a Thursday night last October, Ryan Carlos set off the metal detectors at the door of Brooklyn Steel, a popular music venue in Williamsburg.
A security guard pulled him aside, patted him down and instructed him to turn out his pockets.
llm: On a Thursday night in March, the electronic dance musician Skrillex was scheduled to perform at a club called the Mid in Chicago.
Hours before the show started, an overdosed patron was carried out of the Mid and taken to a hospital.
The paramedics who responded used two doses of naloxone, sold under the brand name Narcan, to revive him.
Then they left, without making any arrests.

human: When an illustrator and a poet went searching for queer stories in the history and mythology of Greco-Roman antiquity, they found nothing less than an army of boyfriends.
Specifically, in the fourth century B.C., an elite troop composed only of pairs of gay lovers battled its way across ancient Greece.
llm: When an illustrator draws a gay couple, the world stops and listens.
It’s time to make this part of our daily lives.

human: Today is Election Day, and we are using this newsletter to give you a guide.
One theme is that Democrats are hoping to continue their strong recent electoral performance despite President Biden’s low approval rating.
llm: Today is Election Day!
I hope you are planning on voting.

human: The soldiers’ mission was as dangerous as it was audacious: a trek of more than 500 miles through mountainous jungle in northern Burma to seize a Japanese-held airfield in World War II.
llm: The soldiers’ mission was to fight behind enemy lines in the jungles of Burma.

human: It was rare for Jewish women to practice radiology in post-Stalinist Russia, but that’s what Diana Amastis, now 95, did for most of her life in St. Petersburg in the 1950s and ’60s.
llm: It was rare for me to go out on a Friday evening because I knew I would have to run from gangs of Russian skinheads, or neo-Nazis.

human: “Lovers in Auschwitz” is, as the title portends, a nonfiction account of two Jews who became lovers in Auschwitz.

The journalist Keren Blankfeld adapted it from her viral 2019 New York Times article and structured the book as a kind of braided biography; alternating chapters tell the story of David, a boy from Poland who dreams of becoming a singer, and of Zippi, a confident, talented girl from Slovakia.
llm: “Lovers in Auschwitz” by Primo Levi

human: Andriy Koshelev steered his car into the driveway of his home on Pushkin Street in Bilozerka, a lakeside town in Ukraine’s Kherson region.
Leaving the car on, Koshelev got out and walked to the entrance gate.
He reached down to loosen the latch.
When he pulled it, the gate exploded.
Koshelev’s parents, who lived on the same property, rushed outside as acrid smoke filled their driveway and the street.
The explosion resounded across town.
llm: Andriy Koshelev steered his motorcycle into the dirt driveway of a house in this western Ukrainian village and stopped, unnerved by what he saw: a pile of furniture, a smashed computer, clothes strewn about.
Then he looked to his right and saw it — the remains of a man who had been beaten to death with baseball bats, stabbed with knives and hanged from a tree in front of his own home.
A sign hung on the body: “This is a traitor.”

human: This year alone, Bishop Joseph Strickland of Tyler, Texas, has accused the pope of undermining the Catholic faith, has suggested that other Vatican officials have veered so far from church teaching that they are no longer Catholic, and has warned that a landmark global gathering that opens this week at the Vatican could threaten “basic truths” of Catholic doctrine.
llm: This year alone, 2019, has seen 43 mass shootings in the US.
There were 58 shootings total in all of 2018.

human: The New York Police Department detained 34 demonstrators at the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade who were protesting Israel’s killings of civilians in Gaza, the authorities said on Friday.
llm: The New York Times, November 25, 2011: "Protester Interrupts the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day Parade"

human: The documentary “South to Black Power” — directed by Sam Pollard and Llewellyn M. Smith — employs many of the gestures a newspaper opinion piece might.
Which is apt, since Charles M. Blow, an opinion columnist for The New York Times, is the film’s searching guide — but also, at times, its expounding subject.
llm: The documentary “South to Black Power,” which will be shown at the New York African Film Festival, examines the early days of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee.

human: Long ago, in a moment of youthful discontent, I stumbled upon a primitive listicle on a now forgotten website that advised the reader on how to deal with feelings of dislike.
llm: Long ago, in the days of the first Queen Elizabeth, I was a courtier.

It is true that my sovereign has been dead these many years; it is likewise true that I was but lately born to the unlife; but we courtiers serve for eternity, and until such time as some great change comes over the world, I shall wait upon her Majesty, a spirit devoted to the service of one who valued her servants well.

human: As legal cases against former President Donald J. Trump churn forward on at least five fronts, two of them related to his lie that the 2020 election was stolen from him, his campaign is advancing baseless claims that the 2024 election, too, is on track to be stolen from him.
llm: As legal cases involving Trump's campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, continue to play out in Florida courts, Trump has called for the remaining debates to be cancelled.
The GOP front-runner is demanding that his opponents Ted Cruz and John Kasich do not show up for the next two debates scheduled to take place before the April 19 New York primary.

human: A teenager jailed in Egypt, determined to bear witness to the abuses he suffered during years of detention.
A proponent of peace in Colombia, shadowed by death threats.
A father in India, fighting his own patriarchal impulses to give his two daughters a better life.
llm: A teenager jailed for killing a man by firing an airgun pellet at him has been released early from prison.
Michael Thompson, now 24, was 16 when he shot his friend Andrew Morrison in the eye with an air rifle.
The 24-year-old victim died three days later and Mr Thompson was convicted of manslaughter.
He served six years of his eight-year sentence before being freed last week.
It is understood he had been granted home leave as part of his rehabilitation but failed to return to jail.

human: In some ways, the original New Mexico Museum of Art was too much of a good thing.
The building, located just off the historic Santa Fe Plaza, is a prime example of the Pueblo Revival style of architecture that defines the capital and makes it a popular destination for tourists.
Covered in earthy, brown stucco, and with roof timbers protruding through its exterior walls, the 1917 structure is decorated along doorways, stairs and ceilings with intricately carved wood trim.
llm: In some ways, it’s a miracle that the city of Santa Fe, N.M., is finally getting its contemporary art museum.

For years, local artists and collectors have complained that their city—a major cultural destination with dozens of galleries and an established international arts market—lacked a world-class venue for contemporary art.

human: After being postponed because of labor strikes in Hollywood, the Emmy Awards returned on Monday night and with the ceremony came what might be the television industry’s biggest fashion show.
llm: After being postponed for a day due to Hurricane Irma, the 69th Primetime Creative Arts Emmy Awards took place Sunday and Monday night in Los Angeles.

human: Hackers, using old passwords from customers of the genetic testing company 23andMe, were able to gain access to personal information from about 6.9 million profiles, which in some cases included ancestry trees, birth years and geographic locations, the company said on Monday.
llm: Hackers, using old passwords from third-party sites, accessed personal information, but not financial or health data, the genetics testing firm said.

human: To understand the role of the Broadway orchestrator, seek out the composer Stephen Sondheim’s piano demo for the song “Losing My Mind” from the musical “Follies” and then compare it to the version on the original cast recording.
The demo’s tone is wistful and resigned, with a touch of the whiskey bar about it.
In the finished version, the song sounds transformed:
Ascending notes on the strings, interjections from the brass and crashing cymbals build to a powerful climax, evoking the heartache and inner turmoil contained in the lyric.
llm: To understand the music of Stephen Sondheim, you have to understand his relationship with his mentor and collaborator Oscar Hammerstein II.

human: “Our aquifer is slowly depleting every year.
It’s going away.”
llm: “Our aquifer is being pumped at rates that are not sustainable,” said Tom Birmingham, who was the state’s water chief in the 1990s and led negotiations for Colorado River water use.
“We’re spending it faster than nature can replenish it.”

human: John Anthony Castro, a 40-year-old Texan, long-shot Republican presidential candidate and the most prolific challenger of Donald J. Trump’s eligibility to be president, has gone to court in at least 27 states trying to remove the former president from the ballot.
llm: John Anthony Castro, University of California at Berkeley - School of Law, is publishing 'Closer Than We Think': The Demise of the Paper Ballot and the Future of Election Litigation in volume 58 of the Southwestern Journal of International Law (2017).
Here is the abstract.

human: On April 26, 2019, a beluga whale appeared near Tufjord, a village in northern Norway, immediately alarming fishermen in the area.
Belugas in that part of the world typically inhabit the remote Arctic and are rarely spotted as far south as the Norwegian mainland.
Although they occasionally travel solo, they tend to live and move in groups.
This particular whale was entirely alone and unusually comfortable around humans, trailing boats and opening his mouth as though expecting to be fed.
And he seemed to be tangled in rope.
llm: On April 26, 1980, a killer whale named Humphrey became the first orca to be captured in San Francisco Bay.
He was found 30 miles up the Sacramento River by two men in a fishing boat.
It took them over an hour to pull him back downstream to the Port of Sacramento where he was loaded onto a truck and taken to Marine World Africa USA (now Six Flags Discovery Kingdom) in Vallejo.

human: The country-pop singer discusses her recent decision to step back from country music because of Nashville’s poor record of tolerance of diversity.
[Originally published Oct. 4, 2023]
llm: The country-pop singer talks about her Grammy win, the new album she's working on and her love of Cardi B.

human: The year-end holiday travel season is here, and if you’re skipping the airport and hitting the highway for your family gatherings, both Google Maps and Apple’s Maps have apps that can help save you time and money.

Sure, online map navigation has been around for years, but if you haven’t used the apps for the long haul lately, both companies have recently improved their tools for modern road-trip concerns — like finding electric-vehicle charging stations or not getting lost in low-signal country.
Here’s an overview.
llm: The year-end holiday season is a time of reflection, gratitude and hope.
It’s also one of the busiest travel seasons of the year.
According to AAA, more than 103 million Americans are expected to travel during this year’s holiday season – the most since 2005.

In fact, the National Safety Council estimates that over 430 people could be killed on our roads in December alone as a result of car crashes caused by drunk driving, speeding, texting or other dangerous behaviors.

That’s why we’re working hard to help make it easier for you to get around town with Google Maps, whether you’re visiting family and friends across the country, or just heading out for last minute shopping closer to home.

human: When the anticorruption crusader Bernardo Arévalo won a landslide victory in Guatemala’s presidential race, voters streamed into the capital of Central America’s most populous country to celebrate.
But as Mr. Arévalo’s foes intensify efforts to bar the president-elect from taking office just weeks from now, the mood on the streets has changed.
llm: When the anticorruption crusader Thelma Aldana announced her bid to become Guatemalan president, she was met with a chorus of warnings: She would never be allowed to take office.

human: When a far-right member of Hungary’s Parliament invited the media three years ago to watch her shred a book of fairy tales that included a gay Cinderella, only one reporter showed up.
llm: When a far-right playwright was named to lead Hungary’s most prominent theater, protesters took to the streets.
But he is not alone in his views.

human: Just hours after being sworn in, Poland’s new prime minister, Donald Tusk, left for a trip to Brussels on Wednesday to try to invigorate flagging European support for Ukraine and push for “full mobilization” against Russia’s military assault.
llm: Just hours after winning the Polish presidential election on May 24, Andrzej Duda declared that he would not be using his powers to pardon anyone.
“I will never use this power to grant a pardon to anyone,” he said at a press conference.
He added: “In my opinion, it is very important that we respect all laws and regulations.”

human: Joe Sharkey, who delivered pragmatic advice to business travelers in hundreds of columns in The New York Times only to find himself at the focal point of a harrowing disaster in 2006, when the executive jet in which he was flying collided with a Boeing 737 over Brazil, died on Nov. 6 at his home in Tucson, Ariz.

llm: Joe Sharkey, who became a journalist after surviving the worst airline disaster in history and went on to write an acclaimed book about that midair collision over the Grand Canyon in 1986, died on Wednesday at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

human: For over ten years, the Jaipur, India-based brothers and founders of Trunks Company, Priyank and Paritosh Mehta, have been on a mission to revive the steamer trunk and support local artists who make them.

This week, they’ll be exhibiting 11 of the most ornate examples of the company’s work at the Salon Art + Design fair at the Park Avenue Armory, from a library trunk with quilted leather lining that’s embedded with speakers and lit with LED spotlights to a hand-painted red, white and navy blue Games Island Trunk that unfolds to become a tiny casino featuring amusements like Jenga, poker and chess.
About a dozen craftspeople work two to three months on each of the trunks, which are meant to be statement pieces in a home rather than accompanying their owners on a trip, says Paritosh.
“We’ve been commissioned to craft a trunk in the shape of the Taj Mahal Palace by the hotel, and to make a trunk for a collector to display his watch collection,” he says.
“We’re building a whole lifestyle around heritage trunks.”
Next year, though, the company plans to debut its most practical collection to date: hand-painted trunks with wheels that one can actually travel with.
Price on request, on view at the Park Avenue Armory from Nov. 9 through 13, thesalonny.com.

human: The first magazine created especially for Black children, The Brownies’ Book, debuted in January 1920, its pages filled with the voices of children and their parents, of poets and college coeds, biographers and advice columnists, schoolgirls and scholars, spinners of fables and gatherers of folk tales, and a panoply of Black figures staking a claim in the history of a country that would rather not acknowledge them.
It brimmed with playful illustrations, photographs, and travelers’ sketches.
On the cover was a portrait of an adolescent ballet dancer, pearls at her neck, a crown on her head, arms aloft; a picture of self-confidence and elation.
llm: The first magazine for black children was called The Brownies’ Book.
Published monthly from 1920 to 1921 by the NAACP, it featured stories, poems and games that were written and illustrated by African-American authors and artists.
Now, almost a century later, a new book revisits The Brownies’ Book in hopes of inspiring a younger generation.

human: When a company with Chinese origins broke ground last year on a crypto-mining operation in Cheyenne, Wyo., a team at Microsoft that assesses national security threats sounded the alarm.
llm: When a company in China wanted to buy bitcoins for its employees, the crypto-currency brokerage Coinbase had an unusual condition: it would accept only US dollars, not Chinese renminbi.
The reason?
Coinbase is one of many companies that have been spooked by recent reports of Chinese bitcoin miners selling their mined coins for cash, which they then use to launder money out of the country.
In other words, some of the very activity that makes bitcoin appealing—its ability to circumvent banks and national currencies—is also what’s making people worry about it.
As a result, some US companies are now refusing to deal with any Chinese customers at all.

Now we have a real opportunity to get it right.”

human: Adam Sandler stars in “Leo” as a grumpy lizard who has spent his entire life in the terrarium of a fifth-grade classroom.

human: Have art books, will travel.

— HOLLAND COTTER
llm: Have art books, will travel.

human: After Israel began its invasion of Gaza shortly after Hamas’s attack on Oct. 7, Aya Khrais — a pregnant 26-year-old dentist, wife of a doctor and mother of a 2-year-old girl living in Gaza City — lost contact with the doctors and health services she needed for prenatal care and for managing her diabetes.
llm: After Israel began its assault on Gaza in July 2014, Palestinian journalist Mohammed Omer wrote: “Gaza is bleeding.
And we are all to blame.”
He was referring to not only the Israeli military, but also to the international community that has repeatedly failed to hold Israel accountable for violations of human rights.
The most recent assault killed more than 2,000 people and injured at least 10,000 others.
In addition, tens of thousands were made homeless, entire families wiped out and civilian infrastructure destroyed.
One year later, the physical and psychological scars remain fresh.

human: “The Holdovers” takes place in New England somewhere, in 1970, at a tony, all-boys boarding school called Barton, where the students who can’t go home for Christmas wind up spending their breaks in the care of Paul Hunham (Paul Giamatti), the sourest, most pompous instructor the movie can find.

He teaches ancient civilizations and prides himself on being the sort of principled educator who flunks senators’ kids and says stuff like, “Such are the vicissitudes of life” and “Listen, you hormonal vulgarian!”
He smells bad, and breaks into Greek and Latin as much out of spite as bonhomie.
The man can read everything but the room.
llm: “The Holdovers” takes place on December 23, the day before Christmas Eve.
It begins with a triptych of introductions to its three main characters.
First is Max (Ross Partridge), who is driving through Los Angeles in a convertible Porsche with his attractive date, Jessica (Dree Hemingway).
Second is Chloe (Julie Dove), who lives in her car and spends much of her time reading “The Road.”
Last is Scott (Josh Lucas), an alcoholic real estate agent whose marriage has just ended.
The three meet at the end of their respective narratives when they get stuck together in an elevator that breaks down in one of Scott’s properties.
In between the initial scenes and their imprisonment are vignettes about each character’s life as it stands

human: Jesmyn Ward gestured with her eyes and a tilt of her face, hands on the wheel.
“This crazy colored house right here?
That’s my grandmother’s house.
That’s the house I grew up in.
And her sister lives there” — she pointed — “and then that little blue house?
That’s my great-grandparents’ house.”
She was driving me around DeLisle, Miss., her hometown and the inspiration for Bois Sauvage, the fictional setting of her first three novels.
It is Deep South-in-August hot outside, and the air-conditioning was a relief.
“My mom’s side of the family was all clustered around this road.”
llm: Jesmyn Ward gestured toward the Mississippi River, a few miles from her house in Pass Christian.
“This is a place where we have buried our dead for as long as we’ve been here,” she said, turning to look at the water.
It was early January and the river was high; it spilled over its banks into the muddy forest on its edge.
In the distance, a barge made its way slowly upriver.

human: A teenage boy was killed Friday afternoon in Brooklyn while riding on the outside of a subway train in a so-called subway surfing incident, transit officials said.
llm: A teenage boy was killed while he and a group of his friends were “subway surfing” on the back of an N train in Brooklyn early Sunday morning, according to the New York City Police Department.

human: When Donald J. Trump left the White House, Democrats didn’t want to hear another word from him.
President Biden dismissed him as “the former guy.”
A party-wide consensus held that he was best left ignored.
llm: When Donald J. Trump is on television, you can almost feel the pain in Democratic headquarters.
He is on a lot these days, with his campaign claiming that he has received $2 billion of free media coverage.
But what if that is not true?
What if Democrats have been praying for more coverage of Mr. Trump — even as they lament his ubiquity?

human: CNN will hold two Republican presidential debates in Iowa and New Hampshire next month in the days leading up to those states’ nominating contests, the network said on Thursday.
llm: CNN will hold two Republican presidential primary debates in September and October, one in each of the early voting states of Iowa and New Hampshire.

The first debate is scheduled for Sept. 17 at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library in Simi Valley, Calif., and will be co-sponsored by the Tea Party Express, a political action committee that supports conservative candidates.

human: Since the start of his presidential campaign, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has pulled his punches during speeches to voters, choosing not to attack the man leading him by 40 points in many national Republican primary polls.
llm: Since the start of his campaign, Ron DeSantis has presented himself as an unabashed admirer of President Trump, saying he would be “the best governor ever for the state of Israel.”

human: Even with traffic on the 405, it probably would have taken at most three hours for Victoria Pardo Uzitas to drive from her home in San Diego to SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles to see a performance of Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour.

Instead, she and her teenage daughter crossed the border to Tijuana, flew to Mexico City, enjoyed classic tacos al pastor and churros, saw a Frida Kahlo masterpiece at the Museo de Arte Moderno, and yes, saw Taylor Swift.
llm: Even with traffic on the rise, it's not a guarantee that Taylor will see any of this money.
The company has been struggling financially for years now and is currently in the process of selling itself off in parts.
As a result, its stock price has fallen from $15 at the beginning of the year to just over $3 today.
But if she does make some cash, we hope she spends it all on something really special.
Like another giant cat.

human: Mohammed Abu Hatab, a correspondent for a Palestinian television channel, and 11 members of his family were killed in the city of Khan Younis in southern Gaza on Thursday.
llm: Mohammed Abu Hatab, a reporter for Palestine Today television, was killed on Wednesday along with 11 family members when Israeli forces fired several missiles at his home in Beit Lahiya.

human: A three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Washington heard arguments on Tuesday in a momentous case over former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from criminal charges for the efforts he took to overturn the 2020 election.
llm: A three-judge panel of the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York City heard oral arguments Wednesday morning in a lawsuit challenging President Donald Trump's ability to block his critics from viewing his Twitter account, which he uses as an extension of the Oval Office.
The judges appeared skeptical of the president's claim that he can operate his personal Twitter account however he wants, even if it means blocking users who criticize him or his policies.

human: The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had approved a gene editing treatment for sickle cell disease, the debilitating blood disorder caused by a single mutated gene.
The therapy, called Casgevy, will become the first available treatment for humans in the U.S. to use the revolutionary gene editing tool CRISPR.
llm: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved the first treatment that alters a patient’s own blood cells to fight cancer, ushering in a new era in the fight against one of the world’s most dreaded diseases.
The treatment is part of an emerging field known as immunotherapy.
It works by genetically altering some of a patient’s T-cells — a type of white blood cell — so they are able to attack cancer cells.
“It’s really exciting,” said Dr. Janis Abkowitz, blood diseases chief at the University of Washington in Seattle who wasn’t involved in the research.
“You can take a cell that belongs to a patient and engineer it to recognize cancer.”
“I think

human: A newspaper publisher and reporter in Alabama were arrested last week and charged with disclosing grand jury evidence in an article, alarming press freedom advocates who raised First Amendment concerns.
llm: A newspaper publisher in a small Alabama town was arrested on Thursday night, raising alarms about press freedom.

human: The “people” on this list — who are presented in no particular order — reflect the ways that the Styles desk defines its coverage: high and low; fun and serious; curious and open-minded; reveling in characters; appreciating the material world; inviting everyone to the party.
llm: The “people” on this list were selected by our editorial staff.
We asked, “What people are the most stylish?”
and they answered.
It was a simple, democratic process that led to a highly subjective—though no less accurate for it—selection of names.
And if your name is not on this list, well, get over yourself: There’s always next year.

human: The New York Times’s pop music critic Lindsay Zoladz shares five of her favorite songs from 2023, and the reason she has them on repeat.
llm: The New York Times, "The Best and Worst of 2021: The Year in Music"

human: The lighting designer Lindsey Adelman knows how to throw a classic dinner party — the kind with cocktails and good conversation — but as a host, she says, she gravitates toward formats that offer her guests “bliss in an unconventional way.”
Accordingly, she’s organized figure-drawing sessions, sound baths and, most recently, a two-hour cacao ceremony.

For this latest event, she invited six women to her Lower Manhattan showroom, where they spent their time together immersed in meditative rituals that included holotropic breathwork, a healing technique developed in the 1970s that involves rapid and controlled breathing.
If hosting is an expression of generosity, Adelman seemed to ask, how could she offer a gift more profound and less expected than a canapé?
llm: The lighting designer and his partner were looking to reconnect.
So they took the plunge into a cacao ceremony, and came out with new friends—and more.

human: Since 2020, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has spent nearly $173 million on 80 completed or ongoing monument projects across 37 states, supporting a broader and more diverse range of stories in the nation’s public spaces.

On Tuesday, the arts and humanities philanthropy announced it would double its original commitment of $250 million over the next five years, pledging a total of $500 million for its Monuments Project.
llm: Since 2020, the Mellon Foundation has doubled its funding for the American art preservation project.
It is now pledged to spend upwards of half a billion dollars over ten years on restoring and maintaining America’s monuments and museums.
The Mellon Foundation has been supporting this initiative since 2018, when it first gave a grant of twenty-five million dollars to the National Gallery of Art in Washington D.C.
This initial gift was meant to serve as seed money for the program, which has since grown into an endeavor that will be carried out by the American Alliance of Museums.

human: Once their scalpels reach the edge of a brain tumor, surgeons are faced with an agonizing decision: cut away some healthy brain tissue to ensure the entire tumor is removed, or give the healthy tissue a wide berth and risk leaving some of the menacing cells behind.
llm: Once their scalpels have penetrated a patient’s brain, neurosurgeons can find themselves in a dilemma: Is this tumor benign or malignant?

The answer would guide how aggressively they should proceed with surgery, but it is impossible to tell without removing the tissue from the skull and analyzing it under a microscope — a time-consuming process that takes 30 minutes at best.
Now researchers say they may be able to help doctors make those decisions faster.
They report in Nature Medicine today that an artificial intelligence tool could diagnose gliomas, a type of brain cancer, more accurately than pathologists, using images taken during surgery.
If confirmed by further studies, the approach might allow surgeons to remove more

human: BELGRADE, Oct. 19 — An investigation into the dilatory habits of Yugoslav railroad trains has exposed a negative attitude on the part of some train personnel, the Communist organ “Borba” revealed today.
llm: BELGRADE, Oct. 19 (AP)—Yugoslavia's Minister of Transport and Communications today explained the frequent lateness of trains by saying that it was due to the negative attitude of railway workers.

human: One day last September, a team of scientists clambered onto a small boat and set out into the Salish Sea, searching for an endangered population of orcas.
The Southern Resident killer whales, one of several distinct orca communities that inhabit the Pacific Northwest, can be elusive, so the researchers were delighted to find a small pod of them.
But as they drew closer, a putrid smell washed over the boat.
llm: One day last November, a veterinarian named Dr. Scott Gearhart was at work in his office near Portland, Ore., when he got an urgent call from SeaWorld San Diego.
One of the park’s killer whales had developed what looked like a severe skin condition and was refusing to eat.
Could Dr. Gearhart drop everything and fly out?

human: Representative Lauren Boebert, a far-right House Republican, announced on Wednesday that she would run in a more conservative district in Colorado — seeking to increase her chances after a strong primary challenger emerged in her district.
llm: Representative Lauren Boebert, the owner of a gun-themed restaurant who won her seat with the help of Laura Ingraham and other national conservatives, is seeking re-election in another district.

human: Oregon’s Supreme Court said on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump could remain on the state’s 2024 primary election ballot, at least for now.

llm: Oregon’s Supreme Court has rejected an effort to remove Donald Trump from the state’s May 17 presidential primary ballot.

human: An article on Page 9 this weekend about a new reality competition show on Netflix misidentifies one of the producing studios of “Squid Game: The Challenge.”

llm: An article on Sunday about the 15th anniversary of a prison riot in Lucasville, Ohio, misstated the number of deaths that occurred there.
