human: Your health data is exceptionally valuable — and exceptionally vulnerable.
llm: Your health data is now the hottest commodity on the black market, more valuable than even credit card information.
Why?
Because it can be used to impersonate you and your health insurance company will pay for whatever fraudulent services are provided.
This is an excellent article that explains what's happening, why it's happening, how you should protect yourself from this new threat, and what to do if you become a victim of medical identity theft.

human: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Thursday ratcheted up his feud with Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, filing suit against 17 transportation companies that he said had carried out a plan by Mr. Abbott to send more than 30,000 migrants to New York City and make the city pay for their care.
llm: Mayor Eric Adams of New Rochelle (D) is also seeking to sue the federal government for $10 million.

human: On Tuesday, Cillian Murphy was at his parents’ home in Cork, Ireland, drinking a cup of tea when his phone started buzzing.
A glance at the dozens of texts revealed the news: For the first time, Murphy had been nominated for the best actor Oscar, for his performance as the title character in “Oppenheimer.”
llm: On Tuesday, Cillian Murphy was walking down the street in New York when he got a text from his agent telling him that he had been nominated for an Emmy for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Drama Series.
“I was like, ‘What?!’”
he told Vulture over the phone on Thursday.
“I’m kind of a little bit in shock.”

human: Saturday is the third anniversary of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
The consequences of that fateful day still reverberate through American politics, and its fallout looms intensely over the 2024 presidential race.
llm: Saturday is the sixth anniversary of the earthquake that killed more than 200,000 people and devastated a country still struggling to recover.

human: Some of my favorite Japanese restaurants are bars.
Of course, there are the izakayas scattered around the city, where eating and drinking are as inseparable as sushi and rice.
But there are also bars that happen to have excellent food even though they are best known for their beverages (cocktails and highballs, most often, but also whiskey, shochu and sake).
Fortunately, they seem to be proliferating.
These are a few of my favorites.
llm: Some of my favorite places to drink.
Great list!

human: A parade of powerful legal minds has gathered over the last three weeks at the criminal trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul.

Damian Williams, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, has sat for hours in the 26th-floor courtroom, alongside partners at prestigious law firms and a former deputy to Robert Mueller III, who served as special counsel in an investigation of President Donald J. Trump.
llm: A parade of crypto influencers, bankers and fintech founders turned up at the New York State Supreme Court today for a glimpse of one of their own in court.

human: I was irritated as I drove west from Nashville.
The sun was in my eyes, and I was holding the steering wheel too tight because the car kept getting buffeted by the winds of trucks passing at an astonishingly illegal speed.
At least I’m not heading east, I kept reminding myself, stuck behind one big rig trying to pass another on a steep mountain incline.
On the flat lands of West Tennessee, even eighteen-wheelers can pass going 90 miles an hour.
llm: I was irritated by the fact that I couldn't remember my childhood home, and so I took a trip to see if I could locate it.
This essay is about that trip, which turned out to be more difficult than I expected, and about what I learned from it.
It's also about trying to find a place in the world where you belong.

human: The name Hemlock Neversink might conjure a wooded fairyland, and that idea isn’t too far from the truth.
The 34-room all-inclusive hotel, opening Oct. 13, is set on 230 tree-filled acres in New York’s Catskills region.
Activities include guided bird-watching and pine-needle weaving, but the core purpose of the property is to serve as a wellness retreat.
Guests will be offered a survey with questions such as “How structured do you like your days?” and “Would you like to move or rest?”
The answers are meant to inform a daily itinerary created by the Hemlock team, which might include animal therapy with an on-site herd of goats or a morning cardio dance class.

At the spa, nature-inspired treatments such as the Neversink Ice and Stone Ritual, which involves an herb-infused cold water bath, a hot steam shower and a hot river-stone massage, are available for an added charge.
The property’s design draws from the region’s Quaker heritage, with a neutral color palette, ash and walnut furniture and quilt-inspired custom wool rugs by Manhattan’s Crosby Street Studios.

The husband-and-wife owners, Sims and Kirsten Foster, who were recently nominated for a James Beard Award for Outstanding Restaurateur for their other Catskills hotels (including the DeBruce and Kenoza Hall), conceived of another inviting dining space for Hemlock Neversink: Bittersweet, which has two fireplaces, will focus on seasonal and locally sourced dishes.
From $399 a night, hemlockneversink.com.
llm: The name Hemlock is a girl's name of English origin meaning "poisonous plant".
Hemlock and discussed in our forums with posts like "Name Help: Lily, Violet, Ivy, Poppy...".

human: Twelve months ago, Tom Lee bet that 2023 was going to turn out just fine.
llm: Twelve months ago, I wrote a column for Barron’s that offered my 10 predictions for the stock market in 2018.
The headline was “My Predictions: Get Ready for Dow 36,000.”
I expected the Dow Jones Industrial Average to end this year at 35,950, with a high of 40,700 and a low of 25,000.
As we approach the end of the year, the Dow has fallen more than 1,200 points from its peak in early October, but it is still up about 2%.

human: Nikki Haley, a former governor of South Carolina, and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida are vying to dethrone the Republican Party’s clear presidential front-runner, Donald J. Trump.
But first one needs to triumph over the other.
llm: Nikki Haley, a former governor of South Carolina, is the U.N. ambassador who quit in October 2018.
She was seen as a possible presidential contender before she announced her resignation.
In 2016, Haley endorsed Marco Rubio for president but then backed Donald Trump after he won the Republican nomination.

human: Robbin Mele Gaudieri, who, as Robbin Bain, embodied traditional women’s roles as the winner of a beauty contest designed to promote beer in 1959 and later as the “Today Girl,” handling fashion and beauty segments on the popular NBC-TV morning show, died on Oct. 21 in Southampton, N.Y.
She was 87.
llm: Robbin Mele Gaudieri, known to the world as Robbin Bain, died on April 29.
She was born in Staten Island, N.Y., on June 10, 1931.
A graduate of Penn State University with a degree in drama, she worked for many years as an actress, model, and television personality.

After winning the Miss Pennsylvania beauty pageant, she went on to be crowned first runner-up in the Miss America contest, after which she moved to New York City to work as a TV hostess on “The Today Show” (NBC), where she interviewed such luminaries as Frank Sinatra, Bob Hope, Marilyn Monroe, and Elvis Presley.

human: Eager for bargains, American consumers filled their shopping carts last weekend with holiday gifts.
But it isn’t yet clear if that means this will be a successful season for retailers.
llm: Eager for bargains, Americans shopped in droves on Black Friday last weekend.
But that hasn't settled anxieties about how much they will spend over all this holiday season.

human: Lt. Ridge Alkonis, a Navy officer who was imprisoned in Japan after killing two members of a Japanese family in a car crash, returned to the United States this week after a yearslong diplomatic effort to bring him home, Biden administration officials said.
llm: Lt. Ridge Alkonis, a former Navy fighter pilot, was released from jail in Japan on Wednesday after serving nearly four years of a 20-year sentence for murdering his wife and attempting to cover it up as a suicide.

The release came at the end of a lengthy legal battle that involved his family, American military officials and lawyers who argued that he had been wrongly convicted by Japanese prosecutors with scant evidence.
Mr. Alkonis’s case has highlighted problems with the Japanese criminal justice system, which critics say is overly reliant on confessions.
The prosecution’s case rested largely on statements made during interrogation by Mr. Alkonis, a highly trained naval officer, and his son, then 13, neither of whom spoke Japanese

human: I went to Ann Arbor, Mich., for a journalism fellowship because I was stuck in life.
An outside observer might say I was depressed, unhappy and a little too obsessed with my dog.
I felt isolated and lonely — part of the psychological epidemic that followed the pandemic.
llm: I went to my first University of Michigan football game in 1967, and I have been attending them ever since.
In fact, I've never missed a home game.
My dad got tickets from his friend who had season tickets for decades and could no longer attend due to illness.
The first game was against Purdue at old Michigan Stadium on a warm September Saturday afternoon.
I remember watching with amazement as the band marched into the stadium and then took the field to play "The Victors."
There were cheers all around me, and I remember feeling like I was part of something special -- something bigger than myself.

human: In the days since war broke out in Israel and Gaza, the streetscapes of cities such as New York and Berlin, Lisbon and Buenos Aires have been blanketed with emerging symbols of Israelis’ national pain.
llm: In the days following the kidnaping of three Israeli teenagers, posters with the slogan “Bring Back Our Boys” have sprouted across Israel.
The slogan was a play on words, echoing the popular hashtag #bringbackourgirls used to protest the abduction of more than 200 Nigerian schoolgirls by Boko Haram, an Islamist militant group, in April.
The posters were plastered on billboards, bus stops and street corners around the country.
The campaign grew as people posted pictures of the signs on social media, using the hashtags #EyalGiladNaftali and #BringBackOurBoys.
Many of the signs were made by individuals and groups in their

human: The Supreme Court declined today to decide whether Donald Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
Instead, the case will move forward in an appeals court and will most likely return to the Supreme Court in the coming months.
llm: The Supreme Court has declined to fast track a decision on whether President Donald Trump can be sued by state prosecutors over his business dealings.

human: Early in the summer, an unusual email popped up in my inbox.

Sandwiched between a podcast request and an offer to speak at a South Florida chapter of Hadassah was an invitation to read an excerpt from my latest novel, “On Fire Island,” at a “Books & Burlesque” evening on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.

llm: Early in the evening on Tuesday, March 15th, we were joined by students from across campus for a night of reading, as part of our celebration of Women's History Month.
Students and faculty read excerpts from their favorite women writers and poets.

human: When John Woo was a child, living in the dangerous slums of Hong Kong, he had two sanctuaries: the church and the movie theater.

human: More Americans are buying heat pumps, an environmentally friendly alternative to furnaces and air-conditioners that can significantly lower monthly energy bills.

llm: More Americans are installing heat pumps to save money on their heating bills.

human: A British hedge-fund trader accused of defrauding Danish taxpayers of $1.3 billion has been extradited to Denmark by the United Arab Emirates, where he had lived for more than a decade.

human: Ed Young, whose illustrations in some 100 children’s books, many of which he also wrote, mesmerized young and not-so-young readers with intricate depictions of fairy tales, poetry and his own life story as a Chinese immigrant, died on Sept. 29 at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

llm: Ed Young, whose illustrations for books like “Lon Po Po,” a retelling of an ancient Chinese folk tale about a little girl left in the woods, and “Seven Blind Mice” earned him two Caldecott Medals, died on July 3 at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

human: This year’s list of 52 Places to Go from The New York Times Travel desk features destinations for every kind of globe-trotter.
Some places that made the list will usher in extraordinary events in 2024.
Paris, for one, is hosting the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games; Mexico, Canada and 13 U.S. states will offer paramount views of the total solar eclipse crossing North America this spring.
Other destinations, like Morocco and Maui, Hawaii, are hoping to welcome back visitors after devastating natural disasters last year.
llm: This year’s list of the 52 places to go in 2018 was one of our most ambitious projects yet, an exhaustive selection of destinations around the world that we think are worth a visit right now.
We wanted to be sure that this project lived up to its name
and so we sent four writers — a team of three women and one man, hailing from four different continents — on trips to see for themselves what these destinations had to offer.
Here are their stories.

human: Starbucks said Friday that it wanted to get back to the bargaining table after a deadlock of more than six months with the union that represents more than 9,000 of its workers.

human: She’s a beloved blonde pop star with the initials T.S.

He’s a handsome N.F.L. player with a popular podcast and the initials T.K. Together, they have fused America’s obsession with pop stars and athletes into a celebrity pairing so incandescent it’s almost celestial.
llm: She’s a beloved Disney Channel star.

And they’ve taken to TikTok to spread this gospel.
[…] The “shipping” phenomenon isn’t new; it’s been around since Harry Potter and Hermione Granger were first penned together by J.K. Rowling.
It was only intensified when fan fiction writers on the internet started imagining steamy scenarios for the two.
“Shipping,” or the act of wishing two characters would be in a relationship, is now a major part of f

human: American intelligence agencies have assessed that a deadly blast at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday killed 100 to 300 people, a more conservative estimate than that given by officials in Gaza, and that the hospital suffered light damage.
llm: American intelligence agencies have concluded that an Israeli airstrike killed 10 Palestinian civilians seeking shelter at a United Nations school in the northern Gaza Strip last month, not one as initially reported by the United Nations.

human: The College Democrats of New Jersey were preparing to make an endorsement in one of the country’s most closely watched U.S. Senate primaries when calls began to come in from someone in touch with the campaign of Tammy Murphy, the presumptive front-runner and the wife of the state’s governor.

human: Since her first book of poetry, “The Body’s Question,” was published in 2003, Tracy K. Smith has been a writer to watch.

llm: Since her first book, The Body’s Question (2003), won the Cave Canem Poetry Prize, Tracy K. Smith has been one of our most dependable poets, producing at least a volume every four years—Duende (2007), winner of the James Laughlin Award; Life on Mars (2011), which won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry; and Wade in the Water (2018).
In Ordinary Light: A Memoir (Knopf, $26.95), Smith writes about growing up in Northern California as the youngest of five children.
Her mother, an organist, died when she was 16, and Smith reflects upon their relationship while recounting her own journey to becoming a poet.

human: Some 75.3 million years ago, a dinosaur swallowed the Cretaceous equivalent of a turkey drumstick.
It would turn out to be the predator’s final feast.
llm: Some 75.3 million years ago in what is now western Canada, a tyrannosaurus rex feasted on its prey,
but the carnivore didn't live to enjoy its meal for long—it soon died itself and was buried by sediment, with its last snack still inside it.
Now, the fossils of both creatures have been uncovered in a rare occurrence that has provided new insights into how these dinosaurs lived.

human: By the time Amanda Stern was in her mid-40s, she no longer suffered from clinical depression.
And her panic attacks, which had started in childhood, were mostly gone.
But instead of feeling happier, she said, “I felt wallpapered in an endless, flat sadness.”
llm: By the time I finished reading this, I realized it was describing me.

human: Academy Awards organizers have decided to stick with a tried and true host: Jimmy Kimmel.
llm: Academy Awards organizers have decided not to go hostless again this year, but instead bring back Jimmy Kimmel for the 2018 Oscars ceremony.

human: Believe it or not, the end of 2023 is approaching.
llm: Believe it or not, we're still a long way from the year 2023.
But in the past few weeks, I've read two novels that take place in our Golden State, and both of them are so good they should be on every reader's radar.
And if you love fiction about California as much as I do, these books should also be at the top of your to-be-read list.

human: SpaceX, Elon Musk's spaceflight company, launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.
llm: SpaceX, Elon Musk's space exploration company, made progress on Thursday toward its goal of putting humans into outer space with the second launch of its massive new rocket.
SpaceX successfully launched the Falcon Heavy rocket for the first time last year.
It was a historic achievement because it marked the first time that a commercial company had built a vehicle capable of taking people to the moon or Mars.
The rocket is capable of carrying up to 140,000 pounds into orbit around Earth, and is designed to carry up to six passengers at a time to those deep-space destinations.

human: This house is on James Island, about a 20-minute drive from the dining and nightlife in downtown Charleston.
It is about a five-minute drive from a Publix supermarket, a brewery, a gym, a public library and James Island Elementary School.
James Island Charter High School is 10 minutes away.
llm: This house is on a 1.3-acre lot in the Old Village of Mount Pleasant, S.C., about six miles from downtown Charleston.
It was built in 1974 by the current owner’s parents, who bought the land for $6,000.
They had been looking for property to build a spec house on when they found this site, which was then part of a large farm.
“It was just a dirt road,” said their son, Mike Foley.
“I remember my mother telling me that there were no neighbors.”
The house has four bedrooms and three bathrooms, including a one-bedroom suite over the garage that could be used as an office or rental unit.
Mr. Foley said he loved the screen

human: Small nuggets of advice can sometimes lead to big changes in relationships.

My colleagues and I on the Well desk are fortunate to regularly interview psychotherapists, couples counselors, sex therapists and researchers who share their most useful tactics for strengthening connections.
llm: Small nuggets of wisdom are great
but there is no way you can improve your relationships by following some tips.
A relationship is a living, breathing organism that requires constant work and attention.
You need to get to the heart of the matter which takes time, energy and commitment.

human: A picture book about a same-sex penguin couple at the Central Park Zoo was made inaccessible to young students in a Florida school district.
The history of the Gay Pride flag was one of the most widely banned books in the country.
An illustrated story about surviving slavery in America was prohibited in classrooms.
llm: A picture book on gay marriage was nominated for the prestigious Carnegie Medal this year.

human: The humanitarian crisis deepened in the blockaded Gaza territory on Thursday, with a United Nations official warning of “disaster” as hospitals ran short on fuel for generators and corridors were crammed with wounded bodies.
Fearful residents flooded U.N.-run schools seeking shelter from explosions as Israeli troops moved toward the border for a possible ground invasion to dismantle Hamas.
llm: The humanitarian crisis in Syria is escalating.
The United Nations estimates that more than 10,000 people have been killed since the uprising against Assad began a year ago.
An estimated 230,000 refugees have fled to Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan.
The U.N. is scrambling to provide food, water and shelter for these people as well as those who are displaced inside Syria.
But the needs are outpacing the resources available.

human: Some civilians sheltered in subway stations as Russia launched a widespread missile attack on regions across Ukraine.
llm: Some civilians sheltered in the basements of the destroyed buildings and survived, according to reports.

human: LinkedIn, the professional social networking platform owned by Microsoft, said on Monday that it would cut about 668 jobs, or roughly 3 percent of its work force.
llm: LinkedIn, the professional social network owned by Microsoft Corp., is cutting about 10 percent of its workforce as part of a restructuring following its $27 billion acquisition earlier this year.
The company said it will reduce staff by approximately 400 positions, excluding contractors.
LinkedIn employed nearly 9,350 people worldwide at the end of June.
In February, the company cut 130 jobs after losing a $10,000-per-month contract with the U.S. Department of Labor.
Read more: "LinkedIn to Cut About 10 Percent of Workforce
After Microsoft Deal"

human: Two months ago, Joe Ganim received the most votes in the race for mayor of Bridgeport, Conn.
This week, the city will vote again — to decide if he should even be the Democratic candidate.
llm: Two months ago, the New York Times Magazine did a feature on Bridgeport's history of election fraud and the current mayor's longstanding ties to his predecessor (who is currently serving seven years in prison for corruption).

The article also noted that the city's Democratic registrar of voters is married to an alderman who was convicted of embezzlement and bribery and that she has been accused of improperly handling absentee ballots.
She's the same woman who was suspended by the secretary of state during the last two elections for her mishandling of them.
This latest incident comes after a judge ordered a new primary because of allegations of irregularities -- including improperly handled absentee ballots -- in September's mayoral primary.

human: Hundreds of events over the course of the year reveal distinct campaigning styles among the top three Republican presidential candidates.
llm: Hundreds of events are planned across the country to support Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign.

human: For the past several weeks, dozens of candidates have been facing a five-person committee in a dark, book-lined room at Italy’s Culture Ministry, hoping to convince the panel that they should be selected to direct some of Italy’s top museums, including the Uffizi in Florence, the Capodimonte in Naples, the Brera in Milan and seven others.
llm: For the past year and a half, Italy has been searching for new directors to lead 10 of its most important museums.
The process has unfolded with little transparency and much controversy.

human: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, founded in 1954 by the renowned choreographer, has long been one of the city’s most prominent troupes.
But it has struggled in recent years to find space to match its ambitions for more performances, rehearsals, classes and community events.
llm: The Paul Taylor Dance Company is preparing for a major expansion that will include moving its headquarters from the East Village to a much larger space on West 55th Street.
The company has signed a long-term lease with Kaufman Organization for nearly 17,000 square feet of space at 431 West 55th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.
It will house a new studio complex, administrative offices, costume shop, library and archives, and storage space.

human: The curves on some Covid graphs are looking quite steep, again.
llm: The curves on the chart show that, if trends continue as they have since early March, the number of new cases per day will soon hit 100,000 — and might even approach 250,000 by mid-April.
That would be about where the United States was at the peak of its pandemic in October 2009, when swine flu was sickening more than 400,000 Americans each week.

human: Even amid the uproar over President Donald J. Trump’s freewheeling use of his pardon powers at the end of his term, one commutation stood out.
llm: Even amid the chaos of last week, with President Donald Trump purging his cabinet members and railing against immigrants and the Mueller investigation, one outrage managed to stand out: On Wednesday, he granted a full pardon to I. Lewis “Scooter” Libby, who had served as chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney until 2005.
That was the year that Libby was indicted on five counts by Patrick Fitzgerald, then the U.S. attorney in Chicago.
The charges included obstruction of justice, perjury and making false statements.

human: The U.S. military said it would send more missile defense systems to the Middle East in response to “escalations” from Iran and its allies, who have threatened a broader war in the region.
The deployment comes as Israel continues to signal intentions to invade Gaza after Hamas’s deadly incursion earlier this month.
llm: The U.S. military has sent more missile defense systems to the Persian Gulf region, according to a news report Tuesday.
The Pentagon dispatched an additional Patriot battery and a Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system to bolster defenses in the region, CNN reported.
This is the second time in six months that the United States has deployed its THAAD anti-missile system to the Middle East.

human: “When you talk about politics,” the critic Irving Howe said, “you should stand.”
Martin Peretz quotes this line early in “The Controversialist,” his new memoir, as a style of moralizing he was never crazy about.
But the observation suits him.
Peretz writes as if he were pacing around a dining-room table, ego and self-loathing fighting it out in his head.
llm: “When you talk about the most influential person in the history of the sport, it’s got to be him,” said Mr. Soshnikov, who is now an agent for N.H.L. players and has worked with more than 20 first-round draft picks.
“There were guys that had been scouting before him, but he really made it a profession.”

human: David Del Tredici, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer who began as an experimentalist but became best known for a midcareer shift toward a style that came to be called the New Romanticism, which yielded a series of rich-hued, tuneful pieces based on Lewis Carroll’s “Alice” stories, died on Saturday at his home in Greenwich Village.
He was 86.
llm: David Del Tredici, Who Set ‘Alice’ to Music, Dies at 86

human: OpenAI has ChatGPT.
Google has the Bard chatbot.
Microsoft has its Copilots.
On Tuesday, Amazon joined the chatbot race and announced an artificial intelligence assistant of its own: Amazon Q.
llm: OpenAI has ChatGPT.

human: When Nabeela Elsayed was speaking at a corporate conference several years ago and explained that she would miss the group dinner because she was fasting for Ramadan, she recalls, her manager responded: “Just don’t fast.”
Ms. Elsayed, an executive coach who was previously chief operating officer for Walmart Canada, said she had heard many such slights when stepping away during the workday to pray.
llm: When Nabeela Elsayed, a Muslim who wears the hijab, started at a new job in 2014, she felt isolated and alone.
There were no other women of color on her team or in senior management roles, and no one understood what it was like to be visibly Muslim in America.
She had trouble finding community with other employees, let alone mentors.

human: Senator John Fetterman of Pennsylvania is endorsing Representative Andy Kim of New Jersey in the primary to unseat Senator Bob Menendez, the embattled veteran Democrat who is under indictment in a federal corruption case, taking the rare step of wading into a high-stakes intraparty fight to oust a colleague.
llm: Senator John Fetterman (D) Pennsylvania

human: Three years ago, Nancy Miah had never heard of the fictional, Dutch, poker-faced bunny known as Miffy.
Now, she calls herself the “Miffy Queen.”
llm: Three years ago, I was lucky enough to be at a party where Patti Smith played.
A few weeks later, she played her first show in 16 years.
The New Yorker has an article on her by Rick Moody (author of The Ice Storm and Garden State).

human: “Everyone likes an underdog, and we had underdogs in spades.”
llm: “Everyone likes an underdog,” said one postal worker.
“But we are not just fighting for ourselves; we are fighting for a service that is vital to our communities and loved by our customers.”

human: Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, said it was not worth her time to respond to Vivek Ramaswamy.
llm: Nikki Haley, the U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and former governor of South Carolina, has been accused by two men who were once her close allies of having multiple affairs while she was in office.

human: Amy Julia Harris and Jan Ransom’s recent New York Times investigation started over a year ago, after a tragedy.
Michelle Go, a 40-year-old financial consultant, was standing on a subway platform in January 2022 when a 61-year-old man shoved her in front of a moving train.
Ms. Go was killed, rattling New Yorkers.
Ms. Harris and Ms. Ransom, who cover New York City for The Times, wanted to understand where the system had failed Ms. Go and her assailant, who was homeless and mentally ill.
llm: Amy Julia Harris and Shoshana Walter.
Reveal, December 2016.

human: Donald J. Trump could not hide his anger.
Sitting at the front of a crowded New York courtroom this week, he folded his arms tightly across his chest.
He tossed his head and scowled.
He stared into the middle distance and scrolled through his phone.
llm: Donald J. Trump, the man who made “You’re fired!”
a household catchphrase, has always surrounded himself with people who can serve his needs, and then discarded them when they couldn’t.

human: The Times explores the place where photography is allowed at Guantánamo's secretive war court — and explains what you can and cannot see.
llm: The Times explores how to make a 2014 article about the Guantanamo military commissions fit into 2018's layouts and style guide.

human: Few people have shaped the streetscape of New York as prominently as the stone-carving Piccirilli brothers, six Italian immigrants who turned out one important public sculpture after another at their studio complex in the Bronx starting in the 1890s.
llm: Few people have heard of the Piccirilli brothers, but their work is everywhere.

The six sons of an Italian marble carver had a hand in creating some of the most iconic public sculptures in the United States: the statue of Abraham Lincoln at the Lincoln Memorial, Daniel Chester French’s colossal Minute Man in Concord, Mass., and the firemen memorial at Riverside Drive and 100th Street in Manhattan, among many others.

human: It was a long-awaited day in court for Epic Games’ chief executive, Tim Sweeney, who testified in a San Francisco federal courthouse on Monday in the company’s legal battle against Google.
llm: It was a nice article, keep posting more interesting articles.
I will be a regular reader...

human: Nikki Haley began campaigning early this morning, bouncing from town to town across New Hampshire.

The state’s Tuesday primary, which allows independent voters to cast ballots, is most likely her best early chance to narrow Donald Trump’s staggering lead and turn the nominating campaign into a two-person race.
llm: Nikki Haley began her tenure as US ambassador to the United Nations in January of last year.
In her short time on the job, she has proven herself to be nothing more than a puppet for Israeli interests.

As such, it should come as no surprise that Haley recently disgraced herself by blocking the appointment of Salam Fayyad, former Prime Minister of Palestine and former Finance minister, to a position at the United Nations.

human: The Amazon valley looked like so many others, with a muddy river snaking through dense forest, except that this one had earthen mounds rising at clear right angles and ditches carving long straight lines through the soil.
llm: The Amazon valley was once home to sprawling pre-Columbian settlements, according to archaeologists who flew drones over remote parts of the Brazilian rainforest.

human: Idris Dahiru was hosting some guests at a religious celebration in his village in northern Nigeria on Sunday night, when a piercing sound streaked through the air, followed by an explosion and countless screams.
llm: Idris Dahiru was working in the field when he heard the sound of fighter jets overhead.
He looked up and saw three planes circling his village, Rann, in northeastern Nigeria.

human: In 2004, when Miriam Wilkinson moved from London to Eastbourne, on England’s southeast coast, the seaside town was often referred to as “God’s waiting room” because of its aging population.
But in the last few years, there had been “an awakening” in Eastbourne, said Wilkinson, 40, who works at a nonprofit.
Young families were arriving, she added, and new public art was appearing in the streets.
llm: In 2004, when the Turner prize was awarded in Scotland for the first time, Glasgow had a reputation as “God’s waiting room”.

human: A few blocks from where the Cronut was born, a new pastry mash-up by a French chef is making its debut.

Gregory Doyen developed a cakelike confection inspired by brownies and cookies that’s round, about three inches in diameter, fairly dense and with a central opening where a ganache or fruit filling goes.
Mr. Doyen is calling it MOD, for multilayered original dessert.
It’s offered as a single serving ($7.50 each) and in fours ($29), and can be shared and personalized.
In a show of extreme confidence, it’s the only product sold in the bright white shop of the same name he owns with Edward Geyman, his business partner.

A native of the Burgundy region in France who studied pastry-making and has been a pastry consultant in many countries around the globe, Mr. Doyen, 38, arrived in the United States a year ago and began working on this project.
“I didn’t just want to reproduce French pastry,” he said.
The flavor and filling combinations are endless.

For now he has eight colorful examples, including peanut butter and jelly, matcha with white chocolate, walnut with dark chocolate, red velvet with dark chocolate and raspberry, and pecan caramel with milk chocolate chips and sea salt.
He has a featured flavor of the month, which for now is s’mores with a marshmallow topping that he torches before serving.
He said he’s working on a mini size.
llm: A few blocks away, there's another bakery with a name that might be familiar to fans of Ace of Cakes: Charm City Cakes West, which has opened at 8310 W. Third St. (near La Cienega Boulevard).
It's an offshoot of Duff Goldman's bakery in Baltimore and will serve some of its signature cakes as well as cupcakes and macarons.
And if you want something savory, they also have sandwiches and salads on the menu.

human: A digital-age dirty-trickster who used Twitter posts that looked like Hillary Clinton ads to spread false information before the 2016 presidential election was sentenced on Tuesday to seven months in prison.
llm: A digital-age dirty-trickster who used Twitter and Facebook to spread lies about Hillary Clinton during the 2016 presidential campaign was sentenced Wednesday to seven months in prison.

human: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy.

llm: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets readers know what happened late-night Thursday so they can enjoy their beauty sleep.
Today:

Stephen Colbert mocks the Fox News tradition of blaming President Biden; Jimmy Kimmel asks people on the street if they're worried about being attacked by ISIS in Los Angeles; and James Corden tries to get into the Oscars.

human: The annual defense bill has become entangled in a tumultuous Republican feud in the House, as hard-right lawmakers revolt over a bipartisan agreement to jettison a raft of deeply partisan dictates that would have limited abortion access, transgender care and diversity training.
llm: The annual defense bill has been a slam dunk for decades in Congress, easily passing with bipartisan majorities and signed into law by presidents of both parties.

But the latest version is teetering on the edge of passage after angering a group of hard-line conservatives who are threatening to sink the legislation — and take down the House Republican leadership with it.

human: It’s fair to say that 2023 was a good year for blond girl-culture icons with a long history of being underestimated.

Britney Spears may not have enjoyed the rapturously smooth sailing of Taylor Swift or Barbie but her calendar-year triumphs, including a bestselling memoir, “The Woman in Me,” a newly clean romantic slate and a song, “Toxic,” that’s racking up record numbers on Spotify, look from the outside all the more gratifying precisely because they’re so hard won.
llm: It’s fair to say that, over the past few years, I’ve developed a soft spot for Britney Spears.
The most famous pop star in America, if not the world, she has managed to be both utterly ubiquitous and completely underrated.
Her 2013 album Britney Jean was widely panned by critics; its songs were written by committee, and Spears herself was just one voice among many.
But it’s hard to deny her appeal:
Even at her worst, there is something about Britney that is so undeniably her.

human: One reason I’m afraid that the worst is yet to come in the Middle East is that the mutual dehumanization is the most savage I’ve ever seen in decades of on-the-ground reporting in the region.
llm: One reason I’m a writer is that I don’t like to talk.
I feel most comfortable with words on paper.
But I can’t be quiet anymore about what’s happening in Israel and Palestine, because my heart is breaking.
I’ve been silent long enough.
The time has come for me to speak up.

human: The day Israelis woke to the horror that the Palestinian squads that had infiltrated their country were shooting soldiers and civilians and dragging captives back to Gaza, the shadowy commander of Hamas’s military wing released a rare message blessing the attack.
llm: The day Israelis stop being afraid to travel on their own roads and sleep in their own beds is the day they can say that Hamas has been defeated.
The fact that Hamas can still sow fear and cause such devastation from within Gaza shows how dangerous it remains, despite all the efforts of Israel’s military to suppress it.

human: Early last February, at the Mount Washington Backcountry Ski Festival in New Hampshire, the organizers faced an increasingly common problem: Terrible snow.
llm: Early last February, a snowstorm blanketed Mount Washington with more than two feet of fresh powder.
That night, I sat at home watching my Facebook feed fill up with images of friends skiing and boarding on the mountain’s steep flanks.
“Looks like we missed out,” my wife said.
We had recently moved to New Hampshire from Utah, where we’d lived for 12 years.
Backcountry skiing was our thing.

human: In the days after Artforum magazine fired its top editor, David Velasco, because of an open letter it published about the Israel-Hamas war, at least four other editors resigned and several prominent artists said they would boycott the publication unless Velasco was reinstated.
llm: In the days since longtime Artforum editor-in-chief Knight Landesman was fired by his company after a former employee accused him of sexual misconduct, many in the art world have been wondering what would become of the magazine.
Now, a group of artists is calling on their peers to boycott the publication until the publisher and majority shareholder, Anthony Korner, steps down from his position as co-publisher.
The boycott comes amid an investigation into allegations against Landesman by New York City’s Commission on Human Rights, which has reached out to current and former employees at the magazine.

human: Thousands of earthquakes recorded over the past few days have led to the pre-emptive closure of the Blue Lagoon, a popular tourist destination in Iceland.
llm: Thousands of earthquakes have forced the closure of a famous hot spring known as the Blue Lagoon.
The lagoon is located just outside Reykjavik, and is a popular tourist attraction in Iceland.
According to the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), more than 500 quakes were recorded on Saturday morning alone.
While most were small, some measured up to magnitude 3.9.

human: Former President Donald J. Trump’s resounding victory in Iowa significantly raises the stakes of next week’s New Hampshire primary for Nikki Haley and the increasingly desperate contingent of Republicans who want to move on from Mr. Trump.
llm: Former President Donald Trump advisor and South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley has her eyes set on the first-in-the-nation primary state of New Hampshire, according to reports.

human: Multiple Republicans have ended their presidential campaigns over the past two months, narrowing the field against former President Donald J. Trump — but the only person who has gained much ground in the first voting state is Mr. Trump, according to a new poll.

human: Nearly 15 years ago, Mary Nepomuceno separated from her husband.

llm: Nearly 15 years ago, Abdel-Hamid el-Ghazaly was forced to marry a woman he barely knew.
He was 20
and she was 16, and they were engaged after just one meeting.

human: Many modern cars are internet-connected and have apps that allow an owner to see a car’s location, turn it on remotely, honk its horn and even adjust the temperature.

These apps for car control and tracking are designed for convenience, but a New York Times article last month detailed how they have been weaponized in abusive relationships, allowing for unwanted stalking and harassment.
llm: Many modern cars are equipped with built-in cellular modems that send data about your car’s location, how you drive and whether you wear a seat belt to the manufacturer.
The Federal Trade Commission wants to know what automobile manufacturers do with this information — and what they tell customers.

human: Representative Dean Phillips of Minnesota, a Democrat running a long-shot primary challenge to President Biden, said on Saturday that he would consider running on the ticket of No Labels, a centrist group exploring an independent bid, if it appeared the general election would be a rematch between Mr. Biden and Donald J. Trump.

human: Israel, already bombing intensively in Gaza, is gearing up for a major military operation there unlike any in the past, warning the world that for Israel, after the massacre of its citizens by Hamas on Saturday, the rules have changed.

human: After enjoying a strong rebound in sales in 2023, the auto industry appears headed for slower growth this year as consumers struggle with elevated interest rates and high prices for new cars and light trucks.

human: There is a shelf at Carissa Moore’s home in Honolulu where she keeps her journals.

human: The police in Charlotte, N.C., have started an internal investigation after a video was shared on social media showing an officer repeatedly punching a woman while other officers restrained her on the ground.

human: Oscar Pistorius, a once-inspirational figure who gained international fame as an Olympic sprinter for South Africa before he was convicted of murdering his girlfriend, will be released on parole, the authorities said on Friday.

human: The figurative painter, a favorite of Barack Obama’s and Kendrick Lamar’s, has made portraiture the dominant mode of art in our era.

human: Extreme weather gripped large parts of the Southern United States on Monday, with ice and snow hampering plans to commemorate the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday, and several governors declaring states of emergency.
llm: Extreme weather gripped the eastern half of the United States on Tuesday, with snow falling in Jacksonville, Fla., and icy roads snarling travel as far south as Florida's Gulf Coast.

human: Thousands of pro-Palestinian protesters took to the streets of Lower Manhattan on Friday afternoon for what was billed as a “Shut Down Wall Street” event, just as the United States vetoed a resolution at the United Nations Security Council calling for a permanent cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

human: Low approval ratings and rock-bottom consumer confidence figures have dogged President Biden for months now, a worrying sign for the White House as the country enters a presidential election year.

llm: Low approval ratings for Trump in key battleground states, as well as voters' doubts about his honesty and trustworthiness, could be a boon to Democrats in 2020.

human: Sure, you can improve almost any vegetable by slicking it with oil and roasting it at high heat.

llm: Sure, you can eat broccoli raw in a salad or as a snack with hummus.
But roasting it is one of the best ways to bring out its flavor and nutritional benefits.
Here’s how to do it right: Preheat oven to 450 degrees Fahrenheit.
Break off tough ends of stalks and discard; cut florets into bite-size pieces.
Place on large rimmed baking sheet.
Toss with enough extra virgin olive oil to lightly coat (about 2 tablespoons), salt and pepper.
Spread into single layer.
Roast until tender and browned in spots, about 18 minutes.

human: Confinement comes up often in two debut story collections, “House Gone Quiet,” by Kelsey Norris, and “The World Wasn’t Ready for You,” by Justin C. Key.

llm: Confinement comes up in the title story of Joy Williams’s “Ninety-Nine Stories of God” (Tin House, 240 pages, $19.95).
In it, a man goes to his dentist appointment to have his cavity filled, but ends up being held captive there by an angry dental hygienist who thinks he has stolen her boyfriend.
She makes him sit in the chair for hours while she reads aloud from various religious texts.
He is confined to this place where he can do nothing, where time slows down and loses its meaning.

llm: Ukraine scored a major military victory on Sunday by hitting and destroying an armored column of Russian vehicles that had rolled into Ukraine from Russia.

human: At its core, the Colorado lawsuit trying to keep Donald Trump off the 2024 ballot involves a clash between constitutional textualism and voter empowerment.
llm: At its core, Trump's appeal to his supporters is a direct threat to our democracy.

human: In cities from New York to Vienna, new short-term-rental restrictions — designed to improve housing availability for residents — are poised to boost the bottom lines at hotels.

In New York in November, shortly after Airbnb and the like were limited to stays of 30 days or longer, hotel occupancy was up 6 percent and rates were up 8 percent, according to the commercial real estate firm CoStar.
llm: In cities from New York to San Francisco, it's not uncommon for a vacation rental unit to cost two or three times as much per night as a hotel room.
But the high-end hotels are fighting back with new amenities and luxury features that make them a more attractive option for business travelers.

human: From deep within a papyrus scroll that has not been read in almost 2,000 years and would crumble to pieces if unrolled, researchers have retrieved a handful of letters and a single word: “porphyras,” ancient Greek for “purple.”
llm: From deep within the Roman Empire, a scroll has spoken.

human: Good morning, dear connectors.
Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
llm: Good morning, dear readers!
We have a guest post from the lovely Cassandra Carr today.
She's sharing an excerpt from her book The Connections Companion with us and she's also giving away some goodies to one lucky commenter!
You can enter by filling out the Rafflecopter form below.

human: Here’s what bank security employees might be thinking when deciding whether to shut down a customer account after detecting unusual activity.
llm: Here’s what bankers are saying about this case study.

human: Eighteen months ago, when the New York-based T writer at large Aatish Taseer began planning his reporting trips for this month’s three-part feature story — an exploration of religious travel in Bolivia, Mongolia and Iraq — he was already well acquainted with the idea of pilgrimage.

His first book, the 2009 memoir “Stranger to History,” opens with what is arguably the world’s best-known faith-motivated journey, the hajj to Mecca, and ends with what he describes as a personal pilgrimage to meet his estranged father in Pakistan.
In Delhi, India, where Taseer grew up, quick trips for the purpose of worship were commonplace.
“People would do a pilgrimage on an ordinary Sunday,” he says, “instead of going to an amusement park.”
llm: Eighteen months ago, I bought a new car.
It was my first in eight years.

human: Unconscious bias in the medical profession may be raising risks for pregnant Black women.
llm: Unconscious bias in the medical community is contributing to a disproportionate number of deaths and injuries among black women during childbirth, says journalist Linda Villarosa.
She talks with NPR's Michel Martin about her cover story in The New York Times Magazine.

human: On a clear late summer day in 1976, a plane popped up on the radar just off the coast of the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido.
It had been flying a mere 100 feet off the water, low enough to avoid detection.
Now, suddenly, it climbed up to 20,000 feet.
Clearly, the pilot wanted to be seen.
llm: On a clear evening on Sept. 6, 1976, Victor Ivanovich Belenko, a pilot in the Soviet Air Force, flew his MiG-25 fighter jet from an airfield in Siberia toward Japan and then, after refueling, landed at a civilian airport near Tokyo.
He was granted political asylum by the United States and became one of the most famous defectors of the Cold War era.
His defection came at a time when the superpowers were vying for supremacy in military technology.
The MiG-25, called the Foxbat by NATO, was the fastest operational aircraft in the world — it could reach speeds of more than Mach 3 (three times the speed of sound) — and

human: Vice President Kamala Harris is crucial to the Biden campaign’s strategy for winning over a skeptical Democratic base.
llm: Vice President Kamala D. Harris?
It could happen.
Here is a link to the NYT article: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/09/magazine/an-interview-with-kamala-harris-on-whats-at-stake-in-2024.html.

human: “I had no role models, and then comes this woman, Sandra Day O’Connor, who says, ‘I can make decisions and I can think independently.’”
llm: “I had no idea she was so young,” Justice Antonin Scalia said.
“She doesn’t look it.”

human: In his new memoir, “Uncross Your Legs,” a 95-year-old designer chronicles a lifetime of adventures in apparel (and out).
llm: In his new book, "At Home with Stan Herman," the designer chronicles his life's work.

human: The catchy, folk-tinged numbers from “Treason the Musical” have been streamed online over a million times, in 96 countries.
Its fans — known as “Plotters” — have been listening to an EP, an acoustic record and a live album of the songs, as well as sharing their own performances on TikTok.
But until this fall, there hadn’t even been a full-scale production of the show.
llm: The catchy, folk-tinged songs by Todd Almond and the direction by Gabriel Barre (“Bat Boy: The Musical”) make “Treason,” at City Center through June 30, a lively, engaging evening of musical theater.
But its real selling point is that it has been built around an audience, not vice versa.

human: In the 1970s and ’80s, when Rainer Judd was growing up at 101 Spring Street in New York’s SoHo with her father, the artist Donald Judd, she’d sit in the building’s open windows, “because no one told me not to,” she said, and because back then, SoHo was a “creaky, dirty, lovely place.”
In 1971, her father wrote that one day, the neighborhood might be invaded by “tourist shops and restaurants, bad art and high rents.”

And while this premonition has largely come to pass, his home, a cast-iron former textile factory where his family — which also included his wife, the dancer Julie Finch, and his son, Flavin — lived according to Judd’s influential ideas about art and architecture, is almost entirely unchanged.
llm: In the 1970s, a group of artists in New York City set out to challenge painting.
They wanted to rethink what an artwork could be, using new materials and methods to create objects that didn't hang on walls or sit on pedestals.

human: For many, the upcoming holidays mark the most ambitious cooking and baking season of the year.
And The New York Times Food and Cooking team hopes to help with the endeavor.
Last week, it published a special Thanksgiving section, stuffed with recipes — and mouthwatering photos.
llm: For many, the idea of being a food stylist is something out of a dream.
Working with delicious food all day?
Sounds like a pretty great gig.
But the reality behind the scenes can be much more difficult than it looks on TV and in magazines.
A new book by Denise Vivaldo called How to Stylish Food: The Art of Preparing Food for the Camera offers an inside look at what really goes on behind-the-scenes.

human: An auto-generated poll that Microsoft embedded on its news aggregating platform alongside a Guardian article was “crass” and caused significant damage to The Guardian’s reputation, the newspaper said on Thursday.
llm: An auto-generated poll from Microsoft’s Bing search engine is under fire after it asked people to vote on the question, “Should Holocaust denial be illegal?”
The poll was embedded in a news story about the conviction of a prominent British Holocaust denier.

human: Walt Garrison, a hard-nosed running back for the Dallas Cowboys in the 1960s and ’70s and a member of the ProRodeo Hall of Fame who became a cult hero in Texas, his home state, as the rare Cowboy who actually was a cowboy, has died.
He was 79.
llm: Walt Garrison, a Cowboy Three Times Over, Dies at 79 - The New York Times

human: Joseph Lelyveld, who worked as a reporter and editor at The New York Times for 39 years, the last seven of them as executive editor, died on Jan. 5.
He was 86.
Below, Bill Keller, who served as a managing editor under Mr. Lelyveld, and later as The Times’s executive editor from 2003 to 2011, remembers Mr. Lelyveld as a journalist.
llm: Joseph Lelyveld, who left his post as executive editor of the New York Times in 2001, was a reporter and foreign correspondent before he moved into management.
He won a Pulitzer Prize for reporting on South Africa’s transition to black rule.
In retirement, he has written a biography of Mahatma Gandhi and, most recently, “His Final Battle: The Last Months of Franklin Roosevelt.”

human: When President Biden signed his sweeping executive order on artificial intelligence last week, he joked about the strange experience of watching a “deep fake” of himself, saying, “When the hell did I say that?”
llm: When President Biden said in his inaugural address that the federal government would regulate artificial intelligence, he was thinking of a few things: First, he was thinking about how to make sure algorithms weren’t biased against some groups of people.
Second, he was thinking about making sure robots didn’t take away jobs from human beings.
Third, he was thinking about how to protect people’s privacy and security as more and more data was collected by computers.
And fourth, he was thinking about how to prevent super-intelligent machines from taking over the world.

human: For the second time now, an Alexander Payne movie has changed Paul Giamatti’s life.

The actor, who played the Almighty in the 2014 movie “Noah,” has reprised that role for the new Broadway musical “John.”

human: A Long Island man was charged on Tuesday with smuggling $200,000 worth of deceased, protected butterflies, including exceptionally large ones known as birdwings, and other insects into and out of the United States.
llm: A Long Island man has been charged with smuggling more than 13,500 illegal butterflies and moths into the United States from Thailand.

human: A German tourist was killed and several other people were injured in central Paris late Saturday after a man attacked them with a knife and a hammer, the French authorities said.
The case stirred fears of renewed Islamist terrorist attacks in a nation already on edge.
llm: A German tourist was killed and four others injured in a knife attack in the French capital.
The Islamic State group claimed responsibility for the deadly rampage.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump lashed out at the special counsel, Jack Smith, on Wednesday, accusing his office of violating Mr. Trump’s due process rights by seeking to obtain a guilty verdict against him before Election Day in the two federal cases he is facing “no matter the cost.”
llm: Lawyers for former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort and President Donald Trump on Monday attacked the government's case against their clients as they tried to persuade a federal judge in Virginia not to move forward with the trials scheduled later this year.

human: Each day the Israel-Gaza war continues, the risks of a cataclysm intensify.
llm: Each day the newspapers are filled with stories of soldiers returning from Iraq and Afghanistan with post traumatic stress disorder.
Twenty percent of the soldiers who have seen heavy combat in Iraq suffer.
But what about the civilians in those war zones?
Men and women who witness the horrors of war close up?
Reporter Neal Conan talks with author, Susan Campbell, whose book is titled The Road Back From Hell: Sexual Violence Against Women and Girls in War and Its Aftermath.

human: Among the soldiers and volunteers heading to Israel from Kennedy Airport this month, as fighting raged in Gaza, were seven Jewish New Yorkers whose lifelong desires were being fulfilled.
They were in seven coffins in the cargo hold of an El Al flight to Israel, where they would be buried.
llm: Among the soldiers who died in Iraq, 15 were Jews who chose to be buried in Israel.
Their stories are intertwined with that of their country and its wars.

human: A woman in a sparkly red dress makes a grand gesture.
Then she notices that she’s being watched and suddenly looks like a squirrel that has realized it isn’t alone.
She tries to make another grand gesture only to be stymied when the Bubble Wrap under her feet pops.
Soon she is joined by a woman in a sparkly black dress who seems trapped in the same situation, reaching for elegance only to have that ideal pop, again and again.
The second woman hunches over and hyperventilates.
llm: A woman in a white suit and heels dances on the stage of the Joyce Theater.
She is joined by a man wearing a black suit, shirt and tie, with sneakers.
They dance together for a while, until they are interrupted by another dancer, this one wearing red.
The first two dancers stop, look at each other and leave the stage.

human: “I’m so happy to have a schedule again.”
llm: “I’m so happy,” said Ms. LeClair, a 51-year-old office manager who had been married for six years before discovering that her husband was leading a double life.
She left him in March and moved to Phoenix from Colorado with her two teenage sons.
“It’s not just about me,” she added.
“It’s about my kids, too.”

human: The son of a once prominent Hollywood agent and executive has been charged in the murder of a woman investigators believe to be his wife and whose remains were found bagged inside a dumpster in Los Angeles this week, the police said.
llm: The son of a former top Hollywood agent was charged on Thursday with the murder and torture of his girlfriend, who had been missing for more than three years.
The body of the woman, Jennifer Spindel, 40, was found in a metal trunk in his apartment in San Diego.

human: Over the weekend, the Israeli military appears to have begun an invasion of the Gaza Strip, with tanks rolling into the enclave and Israeli soldiers fighting Hamas inside.
But the operation remains shrouded in secrecy, and Israel is revealing little about its actions.
llm: Over the weekend, Israel began its invasion of Gaza.
Since then, 40 people have been killed and more than 310 wounded as Israeli warplanes drop bombs on one of the most densely populated places in the world.
More than 2,000 Israeli troops are massed on the border with Gaza awaiting a possible ground invasion.

On Saturday, thousands of Palestinians joined a funeral procession for four young cousins from the Baker family who were killed by an Israeli naval bombardment while playing soccer on a beach beside a coastal road west of Gaza City.
The boys were between nine and eleven years old.
Israel has rejected international calls for a ceasefire and is threatening to step up its attacks even further.

human: The police in New York City are searching for vandals who scrawled “Hamas” and antisemitic graffiti on several Upper East Side apartment buildings last month amid a sharp increase in hate crimes directed at the Jewish community.
llm: The police in New York City are reporting a huge increase in hate crimes directed against Jews, and they say the majority of these attacks were committed by blacks.

human: Annie Nightingale, who became the first female disc jockey on BBC Radio 1 in 1970 and remained a popular personality there until her final show, late last year, died on Jan. 11 at her home in London.
She was 83.
llm: Annie Nightingale, who became one of the first women to host a regular program on BBC Radio 1 in Britain and remained a vital presence on the airwaves for more than half a century, died on Monday at her home in London.
She was 83.
Her daughter Mary Nightingale confirmed the death but did not specify the cause.
Ms. Nightingale began working as an announcer for the BBC World Service in 1967 before joining Radio 1 when it started up two years later.
In 1970 she took over what was then the station’s weekly late-night music show, which ran from 2 to 5 a.m., and gave it its still-used name, “The Chill Out Zone.”
The show made her a favorite among listeners seeking a

human: Federal Reserve policymakers expected that rates might need to rise slightly higher as of their September meeting, freshly released minutes from the gathering showed.
But they were also determined to creep forward carefully, wary that they could overdo it and clamp down on the economy too hard.
llm: Federal Reserve policymakers were cautiously optimistic about the economy when they met at the end of last month, according to minutes released Wednesday.
But they also expressed concern that inflation would remain persistently below their 2% target, and they indicated that they were unlikely to raise interest rates anytime soon.
The Fed left its benchmark rate unchanged after the meeting, and investors expect it will keep them near zero for a while longer, as the recovery remains fragile.
The central bank’s policy-making committee said it was encouraged by recent signs of improvement in the labor market but was still concerned about weak inflation.
It suggested that it wouldn’t raise interest rates until “inflation moves back toward” its long-run objective.
Inflation has been running well under 2%, and

human: As a teenager in the 1980s, I watched the construction of the intricately designed Rashad al-Shawa Cultural Center in Gaza City, named after one of Gaza’s greatest public figures, and its theater, grand hall, public library, printing press and cultural salon.
llm: As a teenager, I lived in the same neighborhood as Mayor Abu Samra.
The last time we met was in 2005 when he visited San Francisco to attend a conference on the Middle East.
At the time, I wrote an article about him entitled "A Gazan Mayor's Vision of Peace".
In that interview, Mr. Abu Samra had expressed his dream for peace between Israelis and Palestinians:

human: The Times deputy editor of Culture and Lifestyle, Melissa Kirsch, has spent many years thinking about innovative ways to approach the New Year’s resolution.
Here she shares three of her favorite strategies for making your resolutions more achievable and more fun.
llm: The Times deputy editor, Paul Webster, said the newspaper was reviewing its policy on the use of such pictures.
He said: "We accept that we made a mistake and we apologise for it."

human: Federal prosecutors have accused 10 people of orchestrating a $20 million scheme to “get rich” by buying and selling black-market H.I.V. medications that in some cases had been purchased from low-income patients who risked their lives by selling it.
llm: Federal prosecutors have accused 10 people of running a multimillion-dollar drug ring that sold expensive prescription drugs for treating AIDS and H.I.V., as well as other serious illnesses, on the black market at huge profits.

human: See full results and maps from the 2023 Maine elections.
llm: See full results and maps from the Maine midterm elections.

human: When art dealers decide to participate in fairs like Art Basel Miami Beach, one of the many tricky decisions they will make is this one: Whether the pieces they choose to feature fall into the primary market category — meaning that they have never been owned by anyone but the artist — or the secondary market, for works that have been bought and sold before.
llm: When art dealers gather in the ballroom of the Fontainebleau hotel in Miami Beach on Tuesday evening, they will face a stark choice: stick with their trade association, which has been buffeted by internal disagreements and financial problems, or form an alternative group.

human: I’m in my early 70s, and I’m married to a man in his 60s.
My husband’s father struggled with Alzheimer’s for almost a dozen years before he died.
It was incredibly hard on everyone involved.
And now my husband is in the midst of his own health crisis.
He has had some significant cognitive decline in the past two years, which affects his ability to function to his satisfaction.
He is constantly looking for his phone or iPad.
He gets lost while driving.
He sometimes asks me to help him send a text or email because he can’t remember how to do it.
This causes him so much shame.
He says he no longer belongs in this world.
His dysfunction reminds him of his father’s decline, and he doesn’t want to put himself or others through that pain.
llm: I’m in my mid-40s and my husband is 67.
We have been together for eight years, married for three.
My husband has dementia and it has progressed to the point that he needs full-time care.
He has no short-term memory but his long-term memory is still quite good.
He has a very strong sense of self and knows what he wants and doesn’t want.
He was very clear before his diagnosis about not wanting to live with this disease.
He has said many times that if he gets like his mother (who had Alzheimer’s) he would want me to help him die.
She lived in a nursing home for four years and died at age 93.
He has seen her decline up close and personal.

human: Tess Merrell had breastfed three babies and never expected trouble with her fourth.
But after a month of struggling with her newborn, she hired Melanie Henstrom for help.
llm: Tess Merrell had a son, Owen, who was born with Down syndrome and a heart defect.
He died at 10 weeks old after undergoing two surgeries to repair his heart.
The family was devastated.

human: Two people have died in a salmonella outbreak linked to cantaloupes as cases have more than doubled since the outbreak was first announced last week, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Friday.
llm: Two people have died and 141 others in 20 states have been sickened by a salmonella outbreak linked to cantaloupe grown at an Indiana farm, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said today.

human: When it comes to grocery shopping, there seem to be two kinds of people in this world: those who prefer self-checkout, and those who prefer interaction with a human.
llm: When it comes to the future of retail, everyone is talking about automation and self-service.
But there's one grocer that just said goodbye to its self-checkout kiosks: Kroger.

human: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China shook hands at the entrance of a grand estate set in the hills of California yesterday as they began their first meeting in a year.
llm: President Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping meet in the Oval Office on Thursday, November 21.

human: China has cast itself as a neutral geopolitical player in the Middle East.
It brokered a deal in March to help Iran and Saudi Arabia restore relations.
And in the days since Hamas attacked Israel from Gaza, China has tried to keep its distance, with a government spokesman calling the country “a common friend of both Israel and Palestine.”
llm: China has cast a long shadow over the global economy, and it is only getting longer.

While the United States, Japan and Europe have struggled with the effects of the financial crisis, China has enjoyed a sustained boom, powered by domestic investment and exports to other emerging markets.
In 2010, China displaced Germany as the world's largest exporter and surpassed Japan as the second-largest economy after the United States.
By some estimates, China will replace the US as the world's largest economy in the next two decades.

human: We’ve reached that lull in the school year when the excitement of Back to School has worn off and the reality of spending long stretches staring into the laptop and Smart Board has set in.
Sitting still, glued to screens, for hours.
llm: We’ve reached that time of year when parents are preparing to send their kids back to school.
As a parent, I think about all the ways my wife and I can help our children make this upcoming school year the best yet.
And as an educator, I wonder how we can prepare today’s students for a world that is changing in unprecedented ways.

human: Rory McIlroy, the esteemed golfer who was among the most outspoken opponents of his sport’s swelling ties to Saudi Arabia, has resigned from the PGA Tour’s board.
llm: Rory McIlroy, the No. 1 player in the world golf rankings and a two-time major champion, has resigned from his position on the PGA Tour board of directors, according to a statement released by the tour Friday morning.

human: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration — or tell us about a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.
llm: Use your imagination and creativity to explore the theme of Reflection.
