The possibilities are endless!

human: The Chinese government stepped up its efforts to influence American politics in the 2022 election, a new report released on Monday said, and intelligence officials are trying to learn if Beijing is preparing to further intensify those activities in next year’s presidential election.
llm: The Chinese government sought to influence the 2018 election in favor of Republicans and against Democrats, according to an intelligence report released Thursday by the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence.

human: In 1892, The New York Times printed an account from a reporter in St. Petersburg, Russia.
The reporter said Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich, posing as a “peasant,” got into a “squabble with a baker.”
Not knowing who he was, police officers “hustled” the duke.
They were about to arrest him when he revealed his identity.
llm: In 1892, The New York Times reported that a man named John O’Reilly had been arrested for stealing $60 from a woman in the city.
According to police, he was “an old offender” who had recently arrived from Chicago.
There, it was said, he had been known as one of the best pickpockets on record.
He had been caught by a detective named Thomas F. Byrnes, “who has a reputation throughout the country for his cleverness in runnin...

human: Good graphic novels tend to appear in bookstores seemingly out of nowhere after years of rumors, scattershot serialization, “process” zines and snippets posted to social media.
As literature, long-form comics are uniquely resistant to editing.
As visual art, the cartoonist is in the weird position of having no access to the final product until it’s presented to the public.
So it’s frankly miraculous when we get as many good comics as we do.
This year there were remarkable new books from established masters and freshman graphic novels from brilliant young artists.
Better still, a gratifyingly thick stratum of our 2023 stack was devoted to making us laugh.
It’s a rich conversation, and one that promises to continue into next year and long beyond.
llm: Good graphic novels, from a variety of genres.

human: If Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for president in 2024, it’s now clear he will likely still have criminal indictments hanging over his head on Election Day.
It’s possible that his criminal liability for the events leading up to the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol will remain unresolved.
llm: If Donald Trump’s trial starts on Jan. 6, as scheduled by Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.), it will be a sprint to judgment for all concerned: The Senate is expected to be in session only five days that week, which means that there are just nine legislative days before Feb. 4, when senators take off for Iowa and New Hampshire.
With the Democratic presidential nominating contests starting just after Groundhog Day this year, senators will want to get out of town ASAP.

human: The Ukrainian military said on Thursday that its troops were fighting “in the vicinities” of a village behind the eastern frontline town of Marinka, a strong indication that Kyiv’s forces have lost control of the town, more than a week after Moscow claimed to have seized it.
llm: The Ukrainian military reported a major escalation in fighting with pro-Russia separatists in eastern Ukraine, with rebel attacks spreading to a third front close to the border with Russia.
The separatist offensive appears to be aimed at seizing control of the town of Shchastya and opening up a new route for weapons and supplies from Russia.

human: New York City’s homeless system is sheltering record numbers of people week after week, as an influx of migrants accelerates to its highest rate since the crisis began.
llm: New York City’s mayor, Bill de Blasio, said the city had reached a breaking point and would no longer cooperate with federal officials.
He called for an end to what he described as a policy of “dumping unaccompanied homeless children onto our doorstep.”

human: Seoul marked a somber anniversary over the weekend, a year after nearly 160 people died in a crowd surge in Itaewon, a popular nightlife district in the city.
llm: Seoul marked a subdued Halloween on Saturday as residents of the city's foreign enclave remembered the tragic deaths of two young girls in last year's festivities.
The neighborhood of Itaewon was packed with people dressed up for Halloween parties at local bars and clubs.
But the atmosphere was more muted than usual after two teenage girls were crushed to death in front of a nightclub during last year's celebrations.

human: Wolverines in the contiguous United States are threatened by climate change and habitat fragmentation and will be listed under the Endangered Species Act, the federal government announced Wednesday.
llm: Wolverines in the lower 48 states are going to get a little extra protection.
The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced last week that it would list the wolverine as threatened under the Endangered Species Act.
This listing is important for several reasons, not least of which is that it gives the species some additional protections against hunting or trapping.

human: “I had a family that went hunting with me instead of going to Disney World.”
llm: “I had a lot of people say, ‘You can’t do that,’” she said.
“And I thought, well, I’m going to try.”

human: In 2013, after years trying to get permission from layer upon layer of authorities in India to put up an outdoor light work, the artist Shilpa Gupta finally got the OK — with the caveat that she take down the piece within 24 hours.
That would have been impossible, but she signed the papers anyway, knowing that once the piece was up, it would take some time before anyone would come around to make her remove it.
llm: In 2013, after the conviction of a young woman for sedition in India, the artist Nalini Malani made an installation about freedom of speech.
The work is now showing at the Asia Society Museum in New York City.
CreditNalini Malani/Luhring Augustine, New York; © 2016 Nalini Malani/Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

human: The word vertiginous has appeared in 55 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 26 in “PinkPantheress’s Music Broke the Internet.
Up Next?
Everything Else” by Lindsay Zoladz:
llm: The word vertiginous is an adjective.

Vertiginous means (1) inclined to frequent change; unstable especially in affections or attachments, (2) tending to cause disorientation, (3) liable to fall or give way, (4) having a confused sensation of whirling and a tendency to fall.
The Quisto editorial staff has evaluated these websites and placed them in the Vertiginous information category.

human: Going into the Iowa caucuses, there were a handful of key things we were watching for: Would the frigid weather hamper turnout?
Would his overwhelming dominance in the polls translate to a decisive victory for Donald Trump?
And finally, could the other candidates muster enough of a showing to keep the race alive?
llm: Going into the 2016 primaries, I had been pretty sure of who I wanted to vote for.
As a Democrat, I was planning to vote for Bernie Sanders in my state's primary.

But after the South Carolina Democratic primary results came in on Saturday night and Hillary Clinton won by a landslide, I started having second thoughts about my choice — it felt like this primary was over already, even though there are still more than 45 states left to vote.

human: How did you get your last name?
Was it passed down to you from your father’s side of the family?
That is how last names are usually given to babies in the United States, but some families are taking different approaches.

They may draw from the mother’s side instead, use both parents’ last names (sometimes placing a hyphen between them), choose a name that has family history or other significance — or come up with something wholly original.
llm: How did you and your spouse decide what to do?
Did you take one of the other's name, combine them, hyphenate or come up with a brand new last name for both of you?
How did you make your decision?
Would you change it if you could go back in time?

human: A consulting firm that has worked extensively with Nikki Haley and her political action committee is facing a lawsuit from a former employee who says that an executive sexually assaulted her, and that other executives failed to take appropriate action and retaliated against her in response.
llm: A consulting firm that has worked with the Trump administration and former U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley is facing a sexual assault lawsuit from a former employee who claims she was raped by an executive at the company in 2015.

human: The House of Representatives still has no speaker, crippling a vital branch of the government.
And the Republican who seems to be in the strongest position to take the role, Jim Jordan of Ohio, was once called a “legislative terrorist” by a former speaker of his own party.
llm: The House of Representatives is about to pick a new speaker.
This process has been full of backroom deals and arm twisting.
The Republican caucus votes on the next speaker tomorrow, and it could be a wild ride.

human: There’s nothing that gets me turning the pages of a book faster than a love triangle.
Maybe I’m a glutton for punishment (most of the time, the romantic interest I root for doesn’t get the girl, and yes, I was Team Jacob), but I always go back for more.
I can’t help it.
The drama and angst surrounding it all is addictive!
llm: There’s nothing that makes me happier than the prospect of a new novel by Elizabeth Eulberg.
I love her characters and their stories, which are always smartly written and emotionally engaging.
Her latest book, We Can Work It Out, is no exception.
It’s a sweet story with strong female friendships, a swoon-worthy romance, and plenty of drama to keep you reading until the very end.

human: The Israeli military said yesterday that it had briefly sent tanks into the northern Gaza Strip overnight as part of preparations for the next stage of fighting, after the prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, indicated that the country was likely to carry out a ground invasion of the enclave.
llm: The Israeli military said Friday that it had sent tanks into the southern Gaza Strip to destroy a tunnel being dug by Palestinian militants.
It was the first time since Israel withdrew from Gaza last September that its forces have entered the area, although they are stationed along the border and often fire at targets there.

human: An assistant manager at a Chipotle restaurant in Kansas pulled off an employee’s hijab, according to a federal lawsuit that contains allegations of religious harassment that a federal official described as “quite egregious.”
llm: An assistant manager of a Chipotle restaurant near Washington pulled off an employee’s hijab while she was preparing food and threw it on the floor, the Justice Department said Monday as it announced a lawsuit accusing the restaurant chain of discrimination.
The woman who wore the hijab is Muslim, according to the department’s complaint, which was filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
It accused Chipotle of violating federal civil rights laws by subjecting employees at the Macomb Mall location in Sterling Heights, Mich., to harassment because of their national origin and religion.

human: Bombing on the big test.
Falling on your face during an audition for the school play.
Striking out with the bases loaded in a big game.
llm: Bombing on the SATs is a common fear for college-bound students.
But it's not just about the scores.
It's what you do with them that counts.

human: The nail-biter “No One Will Save You” quietly materialized on Hulu Sept. 22 and became a streaming darling overnight, an apt entrance for a largely dialogue-free chiller about an alien invasion.
llm: The nail-biter “No One Will Save You” is one of the most understated horror films in recent memory.

The 12-minute short, which premiered at Cannes last year and won Best Short Film at this year’s Sitges International Fantastic Film Festival, is so effective because it uses minimal dialogue to achieve maximum impact.
Writer/director Kristian A. Söderström has crafted a tense tale that leaves viewers feeling as uneasy as the film’s protagonist.

human: The posters dotting the streets of Buenos Aires had a certain Soviet flair to them.
llm: The posters dotting the Argentine capital have a familiar face: that of President Mauricio Macri, whose image is emblazoned on campaign ads ahead of Sunday’s midterm elections.

human: More than two months after a Hamas-led attack in Israel killed 1,200 people, according to officials, the Israeli military is hunting for members of Hamas, the group that runs Gaza, including its most wanted man in the territory: Yahya Sinwar, the Hamas leader it considers the mastermind of the Oct. 7 attacks.
llm: More than two weeks after the Israeli military launched a ground invasion of Gaza, Palestinians and Israelis are still under fire.
Over 600 Palestinians have been killed, along with more than 25 Israeli soldiers.
The number of injured is now over 3,700.
In recent days, Hamas has continued to fire rockets into Israel as Israel bombards targets across Gaza.
On Thursday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would not accept any ceasefire that did not allow troops to complete the destruction of tunnels used by Hamas for raids.
Meanwhile, U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry flew back to Washington after failing to secure an immediate truce between Israel and Hamas who both rejected a proposal

human: Deep in her new book, “Oath and Honor,” Liz Cheney points out that the likeness of Clio, the Greek muse of history, is found in the Capitol’s National Statuary Hall.
“Clio is depicted riding in the chariot of time, making notes in the book in her hand,” Cheney writes, “as a reminder that what we do in the Capitol Building is written in the pages of history.”
llm: Deep in her heart, she's a liberal.

human: Just in time for the holiday season, the Biden administration is offering Americans a fresh round of free at-home coronavirus tests through the Postal Service.
llm: Just in time for the holiday season, the U.S. government is offering another round of free home tests to check if you have been infected with the new coronavirus known as COVID-19.

human: Nokia announced a major overhaul of its business on Thursday that includes slashing up to 14,000 jobs, or about 16 percent of its work force, over the next three years.
llm: Nokia announced a major overhaul of its business on Thursday that will lead to the loss of 14,000 jobs and shift focus away from smartphones.

The Finnish telecommunications giant said it would reduce its workforce by up to 23 percent through layoffs and site closures as part of a new strategy aimed at focusing more on its network infrastructure business.
Nokia's share price soared after the announcement, closing 7.9 percent higher in Helsinki.

human: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy.
Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
llm: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets readers know what bits tickled Jimmy Fallon and Seth Meyers the most on Monday night.
With the House Judiciary Committee’s first impeachment hearing underway, President Donald Trump was an easy target for the hosts, as were Rudy Giuliani and his henchmen.

And although some late-night hosts took aim at Mike Johnson (R-La.), the newly elected congressman from Louisiana's Fourth Congressional District is not actually the one who referred to himself as “Johnson” in an interview with Fox News’ Maria Bartiromo on Sunday — it was Republican Rep. Mike Johnson from Louisiana’s 4th Congressional District.
In case you missed it, here are five highlights from last night:

human: Good morning.
It’s Wednesday.
We’ll look at why a violent attack last week renewed attention on ways to make subway platforms safer.
llm: Good morning.
It’s Wednesday, Jan. 24.

human: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Charleston, S.C., the oldest A.M.E. church in the South, will forever be associated with former President Barack Obama because of his memorable — and melodic — eulogy for the nine victims of a racist massacre in its fellowship hall in June 2015.
llm: Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church was founded in 1816.
The current church building is the fourth to house this congregation and was built between 1890 and 1892.
It is a brick Gothic Revival structure with a corner tower topped by a spire.
Its interior features ornate woodwork and stained glass windows.
It has been designated as a National Historic Landmark.

human: If one of your 2024 resolutions is to cook more fish, you’ve probably already trawled New York Times Cooking’s recipe collections for foolproof fish and easy weeknight salmon.
And if your resolution is simply to eat more fish — not necessarily to cook it — there’s this new recipe for poke bowls from Naz Deravian.
It’s a wonderful way to let a beautiful piece of fish shine while mingling with all sorts of delicious friends: cucumber, avocado, radish, pickled ginger.
Poke piqued your attention?
Try these other recipes for raw fish: Ali Slagle’s crispy rice with salmon and avocado, and a new one from the chef Sheldon Simeon for hamachi sashimi with ginger ponzu.
llm: If one of your goals is to eat more fish, here's a good reason: A new study found that people who ate baked or broiled fish at least once a week had higher cognitive function than those who didn't.
The researchers also found that eating fried fish was associated with lower scores on the tests they gave their subjects.
If you don't care for fish, try making a vegetarian version of this recipe using soy-based sausage, such as Field Roast.
Serve with some whole grain pasta tossed in olive oil and lemon juice.

human: By the time the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year, a draft of the ruling had been leaked to the press and the outcome was anticipated.

The story behind the decision seemed obvious: The constitutional right to abortion effectively had died with Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose replacement, Amy Coney Barrett, was a favorite of the anti-abortion movement.
llm: By the time that Roe v. Wade was decided in 1973, it was already clear to many conservatives that the Supreme Court’s expansion of personal liberty and equal rights had gone too far.
It seemed to them that liberal judges were legislating from the bench, striking down laws passed by democratically elected lawmakers, and even reinterpreting the Constitution itself.
The justices who voted for Roe — a 7-to-2 majority — were continuing what came to be known as the Warren Court revolution, which began in the late 1950s and continued into the early ’70s.
The court ruled against prayer in public schools; ordered the desegregation of public facilities; expanded the rights of criminal suspects; and,

human: Visitors willing to explore the alleyways of this arts- and food-loving city will find gems at every turn.
llm: Visitors willing to go outside the city's well-worn tourist circuit will find that there is more to Melbourne than Federation Square, Flinders Street Station and the Yarra River.

While it may be true that Melburnians are obsessed with coffee (and cafes), food (and restaurants) and footy (that's Australian rules football, for those not in the know), they also love their art, architecture, parks, gardens, markets and multiculturalism.
With its nonstop schedule of festivals, exhibitions and special events, there's always something going on in this town.
And while Melbourne is often touted as Australia's most European city - its wide boulevards, elegant 19th century buildings and stately parks do evoke a certain

human: Since the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, when cruise ships filled with sickened passengers were blocked from U.S. ports, residents in Key West, Fla., have been trying to limit the size and number of vacation vessels on the tiny island, using the momentum created during the pandemic to argue for continuing restrictions on cruise vessels.
llm: Since the early 1980s, cruise ships have docked at a city-owned pier.
But with larger and more modern vessels now sailing to the island, they can no longer fit at the pier.
The U.S. Coast Guard has required the larger ships to anchor offshore and ferry passengers to land.

human: He hoped to succeed Indonesia’s longtime dictator.
He ordered the kidnappings of pro-democracy activists.
He was accused of atrocities during the ruthless military occupation of East Timor.
He has said elections run counter to his country’s culture.
llm: He hoped to win with a plurality, not a majority.
But he may be denied even that victory.

human: In our recent analysis of 515 million Wordle games played over a year, we noted that a few changes would soon be coming to WordleBot’s dictionary.
As of today, those changes are now live — including a new opening word in both regular and hard mode.
llm: In our recent posts, we have been tracking the way that the word “trace” has increasingly come to dominate the WordleCloud of the top 1000 words used in the titles and abstracts of articles published by the journal Trace.

human: As tempers flared on a recent evening in a nightlife district in Auckland, New Zealand’s largest city, Joanne Paikea sensed an altercation — or even an arrest — brewing.
llm: As tempers flared in the wake of a mass shooting in Christchurch, New Zealand, last week that left 50 people dead, a group of volunteer community leaders known as Maori wardens stepped into action.

human: An eighteen-wheeler sat motionless at the intersection of 26th Street and Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, completely blocking traffic in all directions.

As motorists blasted their horns in an orchestra of rage, the bewildered truck driver hopped down from the cab and began yelling — in a distinctly out-of-town drawl — at the pileup of cars behind him on 26th, demanding they back the heck up.
llm: An eighteen-wheeler sat in front of a warehouse, its engine running.
The driver was a fiftyish man with a graying beard and long hair pulled back into a ponytail.
His name was Gary Mathias.

human: Earlier this year, several things went missing from cargo trucks in Philadelphia.
Six refrigerators.
Sixty cases of Jose Cuervo tequila.
And then, somehow, more than two million dimes, worth nearly a quarter of a million dollars.
llm: Earlier this year, two men were arrested in connection with a theft at a coin factory.
According to reports, the men stole over $100,000 worth of dimes from the facility where they worked.
The incident was discovered when one of the suspects allegedly tried to deposit some of the coins into his bank account.
After an investigation by local police and federal authorities, both men have been indicted on federal charges.
One man faces charges for conspiracy to commit theft from an interstate shipment while the other is charged with attempting to steal government property.
Both could face up to five years in prison if convicted.

human: At least 17 people were killed when a passenger train and a freight train collided outside Bangladesh’s capital, Dhaka, during a busy holiday season.
llm: At least 17 people were killed and more than 50 others injured when two trains collided Tuesday morning in eastern Bangladesh, a government official said.

human: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet.
“The genre is rooted in my land,” she said, in a video call from her place just outside Madrid.
“It’s in our roots.”
llm: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo sings “I Am a Woman,” her voice is an instrument of passionate self-possession and empowerment.
She leans into the song, which is written in Andalusian Arabic dialect, with defiance and pride.
The song was recorded by Ms. Llergo for the 2018 documentary film “Yo, la peor de todas” (“Me, the Worst of All”), about the life of the 17th-century Mexican nun and poet Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz.
It is one of many songs that she has collected, preserved or created as part of her mission to amplify the voices of women who have been historically ignored.

human: On Dec. 4, 2020, Shaye Moss, at the time an election worker in Fulton County, Ga., was summoned to her supervisor’s office, where she thought she would be getting a promotion for her hard work on Election Day, after a month of positive feedback.
llm: On Dec. 4, 2019, the Washington Post published an op-ed by former Ohio Secretary of State Jennifer Brunner (D), who served as a co-leader of the Brennan Center's Election Protection efforts in Ohio during the 2016 presidential election.
The piece recounts her experience after then-candidate Donald Trump and his advisors falsely claimed that she and other Democratic officials were rigging the election against him.

human: “Put a good dinner in front of him, and he was a very good talker about world politics, and he always took his time.”
llm: “Put a good face on it, gentlemen,” said Mr. Clemens, “and cheer up.
You never can tell what will happen.”
– New York Times, March 31, 1906.

human: Donald Trump appeared today in front of an appeals court panel in Washington to argue that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election because they arose from actions he took as president.
The three judges on the panel seemed unconvinced, suggesting that they are unlikely to rule in the former president’s favor.
llm: Donald Trump appeared to be in some trouble when it was revealed that he paid $130,000 to a porn star named Stormy Daniels.
The payment had been made by his lawyer, Michael Cohen, through an entity called Essential Consultants LLC.
In addition to the payment to Ms. Daniels, it is also alleged that President Trump had affairs with Playboy model Karen McDougal and reality television personality Summer Zervos.

human: Information wants to be free, the saying goes — but misinformation does too, alas, and the journalists who reliably distinguish one from the other still need to be paid somehow.
This tension has prompted a lot of head-scratching in the news business over the past few decades, as two seasoned insiders explain in books we recommend this week:

In “Collision of Power,” the former Washington Post editor Martin Baron recalls his tenure at that august institution, while in “The Times” my colleague Adam Nagourney looks at challenges and sea changes at the news outlet we both call home.
(For one thing: It’s an “outlet” now, not just a newspaper.)
llm: Information wants to be free.
That's easy to say when you're Steve Jobs, and it costs you nothing to speak out against DRM.
But what if you're a midlist author who sees your livelihood threatened by illicit file sharing?

human: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, who has been a vocal critic of former President Donald J. Trump, nonetheless committed on Wednesday to supporting him if he won the Republican nomination, even if he were convicted of a felony.
llm: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire, who has endorsed Senator John McCain for president but has said he would back Donald J. Trump if he were to win the Republican nomination, is now committed to doing so.

human: Most words in the headline of a New York Times article are capitalized.
But capitalization is sparsely employed in the Spanish language, which uses the lowercase for many proper nouns and titles.
So when Elda Cantú and her team translate Times articles from English to Spanish, they might lowercase a few letters.
llm: Most words in this newsletter are in English.
We have provided definitions of Spanish words to help our readers who do not speak Spanish, but we encourage you to look up any word that is unfamiliar to you.
The best way to learn a language is to use it!

human: Israeli soldiers have encircled Gaza City, the Israeli military said yesterday, waging “face-to-face battles” with Hamas as they push forward with what officials have predicted will be a long and bloody ground invasion.
llm: Israeli soldiers have been instructed to open fire on Palestinian children who throw stones, in a move that has drawn criticism from human rights groups.

human: If companies want to leave Russia, the president is setting the terms — in ways that benefit his government, his elites and his war.
llm: If companies want to do business in Russia, they must accept that there are risks associated with doing so.

The recent announcement by Siemens that it is pulling out of its joint venture with Russian Railways should serve as a warning signal to other western investors: if you don’t like the way your business partner does things, then get out and stay out!

human: Mangled pipes poured sewer water into what remained of the road.
On either side of the runoff were piles of broken pavement, churned up by bulldozers.
The archway at the entrance to the neighborhood had been demolished; the gnarled hull of a black car sat nearby.
llm: Mangled pipes poured sewage onto the street.

human: At the outset of “Julia” — Sandra Newman’s retelling of George Orwell’s classic “1984,” this time as seen by Winston Smith’s love interest, Julia — we learn that our protagonist is a mechanic in the Fiction Department.

Fiction, along with Records and Research, makes up the Ministry of Truth, which is responsible for producing the official narrative of Oceania, and, since Oceania is a totalitarian state, producing history itself.
While Orwell situated Winston in Records, altering past news articles, Newman has Julia crawling around within the systems of Fiction.
llm: At the outset of George Orwell’s “1984,” Winston Smith is sitting at a desk writing in his diary.
He knows this is dangerous: The Thought Police are everywhere and there is no place where he can be sure that he will not be seen.

But if there is hope for humanity to escape its totalitarian oppressors, it lies with men like him — those who have had enough of Big Brother’s tyranny and are willing to risk everything to record their thoughts as they truly exist, independent of Party propaganda.

human: The Moroccan restaurateur Kamal Laftimi, 53, grew up on the edges of Jemaa el-Fna, the main public square of Marrakesh and an entrance to the city’s historic medina quarter.

All day, and late into the night, travelers, musicians and local families wander through its cafes, souvenir shops and food stalls, against a soundtrack of hawkers’ shouts and the calls to prayer from the nearby Koutoubia Mosque.

“The square is always changing,” said Laftimi recently in the leafy courtyard of his latest restaurant, the Pétanque Social Club, located outside of the medina’s ancient walls, in the upscale neighborhood of Gueliz.
“You [go there] in the early morning and then a few hours later, it’s got a whole different atmosphere.”
llm: The Moroccan restaurateur Meryem Cherkaoui has turned her riad into one of the city’s most exciting, and discreet, new culinary destinations.
At Nur, everything is made fresh daily — including the tables.

human: Walking is among the world’s most popular forms of exercise, and far and away the most favored in the United States.
And for good reason: It’s simple, accessible and effective.
Taking regular walks lowers the risk of many health problems including anxiety, depression, diabetes and some cancers.
llm: Walking is among the simplest, most natural forms of exercise around.
It requires no special equipment or training, and you can do it almost anywhere at any time.
But if you're like many people, you might find yourself wondering whether walking is enough to keep you fit -- especially if you have a busy schedule.

human: Sometime in the next few weeks, when she wins her 1,203rd game, Tara VanDerveer at Stanford will pass Mike Krzyzewski at Duke as the college basketball coach — man or woman — with the most wins of all time.
llm: Sometime in the mid-1980s, I was on my way to play a tournament game.
The game was played at the Westchester County Center in White Plains NY.
I went upstairs and found that it was almost time for me to play.
My opponent was not there yet.
While waiting for him, I took out some games I had been working on.
One of them was a game I just played a few days earlier against an Expert.
It was a win for me and a very nice one too.
There were two spectators standing by watching me work.
When I finished looking over this particular game, one of the spectators said, “You’re going to lose”.
“What do you mean?”, I replied.
He pointed out that there was a move I could have made which would

human: The Food and Drug Administration’s approval on Friday of two groundbreaking gene therapy treatments for sickle cell disease has brought a rare moment of hope and celebration to people with the agonizing blood disorder.
llm: The Food and Drug Administration is likely to approve a new drug for sickle cell anemia this year.
Called Endari, the drug reduces the incidence of painful crises in patients with the disease by 25 percent or more.

But despite the fact that most Americans with sickle cell are African-American, only about 30 percent of those affected have health insurance through their employer or a government program such as Medicare or Medicaid.

human: On a warm Friday afternoon in October, Luis Ferré-Sadurní, who covers New York State politics for The New York Times, scanned the faces of a crowd at a beachfront resort in Puerto Rico.
He had hoped to spot Robert Menendez, the New Jersey senator who had been indicted on federal bribery charges — and who was, nevertheless, holding his annual fund-raiser at the hotel.
llm: On a warm spring afternoon in the West Village, Michael Barbaro sat on the edge of his bed and stared at his phone.
It was April 18, the day before he would start as a new reporter for The New York Times, and his head was spinning with questions: Should I buy a bicycle?
What’s my first story going to be about?
How do I get an office key?

human: Matt Gaetz’s gamble appears to have paid off.
llm: Matt Gaetz’s gamble on Trump paying off handsomely in Florida

human: Goldman Sachs said on Wednesday that it would offload GreenSky, a major player in the “buy now, pay later” lending sector, less than two years after buying the company, in the latest hit to its consumer-finance ambitions.
llm: Goldman Sachs said on Wednesday it had sold a stake in online fashion retailer Clearbanc to its founder and former employees after the investment bank’s first venture into the nascent “buy now, pay later” industry drew criticism from anti-poverty campaigners.
Goldman bought the stake in February 2019 for an undisclosed sum and added Clearbanc to its own consumer finance platform, Marcus by Goldman Sachs.
The deal came as part of a flurry of interest from Wall Street in the burgeoning market for credit to millennial shoppers who do not want to use traditional payment cards or cannot get loans.

human: The Falcons have a 77% chance to make the playoffs.
llm: The Falcons have a very difficult schedule ahead of them.
I think they will be lucky to win one or two more games this season.
They play the Saints twice and the Bucs are not pushovers.
The offense is inconsistent and the defense is terrible.
There has been a lot of talk about coaching changes, but I do not see that happening until after the season.

human: Pregnancy can feel like a nine-month feat of strength and stamina, filled with relentless physical challenges, from the extreme fatigue of the first trimester to the breathlessness and back pain of the third.
llm: Pregnancy can feel like a marathon, so why not train for it?

human: The Chinese government announced on Friday that Tesla would recall practically all of the cars it has sold in the country to adjust their assisted-driving systems, less than a month after a similar recall in the United States.
llm: The Chinese government has ordered Tesla to recall more than a million cars in the country after the company allegedly failed to meet its self-driving requirements.

human: Israeli officials say that everywhere Hamas terrorists struck on Oct. 7 — a rave, military bases along the Gaza border and kibbutz after kibbutz — they brutalized women.
llm: Israeli officials say they have thwarted a major terror attack on the US embassy in Tel Aviv, seizing three Palestinian men allegedly planning to kidnap an American diplomat.
The plot was reportedly hatched by members of Islamic Jihad from Jenin, who were arrested over the past month.
They are said to have been planning to grab their target at a beach near Tel Aviv and spirit him back to their base in the West Bank city.
In an operation code-named “Five Hundred,” Shin Bet security forces reportedly seized two rifles, six pistols, and ammunition during raids in Jenin.
Meanwhile, the Israeli army has imposed a curfew on Ramallah, seat of the Palestinian Authority, following

human: At least 51 people were killed yesterday when a rocket hit a group of people gathered for a wake in the village of Hroza in northeastern Ukraine, local officials said.
The strike was one of the deadliest wartime attacks on civilians since Russia’s full-scale invasion began more than 19 months ago.
llm: At least 51 people were killed and more than 90 injured in a series of explosions outside churches holding Easter services in Sri Lanka.
The blasts, six in total, occurred at three churches and three luxury hotels frequented by foreigners.
Police have arrested seven suspects in connection with the attacks.
No one has claimed responsibility for the bombings, but suspicion is focused on Islamic extremists.

human: If you’re a normal human being trying to read recent economic news, especially about inflation, you may be feeling confused right now.

You may have seen reports that consumer prices are up 3.1 percent over the past year, which sounds bad; “core” inflation, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, was 4 percent, which sounds worse.
llm: If you’re a consumer, you might think inflation is running high.
If you’re an economist or investor, you probably think it’s low.
The reason for this discrepancy lies in how the government measures the cost of living, and the problem has been getting worse over time.

human: The ouster of House Speaker Kevin McCarthy a few days ago demonstrated how powerful a small group of hard-right House Republicans have become and how deep their grievances run.
llm: The ouster of the speaker was a stunning reversal for one of Capitol Hill's most powerful figures, who just days ago seemed on track to be elected to an eighth term as House leader.

human: The original 2004 movie “Mean Girls” contained something unusual, both then and now: a main character who was home-schooled.
But not that kind of home-schooled.
llm: The original 2004 film was a surprise hit, grossing more than $129 million worldwide.
It featured Lohan as Cady Heron, a home-schooled teenager who moves to suburban Illinois from Africa with her family.
She falls in with a group of cool girls known as The Plastics — played by Rachel McAdams, Amanda Seyfried and Lacey Chabert — only to find that they are secretly vicious bullies.

human: Just weeks before Ecuador descended into chaos, with prison riots, two escaped criminal kingpins and the brief siege of a television station, the country’s top prosecutor launched a major operation aimed at rooting out narco-corruption at the highest levels of government.
llm: Just weeks before he was gunned down, Mr. Moncayo had been removed from his job by the country’s highest court after a lawsuit brought by his former boss, who accused him of abusing power in office.
The lawsuit was later withdrawn and Mr. Moncayo was reinstated.

human: Red-state legislatures are the incubator and the proving ground of many varieties of right-wing nutjobbery that go on to affect national policy, but most people give no thought to what happens in their chambers.

human: The intaglio — a stone engraved with an image — is a form of jewelry that goes back to ancient Mesopotamia.
“In the Greek and Roman galleries at the Met, there’s a study room that’s full of intaglios,” says the New York-based jewelry designer Jean Prounis.

For just over a year, her namesake brand, which often references ancient decorative arts, has been creating personalized intaglios in lapis, carnelian, onyx, jade or gold that can be set as rings or spinning pendants.

Once you’ve chosen which of the settings and stones to offer your giftee, Prounis will, she says, ask you or the betrothed a series of questions about the couple’s relationship before suggesting a design, which is then etched on the stone by a specialized intaglio carver.
Or she’ll present a menu of options — among them, palm trees, clasped hands and olive branches.
Prounis’s designs have also included pet portraits, initials and dates.
“It’s kind of like an anthropological study of what modern-day people want to inscribe in stone,” she says.
And for the newly engaged, an intaglio can also function as a wax seal: perfect for sending off invitations and thank-you notes.
llm: The intaglio — the design etched into a gemstone — is what gives cameos their three-dimensionality.
The motifs are usually classical and mythological in nature, but portraits of people have also been popular since Roman times.
Cameo carving was popularized by master gem cutters of ancient Greece and Rome who created intricate seal rings for wax correspondence and signet rings bearing family crests or other emblems.

Some historians claim that cameos were introduced to England during the reign of Edward the Confessor (1042–1066), while others say the style gained popularity much later when Queen Victoria wore them.
They reached the height of their popularity during the Victorian era, and have remained a classic jewelry choice ever since.
Read

human: Thomas J. Watson Jr. seemed, from a young age, to be destined for failure.

He barely gained his high school diploma after attending three different schools.
His father, Watson Sr., the head of IBM, was a domineering man who subjected his son to a classic combination of emotional distance and cruelty.
Watson Jr. responded by becoming a rebel and wastrel.

human: Last fall, California lawmakers passed a sweeping online children’s privacy law aimed at regulating how some of the most popular social media and video game platforms treat minors.

human: AT THE HOUSEWARES store John Derian Company in Manhattan’s East Village, things are almost never what they seem.

And a marbled cheese board, with a heart-shaped Camembert atop it, is sculpted entirely from earthenware.
“Everyone grabs for the cheese on that board,” says John Derian.
“Setting your table with these kinds of things is like setting a table in Alice in Wonderland.”
llm: AT THE HOUSEWARES SHOW in Chicago last month, one of the best-looking new products was a kitchen gadget called a “fresh keeper” — a plastic container that extends the life of produce by regulating the flow of oxygen and carbon dioxide.
It would have been nice to think that it was designed for people who shop often and eat fresh foods.
But I couldn’t help feeling that it was actually made for people who buy too much, let food spoil, and then throw it out.

human: Vietnam and New York, our worlds were far apart.
Camp for me meant refugee sites, ration lines; for Adam, summer and water sports.
After we met in college, he gave me my first bouquet.
I plucked flowers from his gift (and the college grounds) to create my own bouquet for him.
“You don’t rebundle a gift,” he said.
“Why waste money?”
I countered.
It took us 30 years as a couple to finally agree that both are true: A gift shouldn’t be re-gifted, but once given, a gift is no longer yours.
Now, we’ve moved on to new disagreements!
— Oanh Ngo Usadi
llm: Vietnam and New Zealand sign strategic partnership agreement

human: Shortly after midnight on Tuesday, 17,000 feet up in the Himalayas just south of India’s border with China, some slight shift started an avalanche.

llm: Shortly after midnight on July 17, a sudden rush of water swept through the town of Mocoa, Colombia.

The tragedy was exacerbated by inadequate infrastructure—Mocoa lacks an effective drainage system to cope with heavy rains—and underscored the vulnerability of mountain communities that live in the shadow of melting glaciers.

human: For 10 years, I’ve belonged to a walking group of 12 women.

The problem: A woman who coordinates the group with me recently added her best friend, with whom I had a falling-out several years ago.
She broached the idea of including her on the group chat on a day when I wasn’t checking my phone.
(She knows about our falling-out.)
I have not seen this other woman in years, and I have no interest in reconciling with her.
This group was my most cherished social outlet; now, I no longer want to participate.

llm: For 10 years, my wife and I have walked the same route in our neighborhood every morning.

We said yes because it was only one day, but now he comes with us every time we walk by his home.
He makes jokes about how he’s stalking us and even joked about peeking into our windows at night.
His comments make me uncomfortable and I don’t want to be rude.
What should I do?

human: In mid-December, just one day after Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas signed into law a radical new immigration bill, immigrant rights groups challenged it in court as ridiculously unconstitutional.
The groups felt they had no choice, but they did exactly what Texas was counting on, because the point of the law isn’t simply how outrageous it is; it’s about the fight it will cause.
llm: In mid-December, just weeks after Donald Trump won the presidency, Arizona Governor Doug Ducey took to Twitter to proclaim his commitment to “securing our border” and making sure “no one is above the law.”
The tweets were a clear swipe at then President Barack Obama, who had announced that he would not pursue deportation against undocumented immigrants who had no criminal records.
In response, Ducey called for the immediate deployment of 250 National Guard troops to the Mexican border—a move that would require federal authorization from the White House.

human: George Santos, the New York Republican congressman whose tapestry of lies and schemes made him a figure of national ridicule and the subject of a 23-count federal indictment, was expelled from the House on Friday after a decisive bipartisan vote by his peers.
llm: George Santos, the only politician in Portugal who has been convicted for corruption and who is currently being investigated by the Public Prosecutor’s Office for money laundering, has just been expelled from Parliament.
The vote was 134 to 95 (with one abstention), which means that he will lose his seat as an MP and that this will open up a vacancy in the Socialist Party.
This historic decision comes after the Constitutional Court declared that the suspension of Santos had been illegal and ordered him to be reinstated as an MP.
It also represents a victory for the Left Bloc.

human: “Dancing With Glass: The Piano Etudes” is titled a little misleadingly.

Really, the show is Glass with dancing.
llm: “Dancing With Glass: A Portrait in Sound” (Friday) Philip Glass is one of the few composers of his generation who has become a household name, but he remains an enigmatic figure.

This new film by Scott Hicks explores Mr. Glass’s music and artistic life through interviews with collaborators like the director Robert Wilson and choreographer Lucinda Childs as well as commentary from musicians and scholars.
The screening will be followed by a panel discussion featuring Mr. Glass; the composer Nico Muhly; the conductor Michael Riesman; and the soprano Lisa Bielawa, who also wrote the film score.
At 7 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street

human: When climate activists protesting the building of a huge church complex in a natural park in the South of France scaled the construction site, the nuns gave chase.

human: A long time ago I lay awake for hours, terrified that they would be my last ones on earth.

It was pounding so hard, so fast, so loud, I was certain it
and I couldn’t survive.

human: Good morning.
You make corn muffins with corn meal, which is dried ground corn.

You make tortillas and pupusas with masa harina, which is corn that’s been cooked and steeped in an alkaline solution (a process known as nixtamalization), then dried and ground.
A homemade tortilla is a revelation; a pupusa stuffed with cheese and grated yellow squash is paradise.

human: Growing up, all Yuni Matsumoto wanted was to fit in.

human: If we as a nation are reaching an increasingly critical juncture over the fate of labor, “The Mill” is a film that appears startlingly well-suited for the moment.

The dystopian thriller, directed by Sean King O’Grady, almost literally translates the idea of cog in a machine, following Joe (Lil Rel Howery), a middle manager within a major corporation called Mallard, as he mysteriously wakes up in an open-air prison and is forced to push a grist mill hundreds of times, 18 hours a day.
He doesn’t know how he got there, only that, as a neighboring prisoner who talks to him through a vent explains, you better keep working or get “terminated.”
llm: If we as a society are to continue on this path of automation, then we will need to rethink how we pay for things.
Income is only possible if there are jobs, and if those jobs are all automated then no one will have any income with which to purchase anything.
And we can’t just rely on the government to provide a basic income for everyone because that would bankrupt it (and there’s always going to be someone who tries to cheat the system).
So what do we do?
I think that we should start experimenting now with various forms of alternative economics like resource-based economy, gift economy, etc., and see if they can work before we run out of time.

human: There is something bigger than beer brewing at the Francis Kite Club, a new haunt in the East Village whose artists hold performances, shape its programming and debate politics from their barstools.
llm: There is something very odd about this article.
Is it really necessary to go into detail about the author's personal life?
And what does her decision to be a bartender have anything to do with the museum's policies, which she helped implement?
The article seems to imply that Ms. Raicovich was somehow forced out of her position at the Queens Museum because she chose to work as a bartender in her spare time.
But this is not the case, and it would be helpful if you could clarify the situation.

human: Matthew Perry, who died Saturday at 54, was one of the biggest TV stars of the past three decades thanks to his role on “Friends,” the blockbuster NBC sitcom that continues to be enormously popular in the streaming era.
llm: Matthew Perry, who was born in Williamstown, Massachusetts on August 19, 1969, is a Canadian-American actor and writer.
He is best known for his role as Chandler Bing on the sitcom Friends (1994–2004), for which he received an Emmy Award nomination in 2002.
In addition to starring in several feature films during the mid-1990s to early 2000s, including Fools Rush In (1997) and The Whole Nine Yards (2000).

human: Caity Weaver loves holiday music.
She also loves throwing parties.
A few years ago, she set a goal: Create the ideal holiday music playlist for the ideal holiday party.
Little did she know that it would become an obsession.

Throughout the year, she collects new holiday music, and each December finds her spending hours refining her playlist — adding, subtracting and rearranging songs in pursuit of party soundtrack perfection.
llm: Caity Weaver loves the holidays.
She also has a great sense of humor and an epic taste in music.
Check out her Spotify playlist, which she calls “The Best Christmas Album Ever.”
It’s funny, it’s eclectic, and it will help you throw one heck of a party.

human: An influential conservative group is using a questionnaire to test the ideology of potential recruits for the next Republican presidential administration — and the questions reveal the extent to which former President Donald J. Trump has transformed the conservative movement in his image.
llm: An influential conservative intellectual who has been critical of Donald J. Trump said on Monday that he had been offered a job in his administration and was considering it, a move that could help bridge a divide between Mr. Trump’s circle and some right-wing leaders.

human: A young lawyer named Wes Clark begins defending children at the Rutherford County juvenile court.
He quickly sees a troubling pattern: Kids are jailed for minor offenses, even when the law says they shouldn’t be.
But he can’t always persuade the juvenile judge to let them out.
llm: A young lawyer who is working with a team investigating the Rutherford County Juvenile Court said she was so disturbed by what she saw there that she questioned whether to continue.

human: Tieghan Gerard was busy lighting pumpkin spice-scented candles when I arrived at her sunlit studio this month.

After more than a year of negotiations with the representatives who guard her schedule and her image, she’d agreed to cook two recipes I’d chosen from the thousands on her immensely popular recipe site, Half Baked Harvest.
llm: Tieghan Gerard was the 21-year-old food blogger behind the popular site Half Baked Harvest.
When her cookbook came out in 2017, it became a best seller.
But soon after, she started getting angry messages from her fans: Hadn’t they seen those recipes before?

human: Laboratories in at least four states are investigating a mysterious respiratory illness in dogs that are presenting similar symptoms to kennel cough but can last much longer, and in some cases prove fatal, according to veterinarians.
llm: Laboratories in at least four states have confirmed the presence of canine influenza virus H3N2.

human: Strong winds and likely tornadoes destroyed several buildings in the Southeast.
llm: Strong winds and severe storms ripped through parts of Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia on Wednesday night, causing damage to homes and leaving thousands without power.

human: Progress toward closing the pay gap between men and women in New York City has stalled, even as there has been improvement nationally, according to a new study.
llm: Progress toward closing the pay gap between men and women in New York City has stalled since 2007, according to a report released on Wednesday by the city comptroller’s office.

human: The United States and Canadian governments went into high alert, four international bridges were closed and cross-border train travel came to a halt after a car exploded on the American side of a Niagara Falls bridge, upending travel plans and sowing fear on the busiest travel day of the year.
llm: The United States and Canada vowed to cooperate in an investigation into a fiery crash that killed two people and injured more than 30 others on Wednesday when a runaway freight train loaded with crude oil derailed near the Quebec border.

human: Weeks after mechanics working for Tesla in Sweden walked off their jobs in late October, members of other unions across the country and elsewhere in Scandinavia have joined the strike in sympathy by refusing to provide services to Tesla to pressure the automaker to sign a collective agreement with its Swedish workers.
llm: Weeks after mechanics at Tesla Inc.’s plant in California voted to unionize, the electric-car maker is now fighting a similar battle on the other side of the world.

human: Until the morning of Oct. 7, the town of Sderot in southern Israel was a parable of hope and success.

Less than a mile from the Gaza border, it emerged a few years after the 1948 Arab-Israeli war as a haven for Jewish refugees fleeing antisemitic persecution — from North Africa, Kurdish lands, Ethiopia and the former Soviet Union.
I am a second-generation Israeli; my parents found refuge in Israel from Iran.
llm: Until the morning of January 15, 2009, I never imagined that I would be in the midst of a rocket attack.
After all, the only thing I knew about these attacks is what I had read in the newspapers or seen on television news reports.
The fact that Hamas rockets were landing on Israeli cities every day was just another news item for me until this past Thursday when it became very real to me personally.

human: The conflict between Israel and Hamas is fast becoming a world war online.
llm: The conflict between Israel and the Palestinians has become a worldwide war of words.
And in that fight, it is easy to see who is winning: Hamas.

human: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.”

Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.”
And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own.
When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing.
Hand is here to chop it down.
llm: As Holly, the youngest Crain child in Netflix’s The Haunting of Hill House (now streaming), Paxton Singleton has a pivotal role: He not only plays a key part in the series’ present-day storyline but also serves as one of its many flashback narrators.

In EW’s exclusive first look at his audition tape for the series, above, Singleton’s take on Holly is chilling, capturing both the boy’s sweetness and his connection with the house that haunts his family.

human: For more than a decade, smartphone users everywhere have faced a major problem in how we communicate: the “green versus blue bubble” disparity.
llm: For more than a decade, the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) has been using data from the EPA’s ENERGY STAR Portfolio Manager® to assess energy and water performance in commercial buildings across the country.

To date, DOE has used this data to benchmark 23 types of building space, including offices, schools, hospitals, senior care facilities, hotels, retail stores, warehouses, supermarkets, restaurants, and others.
These spaces represent over 50% of all commercial floorspace nationwide.

human: Chinese regulators announced new restrictions Friday on online video games, which they said were aimed at tightening the management of the industry and protecting the country’s minors.
llm: Chinese regulators announced new rules for the country's fast-growing video game industry, including a limit of one hour per day for minors and a total ban on games after midnight.
The regulations, which come into effect in March, are part of an effort to curb gaming addiction among Chinese youth.
A growing number of parents and state media outlets have voiced concerns over the spread of gaming addiction, as China has become the world’s biggest market for interactive entertainment.

human: Abortion rights and marijuana legalization prevailed in Ohio.
Democrats held the governor’s mansion in Kentucky, took full control of the General Assembly in Virginia and won a Supreme Court election in Pennsylvania.
They were even competitive in Mississippi.
llm: Abortion rights and gun control are two of the most controversial issues in America.

On one side, there are those who believe that women should have a right to choose whether or not they want an abortion, while on the other side, people think that abortion is unconstitutional because it takes away the fetus’s life.
Another controversy is about gun control; some think guns should be restricted because they kill many people each year, but others believe that guns don’t kill people, people kill people.
These two issues were brought up by the two candidates for Virginia Governor: Ralph Northam (D) and Ed Gillespie (R).
During their debates, both candidates were asked if they support abortion and gun control.
However, only Ralph Northam was clear about his opinion on these issues, which

human: Americans have long been conditioned to believe that when they buy a cellphone, the next step is to pick a wireless plan from one of the big carriers: Verizon, AT&T or T-Mobile.
With their plans ranging from $60 to $200 a month for individuals and families, the price of a phone is soon eclipsed by the recurring service bills.
llm: Americans have long been willing to pay more for their cellphone plans than consumers in other countries, and that has helped subsidize the development of high-speed wireless networks.
But new research indicates that American consumers may finally be getting some relief.

human: The video, called “Let’s Get Ready to Bumble,” is a slick mash-up of President Biden’s verbal slip-ups and his stumbles set to a thumping 1990s dance track.
And when it was played on a big screen at Trump rallies late last year, it consistently drew laughs and jeers from the crowd.
llm: The video, called “Donald Trump’s Argument For America,” was posted on YouTube two weeks ago and has been viewed more than 3.8 million times since then.

It shows a series of images — Hillary Clinton looking tired; refugees swarming across borders; the black suspect in the killing of a San Diego police officer — overlaid with ominous music and a warning about Mrs. Clinton’s election: “If we don’t win this election, please be prepared for what you will see from Jan. 20, 2017 on.”

human: An article on Saturday about a man who was replaced as the local Santa Claus after sharing his views on the Israel-Hamas war at a public event misstated the Sag Harbor Chamber of Commerce’s description of the email requests it had received to “find a different Santa.”

llm: An article on Tuesday about a study of the effects of long-term solitary confinement misstated part of the name of the federal prison where the study was conducted.
It is the Federal Correctional Complex in Florence, Colo., not the Federal Correctional Institute.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked the full federal appeals court in Washington on Monday to consider whether a gag order in the criminal case in which he stands accused of plotting to overturn the 2020 election should be further narrowed or thrown out.
llm: Lawyers for former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort have asked the full D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals to review an order that would allow Special Counsel Robert Mueller's team to issue a gag order in their client's case.

human: Christopher M. Kise and Alina Habba, the two lawyers who joined Donald J. Trump at the defense table before he testified Monday at his civil fraud trial in New York, represent different aspects of what the former president looks for in a defender.
llm: Christopher M. Kise is a partner in our Atlanta office and focuses his practice on tax, corporate and international matters.

He was recognized by Georgia Trend magazine as one of its “40 Under 40” best and brightest Georgians for 2016, and he has been selected for inclusion in The Best Lawyers in America® 2017 for Corporate Law.

human: On Tuesday evening, I was drinking on the porch of my friend and neighbor Misha Shulman, the Israel-born rabbi of a progressive New York synagogue called the New Shul.

Of all the people he spoke to, he said, those most devastated were either people who had lost close friends or family, or young Jews “completely shattered by the response of their lefty friends in New York,” who were either justifying Hamas’s atrocities or celebrating them outright.
llm: On Tuesday evening, the 25th of March, I participated in a panel discussion on the topic “The Massacre in Israel and the Need for a Decent Left.”
The event was sponsored by Haymarket Books.
I’d like to share with you some of what I said that night.

human: Martti Ahtisaari, a dogged Finnish statesman whose many quests to end conflict took him from the deserts of Namibia to secret arms caches in remote Irish farmlands, earning him the Nobel Peace Prize, died on Monday in Helsinki, Finland.
He was 86.
llm: Martti Ahtisaari, a former Finnish president and diplomat who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2008 for his efforts to resolve international conflicts, died on Thursday.
He was 86.
His death was announced by the Crisis Management Initiative, an organization he founded after leaving office that specialized in conflict resolution and crisis management.
The group did not specify where Mr. Ahtisaari had died or give a cause of death.

human: “You Hitler at the Reichstag or Hitler in the bunker?”
llm: “You Hitler at all!”

human: Over the past two years, as Ishan Bhabha and his colleagues at the law firm Jenner & Block prepared briefs for the affirmative action case the Supreme Court ruled on last year, Mr. Bhabha had a realization: If higher education institutions like Harvard were the first target of litigation about diversity, equity and inclusion, America’s corporate boardrooms were probably next.
llm: Over the past few years, companies have made a big push to publicly embrace diversity and inclusion efforts—releasing annual reports on their progress, issuing strong statements in support of women’s equality, even participating in protests.
But some executives are starting to realize that these public displays might not be helping as much as they’d hoped.
In fact, it could actually be hurting.

human: A regular golf cart has no turn signals, no radio, no protection from the elements other than a thin roof and rain flaps.
Press the pedal to the floor and it can maybe — maybe — accelerate to 15 miles per hour.
llm: A regular golf cart for adults is typically not legal on the streets or highways of any state in the United States.
They are required to be licensed and insured if they will be driven on public roads.
The minimum requirements usually include having seat belts, turn signals, headlights, taillights, reflectors, mirrors, a parking brake and a windshield.

human: The start of the new year often brings lofty ambitions.
llm: The start of a new year is often when we take stock of our lives and think about what we want to change.
It can be difficult to figure out how to make positive changes, especially if you struggle with anxiety.
We all know that we should eat healthier, exercise more, quit smoking or stop drinking too much alcohol.
But it's hard to get motivated to actually do these things.
And then there are some resolutions that people make just because they feel like they have to (I'm thinking of you, gym membership salespeople).
So, if you find yourself feeling anxious about your New Year's resolutions, here are a few ideas to help you ease into 2018.

human: The former head of the Grammy Awards was sued on Wednesday by a woman who said he drugged and raped her in a New York hotel room in 2018.

In the document, she claims that the unnamed musician was invited to sing for Portnow during a 2016 event.
After her performance, she allegedly accepted an offer for a ride home from him but instead he drove her to his house and raped her.

human: On Aug. 23, I stood inside what was left of a burned shack on a hillside.
The air was heavy with smoke, but after hours of reporting I had given up covering my mouth and nose.
llm: On Aug. 23, 1945, the USS Indianapolis was torpedoed by a Japanese submarine.
About 800 of the 1,196 sailors and Marines on board survived the sinking but only 317 were pulled from the water alive.

The survivors spent four days in shark-infested waters, most covered in fuel oil, some with injuries, and all suffering varying degrees of dehydration before they were spotted by accident by a U.S. bomber on routine patrol.

human: Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota knows that many people, including powerful voices in his own party, think he should quit the Republican presidential primary, abandoning his quixotic bid so that momentum can gather behind a challenger to Donald J. Trump, and ultimately President Biden.

human: New York City officials put forward a plan on Tuesday to direct public money toward mixed-income housing projects in wealthier neighborhoods — a proposal aimed at addressing the affordable housing shortage and spurring development after a lucrative property tax exemption lapsed last year.
llm: New York City is planning a major overhaul of its affordable housing policy, aiming to build far more apartments for low- and moderate-income families while also requiring that some of those units be built in wealthy neighborhoods.
The changes are the most significant effort in decades to desegregate subsidized housing in New York.
They are the result of a long-running civil rights lawsuit accusing the city of concentrating public housing in high-poverty areas populated mostly by minorities.
The suit was brought by fair-housing advocates and civil rights groups who said that the segregation perpetuated inequality.

human: “Coppelia” is the last, exuberant gasp of 19th-century ballet Romanticism, that moment when the idea of the ballerina as a weightless, ethereal being, poised on the tips of her toes, became central to classical dance.
llm: “Coppelia” is the first ballet that Alexei Ratmansky, American Ballet Theater’s artist in residence and former artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, choreographed.
It was made for the Royal Winnipeg Ballet in 2004; his version has since been danced by companies around the world.
On Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, it had its American Ballet Theater premiere.

human: Plagiarism is perhaps the mildest academic sin, as well as the easiest to detect.
There are innumerable cases of more serious forms of misconduct — such as the falsification and fabrication of data — that have stained the reputations of universities all over the world.
If academia really wants to tackle the problem, it’s got to rethink the way it judges and rewards research — and tell good from bad.
llm: Plagiarism is perhaps the least of the problems that arise when a researcher fabricates data.

human: The closing night party at the annual conference of eXp Realty was — in the company’s own words — “epic.”
llm: The closing night of the 2019 Tribeca Film Festival, Saturday, May 4th, will feature an outdoor screening of the classic film Goodfellas.
The screening will be followed by a conversation with Martin Scorsese, Robert De Niro, Joe Pesci, Lorraine Bracco, Ray Liotta, and Paul Sorvino to celebrate the film’s 25th anniversary.

human: Eight years ago, just before the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump crowed about his invulnerability.
llm: Eight years ago, President Obama ordered the killing of Anwar al-Awlaki.
The U.S.-born cleric had been associated with Al Qaeda in Yemen and allegedly was involved in plots to attack Americans.
He had been placed on a kill list by the CIA, which monitored his whereabouts until he could be killed without collateral damage.
On September 30, 2011, drones hit Awlaki while he was traveling through northern Yemen; he died instantly.
Two weeks later, Awlaki’s 16-year old son, Abdulrahman, an American citizen, also was killed by drone fire while eating at an outdoor restaurant.

human: Hi busy bees!

human: Former Vice President Mike Pence, who spent four years dutifully serving President Donald J. Trump but refused to carry out Mr. Trump’s demand that he block the 2020 election results, ended his presidential bid on Saturday, with a final appeal for his party to return to conservative principles and resist the “siren song of populism.”
llm: Former Vice President Mike Pence announced today that he will not be running for president in the year 2024.
This is surprising, considering that Donald J. Trump has been president since January 19th, 2017 and won't even begin his first term until January 20th of this year.

human: Though only 9 at the time, May Pundak knew that when her father was often away in the early 1990s, he was involved in some kind of mission for Israel, one so secret that she could not breathe a word about it to friends at school.
llm: Though only 9 miles apart, the cities of Ramallah in the West Bank and Jerusalem in Israel are worlds away when it comes to their relationship with the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.
In Ramallah, younger activists see the current peace process as being stale, unrepresentative, and not moving fast enough.
The youthful population is pushing for more direct action to make change happen faster, while older generations continue to work within the framework of the existing system.
On the other hand, in Jerusalem, young people tend to be less interested in politics and have less confidence that there will ever be peace.
While both sides express an eagerness for peace, they differ greatly in how to achieve it.

human: The New York Times sued OpenAI and Microsoft for copyright infringement on Wednesday, opening a new front in the increasingly intense legal battle over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
llm: The New York Times has filed a lawsuit against the nonprofit research firm OpenAI, accusing it of copyright infringement for using large amounts of text from Times articles without permission to train its language software.
The suit was also brought against Microsoft, which is a major funder of OpenAI, and is based on 140 articles that appeared between 2017 and 2018.
In July, OpenAI released GPT-2, an algorithm trained to predict the next word in any English sentence by studying eight million web pages, including some from the Times.

The lawsuit says that “OpenAI’s conduct constitutes willful copyright infringement,” and asks the court to prevent the company from using the Times’ articles to train artificial intelligence systems in

human: The beginning of the story was strangely familiar, like the opening scene in a shopworn police procedural:
A woman runs screaming down a street in Oak Beach, a secluded gated community on Long Island’s South Shore, only to vanish, it seems, into thin air.
It was almost dawn on May 1, 2010.
Hours earlier, Shannan Gilbert traveled from New Jersey to see a man who had hired her as an escort from a Craigslist ad.
By the time the police arrived, she was gone.
They talked to the neighbors, the john and her driver and came up with nothing.
A few days later, they ordered a flyover of the area and, again, saw no sign of her.
Then they essentially threw up their hands.
She went into the ocean, they decided, either hysterical or on drugs.
llm: The beginning of this is a good read.
I didn't know there were 4 more victims after the first two (or three) women found, and that those last 2 were also prostitutes.
It seems like they have to find a link between the women other than prostitution or else it will be very hard to catch the killer.

human: President Biden and President Joko Widodo of Indonesia met at the White House on Monday to announce a new strategic partnership, but their differing views on the conflict in Gaza came into view when Mr. Joko asked for the United States to “do more” to stop the war.
llm: President Biden and his wife Jill are currently on a visit to Jakarta, where they were welcomed by President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.
The purpose of this visit is to strengthen the relationship between the two countries.
It is the first time that a US president has visited Indonesia since Lyndon Johnson in 1967.

human: Parents, schools and even attorneys general have increasingly been raising concerns about how TikTok may be hooking children to the app and serving them inappropriate content.
But some lawyers say bringing legal action against the company could be more difficult after TikTok quietly changed its U.S. terms of service this summer.
llm: Parents, schools and lawmakers are increasingly worried about the app’s popularity among kids and teens.
The concerns range from its potential for misuse by predators to questions about how it collects personal information.
TikTok is under scrutiny over allegations that it censors content critical of China's government.

human: Being a documentary subject can be a thankless kind of stardom, without much control over how your life story is told.

In “Subject,” Jennifer Tiexiera and Camilla Hall went back to five famous documentaries and asked their stars about their experiences: “Hoop Dreams,” “The Staircase,” “Capturing the Friedmans,” “The Square” and “The Wolfpack.”
llm: Being a documentary filmmaker means you have to be a little crazy.
It’s just the nature of the beast.
We’re all slightly off our rockers, and I think it’s because we know that no one is ever going to give us any money for what we do.

human: Within 24 hours of Taylor Swift’s surprise appearance at a Kansas City football game in September, Ashlee Hartley and her husband, Charlie Tighe, began gathering materials for their Halloween costumes.
llm: Within 24 hours, I had received a cease-and-desist letter from the NFL.
The league claimed that the photo was copyrighted material, that my use of it infringed on its rights, and that I was liable to pay damages for this infringement.

human: When the Nordiques left Quebec nearly 30 years ago, the hockey team’s departure fueled the kind of mythologizing and nostalgia familiar to fans of the Brooklyn Dodgers.
llm: When the Nordiques moved to Denver in 1995 and became the Colorado Avalanche, Quebecers lost not only their beloved hockey team but also an emblem of their province’s distinct identity.
The departure of the Nords left a wound that has never fully healed.

human: The French writer Marie NDiaye likes a mystery.

llm: The French writer, whose new novel is the latest to win the International Man Booker Prize, has a knack for evading questions.

human: Rishi Sunak, the prime minister of Britain, had one last appointment on Thursday evening after a busy couple of days hosting dozens of government leaders, tech executives and other experts at a summit on the dangers of artificial intelligence: a sit-down with Elon Musk.
llm: Rishi Sunak, the Conservative MP for Richmond in Yorkshire, is one of the few people outside the worlds of business or science to have heard Elon Musk talk about artificial intelligence (AI).

human: I’m planning a road trip this weekend along California’s coast, and I already know what I’ll be listening to for many hours in the car.

human: The word klaxon has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 14 in “He Was a Revolutionary at the Birth of a Nation.
Does Anyone Care?” by Alex Traub:
llm: The word klaxon was first used to describe a loud electric horn, but it is now used more generally for any loud horn.
The word comes from the French word klaxo which in turn came from the Greek word κλαξ (klax), meaning “bell.”
The French word originally referred to the sound of bells ringing.

human: A recent string of attacks across the Middle East has raised concerns that the war between Hamas and Israel is spreading, and might put pressure on other countries like Iran and the United States to get more involved.

human: Four top aides to Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III were informed last Tuesday that he had been hospitalized a day earlier but did not notify the White House until two days later, the Pentagon said on Monday.
