human: Gavin Newsom, the California governor, packed his bags and his ambition Monday and flew to Chinese provinces on a weeklong mission to negotiate climate agreements.
llm: Gavin Newsom, the former San Francisco mayor who is now running for governor of California, wants to use his state as a model for how nations can tackle climate change.

human: On Aug. 6, my wife, my two children and I arrived at the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal to board the MSC Meraviglia for a weeklong cruise that included a stop in the Bahamas.

I am a scientist in the United States on a work visa and awaiting my green card, so I followed my lawyer’s instructions and presented my Chinese passport and my “combo card” — an American document that grants immigrants in my situation permission both to work in the United States and to travel abroad.
But MSC Cruises refused to let me board, saying the card did not guarantee I would be readmitted to the country when the boat returned to Brooklyn.

I soon met two other would-be travelers in the same, er, boat: Fadia, a 79-year-old Egyptian grandmother set to board with 19 relatives and friends, and Nargis, a Bangladeshi woman ready to cruise with her husband.
After hours of pleading our case, even getting Fadia’s immigration lawyer to speak to staff by phone, we were all sent home.
MSC refunded me about $500 in fees and taxes, but I’m still owed about $2,300 for the cruise fare for my family of four.
Nargis and her husband have also not been reimbursed, nor have Fadia and her son (who stayed behind with her while the rest of the group sailed).
Can you help?
Heng, New Haven, Conn.
llm: On Aug. 6, passengers on Carnival's Ecstasy cruise ship were left stranded in the Bahamas after an engine fire caused the vessel to lose power.
The next day, a Carnival cruise ship departing from Port Canaveral ran into mechanical problems, which forced it to return to port early.
And most recently, a fire broke out aboard Royal Caribbean's Grandeur of the Seas on Monday while the ship was en route to Jamaica.
No injuries were reported.

human: When Sam Klemick was a teenager living in Miami, the neighborhood now known as the Design District was still a place of bars and music clubs.

llm: When Sam Klemick and his partner, Jesse James, founded the design show Collective in 2014, they had a simple mission: Make it fun.
“We wanted it to be something that we would want to go to,” Mr. Klemick said.

An autopsy revealed that she died from multiple stab wounds, said Sgt.
Robert Burns, a police spokesman.

llm: “My job is to win football games.

human: The major entertainment studios and the union representing tens of thousands of striking actors will return to the negotiating table on Tuesday, less than two weeks after talks were suspended because the sides remained far apart on significant issues.
llm: The major entertainment news of the week was the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) strike, which threatened to shut down the entire industry.
After negotiations broke down over a new contract between SAG and the Alliance of Motion Picture & Television Producers (AMPTP), actors began walking off the job on Monday.
The AMPTP is made up of major studios like 20th Century Fox, Paramount Pictures, Sony Pictures Entertainment, Universal Studios, Warner Bros., Walt Disney Co. and CBS Corp.
Although it seemed like a catastrophe at first, things are looking up for everyone involved.

human: When Americans look back and take stock of their most impressive first ladies, they rarely think of Rosalynn Carter.
llm: When Americans look at the role of a First Lady, we often think of the last few.
Michelle Obama, Laura Bush and Hillary Clinton have all been vocal advocates for different issues.
But it wasn't always that way.
In fact, before Hillary Clinton, there was Rosalynn Carter — who made her own waves as Jimmy Carter's wife in the White House.

human: The ballots should, according to the official instructions, be marked with a “yes” or a “no.”

So is a checkmark, for affirmative, but an “X” is considered too ambiguous by the authorities and does not count as a “no” vote.
llm: The ballots should, of course, be counted.
The reason for the delay is that the election was a cliffhanger and postal votes were being counted on Friday.
They will make up for about 15% of the total vote.

human: This house is about 10 minutes from the center of Tivoli, a Hudson Valley village with a bakery, an Irish-style pub and boutiques selling a number of things, including yarn and locally made housewares.
It is also about 10 minutes from the village of Red Hook, which has a diner in a vintage train car and a public high school.
llm: This house is currently listed for sale with an asking price of $1,675,000.
The house has 3 bedrooms and 2 baths and a total living area of 1,948 square feet.
It was built in 1900.

llm: Former President Donald Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski is defending his former boss, saying it's not his fault if Sen. Ted Cruz, R-Texas, didn't know about the rules governing the caucus system in Iowa.

human: Throughout much of the Western world’s history, the wealthiest have been viewed in their communities as a potentially harmful presence, and they have attempted to allay this sentiment by using their riches to support their societies in times of crises like plagues, famines and wars.
llm: Throughout much of my life, I have been a self-styled socialist.
However, in recent years, as I have witnessed the rise of the Occupy Wall Street movement and the 1% rhetoric, I have felt that the definition of what it means to be “the rich” has become too broad.

human: When was the last time you listened to Donald Trump for longer than 30 seconds?
Longer than a clip sailing by in a tweet or a TikTok or packaged on the evening news?
Lovers and haters alike seem filled to the brim with information about this man, unable to take in any more or alter their view of him.
llm: When was the last time you read a book by someone who is a professional writer?
That’s not an easy question to answer.
For me, it was probably the summer of 2016 when I read The Secret History, by Donna Tartt.
That was the last time I remember being truly captivated and enthralled by a novel.
Since then, I have mostly been reading non-fiction books that are either about politics or economics.

human: Traumatic brain injuries have left more than five million Americans permanently disabled.
They have trouble focusing on even simple tasks and often have to quit jobs or drop out of school.
llm: Traumatic brain injuries can leave people unable to move or speak.
But in a recent study, implanting five of these people with tiny sensors in their brains seemed to help them regain some control over their bodies.
The participants were paralyzed and unable to communicate verbally after suffering traumatic brain injuries or strokes.
Their injuries prevented messages from the brain from reaching the body, but the implanted sensors recorded signals coming from an area of the brain that controls movement.
These signals were decoded by a computer, which then relayed the message to electrodes placed on the skin.
This allowed the participants to respond to questions with “yes” or “no.”
The study’s authors say this is only the beginning for the technology.

human: It’s been two years since New York City became home to the nation’s first legally sanctioned supervised consumption program, where people can take illicit drugs like heroin, crack and methamphetamine under medical supervision.
By many accounts that program is thriving.
More than 1,000 potentially fatal overdoses have been reversed and many people who use the facilities have been connected to support services, including addiction treatment.
llm: It’s been two months since The New York Times published an article about the dangers of the anti-drug laws.
“The law was intended to prevent drug dealers from opening businesses that were used to funnel money for their illegal activities, but it has had far broader consequences,” says reporter Jan Hoffman.
“Clinics and treatment centers have closed or never opened because of fear of violating the law.”

human: Roberta Pereira has had a career-long goal to make the performing arts accessible for all.
llm: Roberta Pereira has been named the new director of the Jerome Robbins Dance Division and coordinator of the library's dance research collection.

llm: The staff members of the Real Estate News Exchange (RENX) have been following the recent turmoil in NAR, and its impacts on the real estate industry.

human: On Thursday, Pantone announced its 2024 color of the year: Peach Fuzz.

In other words, a pretty hardworking hue.
llm: On Thursday, Pantone revealed its annual Color of the Year.
The color is peach fuzz—the fine, short hair that grows on the cheeks and chin of a prepubescent boy or girl.

“This year we wanted to get back to basics,” says Leatrice Eiseman, executive director of the Pantone Color Institute, who announced the selection in front of a crowd of reporters at a press conference in Manhattan.
“There are so many colors out there, it’s easy to forget what makes them all possible.”

human: A few days before New Year’s Eve, an unfamiliar health insurance card for me arrived in the mail.

llm: A few days ago, I blogged about the latest Trump administration sabotage effort: the expansion of "short-term plans".

human: As New York City faced a worsening homelessness crisis in recent years, officials repeatedly sought to hide the reality on the ground, according to a city investigation released on Tuesday.
llm: As New York City officials have pushed to reduce the number of homeless people living in shelters, they have reclassified many with severe mental illnesses as “unsheltered” and moved them into a privately run cluster site that is not subject to city audits or inspections.

human: One performer is missing from the current Parisian run of Rébecca Chaillon’s “Carte Noire Named Desire,” an arresting show about the experiences of Black women in France.

llm: One performer is in critical condition after an audience member attacked the cast during a performance of “Black Angels Over Tuskegee,” a play about black women and their experiences with race.
The play was being performed at St. Catherine University in Minnesota when one patron began attacking cast members onstage with pepper spray.

human: Among the bold claims in the motion filed last week by former President Donald J. Trump seeking to dismiss the federal indictment accusing him of conspiring to undermine the 2020 election, there was a significant concession.
The key Supreme Court precedent the motion relied on for claiming “absolute immunity” from criminal prosecution, his lawyers acknowledged, did not address criminal prosecutions.
llm: Among the boldest claims in President Trump’s assertion of immunity from investigation is his argument that, as president, he could not be prosecuted for murder.
The claim has been called “absurd” by a leading legal scholar and is not supported by legal precedent.
Yet it may be one of the few positions that Mr. Trump has advanced that is consistent with the views of the Supreme Court.
In 1982, the court ruled that a vice president who had shot someone was entitled to immunity from criminal prosecution until he left office.

But the court also said in other cases that an official may be prosecuted after leaving office and that lower-ranking executive branch officials can be investigated and prosecuted while still in office.

human: The Justice Department said on Wednesday that it had charged four Russian soldiers with torturing an American living in the war-ravaged region of Kherson in Ukraine, using a war crimes statute for the first time since it was enacted nearly three decades ago.
llm: The Justice Department on Tuesday charged four Russian military intelligence officers with conspiracy, computer hacking and financial crimes in an indictment that detailed a decade-long doping scheme intended to help athletes win medals at the Olympics and other global competitions.

human: He left politics for a talk show and paved the way for reality television.
llm: He left politics and went on to become a TV talk show host.
He was very successful in this endeavor, so much so that he became known as the “titan of trash.”

This article tells about Jerry Springer’s life before becoming a talk show host.

human: Archaeologists excavating parts of the ancient city of Pompeii made public new discoveries on Friday that provide a grim glimpse into the bleak existence of enslaved people two millenniums ago, including the existence of a “bakery-prison.”
llm: Archaeologists excavating parts of ancient Pompeii have found that people there lived in squalid conditions, with poor sanitation and a low-class diet.
In other words, life was pretty bad for those on the bottom rung.

human: Dianne Feinstein had several lifetimes’ worth of accomplishments by the time she died on Thursday at 90.
She was pivotal in crafting a decade-long bipartisan assault weapons ban.
She helped lead the congressional response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and questioned the Central Intelligence Agency for its use of torture.
As mayor of San Francisco, she led her hometown through years of tumult.
llm: Dianne Feinstein had a successful career before she was elected to the Senate.
As mayor of San Francisco, she handled crises ranging from a mass shooting at City Hall to an AIDS epidemic to the 1989 earthquake that devastated parts of Northern California.
But it was her service in the Senate that established her as a trailblazer and role model for women in office — particularly those who have followed her lead and run for office in California.

human: There was plenty of news this week for the late night hosts to riff on, including the fourth Republican presidential primary debate and Time magazine naming its person of the year: Taylor Swift.
Here’s what the hosts had to say.
llm: There was plenty of news to make fun of this week, and Seth Meyers, Jimmy Kimmel, Jimmy Fallon, James Corden and Conan O'Brien took full advantage.
The biggest stories: the Senate health care bill, Donald Trump Jr.'s emails and a woman giving birth in her car at Chick-fil-A.

And then there were the more obscure but still hilarious stories: a new type of cucumber, an old man who stole an ambulance, and a man who got caught trying to steal some beer by putting it down his pants.

human: “Maestro,” Bradley Cooper’s intimate portrait of Leonard Bernstein, takes flight with a terrific whoosh of exuberance.
The young Bernstein (played by Cooper) has just gotten the phone call that will change his life.
He’s been asked to step in for an ailing guest conductor and lead the New York Philharmonic; it will be his conducting debut.
Overjoyed, Lenny, as he’s often called, jumps up, throws open a curtain and then sprints out of his apartment to race, bathrobe flapping, into his dazzling, very public future as an American genius.
llm: “Maestro,” Bradley Cooper’s new movie about the life of composer-conductor Leonard Bernstein, is not a biopic.
It doesn’t try to cover all of its subject’s life or career in any detail.
Instead, it focuses on one period of his life — from 1958 to 1967, when he was working on “West Side Story” — and shows us how that work both reflected and influenced his personal life at the time.

human: It was May 27, 1937, the opening day for a stunning new suspension bridge across a gap in the California coastline known as the Golden Gate.
Before cars were allowed on the crossing, an estimated 200,000 people celebrated between the bridge’s four-foot-high rails, more than 200 feet above the water.
llm: It was May 2013, and the bridge had been closed for about an hour when a California Highway Patrol officer spotted a man in his mid-50s with a leather backpack climbing over the railing.
The man ignored orders to stop, and once he reached the other side of the rail, he dropped his bag and jumped.

human: An eccentric tech billionaire invites a slew of notables to a private retreat, where a detective must solve a mysterious death.

llm: An eccentric tech billionaire and a hard-boiled detective team up to investigate a mysterious death in this new series by the bestselling author of The Long Earth and The Long War.

human: Henry A. Kissinger’s decision to authorize the secret carpet bombing of Cambodia, his efforts to negotiate the American exit from the Vietnam War and his role in the U.S. rapprochement with China have rippled through Southeast Asia in the decades since.
llm: Henry A. Kissinger’s legacy still ripples through Vietnam and Cambodia, where his policies helped prolong the war in both countries for years.
Read more…

human: For nearly a decade, the sensational killing of a prominent Florida law professor in 2014 centered on a single, sordid question: Did his ex-wife’s family, motivated by an ugly custody dispute, hire hit men to murder him?
llm: For nearly a year, Florida dentist Kelly Gillespie planned to have her former law professor and his wife murdered.

human: The massive waves that pounded California’s coast last week washed ashore trash, driftwood and something unexpected: a very old bomb, rusted over and covered with debris.
llm: The massive waves and storms that have been slamming into the Pacific coast of the United States lately may be a great boon to surfers, but they are also washing up all sorts of weird things on beaches.

human: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina ended his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination this week having failed to make good on his early promise as a candidate who could broaden the party coalition in a general election.

And while he could still have a long career ahead of him in Republican politics, his failure to connect with the primary electorate ought to trouble those pining for a more diverse and capacious G.O.P.
llm: Senator Tim Scott (R-SC) is a rising star in the GOP, and has been tapped to deliver the Republican response to President Obama's State of the Union Address on Tuesday.
But last year he was criticized for his role in a failed bill that would have extended unemployment benefits.
This piece explores why this legislation never made it out of Congress.

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain survived a major threat to his leadership on Tuesday, advancing his flagship immigration policy over the objections of hard-right factions in his Conservative Party.

llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak won a key vote on Tuesday, but the battle over his plans for Rwanda is not over.
The House of Commons voted 307 to 290 in favor of Mr. Sunak’s plan to leave the European Union at the end of this month and negotiate a free trade agreement with Rwanda by the end of 2021.

human: Of the many strengths of “Southern/Modern,” a daring and revisionist show about the American South at the Georgia Museum of Art in Athens, the one that follows you out to your car is the alternate history of modern art it proposes.
llm: Of the many things to admire in this exhibition, one is its refusal to limit the scope of Southern art to a handful of famous names.
It includes several artists who are little known even among aficionados of regional culture, such as Paul Ninas and Harold Rittenberry.

human: There is no word for art in the Lakota language.

But the power of art, in every facet of life, has drawn a boisterous group of moccasin beaders, painters, regalia artists and producers of Native hip-hop down a two-lane road that undulates through the tawny hills of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, eight miles from the nearest intersection.
llm: There is no word in Lakota for art.
In English we tend to think of art as a thing—a painting or sculpture or installation—but that’s not how it was traditionally conceived by many indigenous cultures.
It wasn’t something you could buy or sell; it was part of life itself, an essential element of existence like food or air.
You couldn’t separate it from everyday living.

human: Each year, more than 6.6 million people worldwide die from strokes, and researchers caution that the incidence is increasing, especially in young and middle-aged people and in low- and middle-income countries.
In a report published last week, researchers predicted that stroke deaths would increase by about 50 percent, reaching 9.7 million deaths annually in 2050.
llm: Each year, more than 795,000 people in the United States have a stroke.
About 610,000 of these are first or new strokes; 185,000 are recurrent attacks.
Stroke kills about 140,000 Americans each year—that’s 1 out of every 20 deaths.
On average, someone dies of stroke every 4 minutes.
Every year, more than 750,000 people suffer from strokes.
That means one person is having a stroke right now as you read this page.
It can happen to anyone at any time and anywhere.
Stroke risk increases with age, but it also affects younger adults and children.

What did you think about when you heard it?
What did you feel?
llm: Have you ever wondered why some people seem to be so nostalgic about their past?
Why they seem to be attached to their past and can't let it go?

human: The lights dimmed and a Ferris wheel designed by Jean-Michel Basquiat began turning in time to “Tutu,” by Miles Davis.
llm: The lights dimmed, but he didn't want to move.
He felt safe in the darkness of this room.
The only sound was a ticking clock on the wall.
It was almost hypnotic.
And then, all of a sudden, the door opened.
A nurse walked into the room and turned on the light.

human: Midway through Stevie Nicks’s concert at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night, the musician told the audience that she had a “surprise,” prompting speculation among audience members about a potential unexpected guest: Could it be Lindsey Buckingham?
llm: Midway through Stevie Nicks' first solo tour in 35 years, she talks about her new album, 24 Karat Gold — Songs From the Vault, why she hates social media and what it's like to be immortalized as a Barbie doll.

human: During an era of intense politicization of education, there has been rare bipartisan consensus on one issue: the need to overhaul how children learn to read.
llm: During an era in which some schools are still struggling to provide reading instruction that is based on the science of reading, the International Dyslexia Association (IDA) and its partners are pleased to announce a new white paper titled What to Know About the Science of Reading: A Primer for Teachers.

human: Halyna Vynokur, a clerk in a hardware store in Kyiv, was shouldering a firearm for the first time.

llm: Halyna Vynokur, a 28-year-old Ukrainian woman with an athletic build and an ample smile, was not planning to go to war.

That day arrived last fall when President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine announced he would enact legislation allowing women to serve in combat positions — and called on them to join up….

human: A military judge at Guantánamo Bay on Monday scheduled a Jan. 15 plea hearing for two Malaysian prisoners who are accused of committing war crimes as accessories to deadly terrorist attacks in Indonesia two decades ago.

human: Three years after Bayer agreed to pay $10 billion to settle claims that its weedkiller, Roundup, caused cancer, juries continue to award plaintiffs in additional cases billions of dollars in damages, even as the German drug and chemicals giant insists it will continue its fight in court.
llm: Three years after the deal was signed to buy Monsanto, Bayer is still dealing with legal fallout from its acquired company's controversial weed killer.

human: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is by a member of the American literary canon, Henry David Thoreau, from a lecture that he gave in 1851 called “Walking,” which was published posthumously in 1862 in The Atlantic.
“Walking” is cut from the same cloth as “Walden,” a pillar of transcendentalism with which more people may be familiar.
Civilization vs. wildness; the progress and growth of humanity vs. the pastoral and its preservation; individual freedom vs. slavery and women’s lack of suffrage.
All profound topics, best mulled over during a long “saunter,” as Thoreau calls his walks through nature at the beginning of this lecture.
llm: ACROSTIC — Today’s acrostics are a far cry from the word puzzles that originated in ancient Greece.
There, acrostics were poems or …

human: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny has been moved to a remote Arctic prison and “is doing well,” his spokeswoman said on Monday, ending a 20-day mystery over his whereabouts that had many supporters fearing the worst.
llm: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny has been found in a remote prison colony in the Far North of Russia after an unexplained absence from his jail cell for several days raised concerns about his safety among supporters and family members.

human: When you’re renovating a kitchen, it’s easy to get swept up in choosing cabinets, counters and appliances.
But there’s another element that matters just as much: lighting.
llm: When you’re renovating your kitchen, you should remember that light is crucial.
You will need to have an expert to install light fixtures and bulbs so that they can illuminate the entire room.
You don’t want it to be dark in your kitchen, especially when you’re cooking.

human: On May 20, 1964, on a hilltop in New Jersey, an unlikely little structure called the Holmdel Horn revealed telltale signs of the Big Bang, and the birth of the universe we live in.
The Horn has been much in the news this fall, as it survived a threat of demolition.
llm: On May 20, 1965, a group of friends gathered in an art gallery on Manhattan's Upper East Side.
It was a typical spring day in New York City: warm and breezy.
Inside, however, the atmosphere was charged with excitement.
The crowd was there for the opening of the Andre Emmerich Gallery, which would soon become one of the most important venues in America for showing contemporary art.
And they were eager to see what its first show had to offer.

human: Welcome to our first Trump on Trial newsletter of 2024, a year that’s almost certain to put American democracy to the test.
llm: Welcome to our newest members of the club.
They are all looking forward to meeting you at the next event!

human: Elon Musk’s SpaceX launched its Starship rocket from the coast of South Texas just after 7 a.m. Central time on Saturday, a mammoth vehicle that could alter the future of space transportation and help NASA return astronauts to the moon.
llm: Elon Musk’s SpaceX is developing a stainless steel rocket ship, which the company calls Starship.
The new vehicle will be fully reusable and designed to take humans into deep space — and eventually to Mars.

human: These days, real estate imagery is often defined by staged hotel-lobby-style furniture and generic artwork, dramatic drone shots on unsettlingly perfect sunny days and a lack of human presence — almost never do you see any people or evidence that these homes have been lived in.
llm: These days, real estate is a matter of buying and selling.
But for 40 years it was also a matter of living for Lee Friedlander, who has photographed buildings, rooms and people in their environments all over America.
A new book, "Lee Friedlander: The Little Screens," with an introduction by Walker Evans (Fraenkel Gallery, $65), reproduces 173 of these images.

human: President Biden said on Tuesday that he was “outraged and deeply saddened” by a devastating blast that struck a hospital in Gaza City just hours before he left Washington for a wartime trip to Israel.
llm: President Biden said he was “outraged” by the deadly blast that killed three Israeli soldiers and wounded one on Thursday, as he began his first visit to Israel since taking office.
Mr. Biden said he had just met with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah when he heard of the attack.
He said that the United States condemned it in the strongest terms and held Hamas responsible for the violence.

The Obama administration has worked hard to keep its distance from Israel during this conflict, but Mr. Biden’s visit is being seen here as an attempt to demonstrate Washington’s solidarity with the Jewish state.
New York Times crossword puzzle constructor David Kwong reveals some of the secrets behind how these puzzles are created.

human: About 60 hardcore fans of the National Football League piled into the party space at Der Player, a fancy eatery, on a chilly evening in Hamburg, Germany, last month.

They wore team jerseys and hats as they sipped Pilsner from glass mugs.
Whenever the Broncos scored, they stood and shouted, “Touchdown!”

human: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies.
“Fear of Flying,” a book so sexually frank that you may have found it hidden in your mother’s underwear drawer, broke new ground in the explicitness of writing by and for women.
Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire.
She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.
llm: Fifty years ago, the publication of “Fear of Flying” caused a literary sensation and helped to launch the sexual revolution.
The author Erica Jong said she wrote the novel because she couldn’t find one that spoke honestly about female desire.
Her heroine was Isadora Wing, a poet who had a lust for life and sex (and her analyst).
Ms. Jong’s frankness made her an overnight feminist celebrity.
But today, many women say they can’t relate to her dream of freedom through sex.
For them, fear of harassment has replaced the fear of flying.

human: Oleg Protopopov, who, with his wife, Ludmila Belousova, revolutionized pairs figure skating in the 1960s with a balletic style, and who twice won Olympic gold medals with her for the Soviet Union before defecting to the West, died on Oct. 31 in Interlaken, Switzerland.
He was 91.
llm: Oleg Protopopov, who, with his wife Lyudmila Belousova, dominated pairs figure skating in the early 1960s and were the first Soviet gold medalists in the sport at the Olympics, died on Wednesday in Moscow.

human: THEY CALL IT the Island of the Apocalypse, for it was here on Patmos, in the southeastern corner of what’s today Greece, that John the Apostle foretold the end of the world — or at least the version recorded in the Bible’s Book of Revelation.

John had been exiled in A.D. 95 to this speck of land not far from where the Aegean meets the Mediterranean by the Romans, who weren’t only threatened by the rising influence of Christianity but believed it to be a cult.

The Byzantine Empire nonetheless took hold, and with it Greek Orthodoxy — and then, in 1088, rose the monastery dedicated to St. John, a fortified structure of marble and native andesite (a volcanic rock), built on one of the highest points on Patmos, that would forever change the island’s fortunes.
llm: THEY CALL IT “the house of the seven colors.”
It’s an 18th-century mansion that has been abandoned for decades on the Greek island of Patmos.
But this week, its restoration is being celebrated as part of a wider effort to revive the old town of Chora — and one of the most beautiful villages in the Dodecanese islands.

human: Like exercise, flossing and college, travel has long been held up as an incontrovertible good — an essential part of the modern human experience.

llm: Like exercise, flossing your teeth and eating vegetables, airplane mode is a good thing that we all know we should do but don’t always get around to.

human: Scientists in Japan have identified a virus that selectively kills males — and it happens to be inheritable, creating generation upon generation of all females.
llm: Scientists in Japan have discovered a virus that kills male insects but leaves females unscathed, they reported yesterday.
They say it could potentially be used as a pesticide to control agricultural pests.

The virus was found by Masayoshi Fujii and his colleagues at the University of Tokyo after studying the eggs of the brown planthopper, a rice pest that has caused serious crop damage throughout Asia for many years.
Their experiments revealed that when viruses infect the eggs of this insect, only males are killed.
This suggests that the virus is able to distinguish between the sexes and attack males only.
When the researchers injected the virus into adult female brown planthoppers, all the offspring were male.
And when the virus was given to pregnant females, all their

human: I think quite a lot about persuasion.

Where does one aim one’s efforts for maximum effect?
At the head, or at the heart?
llm: I think quite a few of us in Ukraine are not so much looking for aid as we are looking for an end to the war.
We want to stop being afraid that our homes and loved ones will be blown up by rockets from Russia.
We want to go back to work, to see our children safe at school.
We want peace.
And we know that only America can help bring this about.
I hope it does.

human: My father-in-law hides his drinking and denies it, but when we visit, we see him sneak out to the car and drink vodka from the trunk many times a day.
We live close by and see my in-laws quite often; hence we also see him drinking frequently, even though my husband has tried hard to get him to stop.
llm: My father-in-law hides his alcoholism from my mother-in-law, who is a wonderful person and has no idea what he's up to when she's not around.
He's gotten away with this for years because of the code of silence in the law enforcement community.
(This isn't to say that all cops are drunks or that all drunks are cops; it just means they look out for each other.)
Now that I know about this incident, how do I address it with my wife?
She'll be upset with me for betraying her father's trust, but she'll also want to know what happened.
If I tell her, she may try to use this information to get back at him, which I don't think would help

Soon after the novel opens, a mysterious virus appears that will cause everyone in the world to question his or her own mortality.

human: As we head into COP28, the annual global meeting on climate change underway in Dubai, there are two dominating schools of thought, both of which are wrong.

The other says we’re all going to be fine because we already have everything we need to solve climate change.
llm: As we head into the new year, the global economy is in a state of flux.
And with that uncertainty comes anxiety.
The markets are volatile and unpredictable.
Technology continues to disrupt businesses and jobs alike.
And geopolitics seems more complex than ever.
So how should investors think about these challenges?
What should they focus on when it comes to their portfolios?

human: America’s greenhouse gas emissions fell 1.9 percent in 2023, in large part because the burning of coal to produce electricity plummeted to its lowest level in half a century, according to estimates published on Wednesday by the Rhodium Group, a nonpartisan research firm.

human: As the number of people killed in Gaza has exceeded 14,000, according to Gazan health officials, Israel faces worldwide condemnation for its offensive, which was paused last week.

llm: As the number of Palestinian dead continues to mount, calls for a cease-fire are getting louder.
Much of the world is urging Israel to show restraint and do more to avoid civilian casualties.
But from Israel's perspective, even if it pulled out of Gaza tomorrow, it would still have a big problem on its hands.
And that's because Israel effectively controls Gaza's borders, its airspace and its coastline.
It alone decides what and who gets in and out.
The people there are dependent on Israel for their water, electricity and telecommunications.

human: On Nov. 8, 1971, Led Zeppelin released its iconic fourth studio album, which was untitled but is widely known as “Led Zeppelin IV.”

It features the band’s major hit “Stairway to Heaven,” and the wordless cover shows the framed image of a bearded, older man with a large bundle of sticks on his back against the backdrop of a decaying wall.
llm: On Nov. 8, 1969, Led Zeppelin released their fourth studio album, commonly referred to as “Led Zeppelin IV.”
The record is one of the best-selling albums in history and contains some of the band's most well-known songs, including “Stairway to Heaven,” “Black Dog” and “Rock and Roll.”
But the album doesn’t have a title or even the band’s name printed on its cover; instead it features an image of what appears to be an old man carrying a bundle of sticks.

human: This is an addendum to a series about Americans moving away from religion.
Read part one, part two, part three, part four and part five.
llm: This is an interesting article, but it doesn't surprise me.
I have noticed that many of the young people who are attracted to Christianity these days seem to be doing so because they want to join a club, and churches are often happy to provide that.
It seems like this has been going on for decades now.
And it's not just among Evangelicals.
The Catholic Church in America has been trying hard to appeal to the youth culture for some time as well (think LifeTeen).

I suppose this is good in some ways, but it makes me wonder if there will be any Christians left when all those kids grow up and find out that Christianity isn't really about joining a club after all.

human: It’s the season of parties, gifts and lots and lots of food.

human: Oct. 7 was Israel’s Sept. 11.

I fear that analogy carries so much more truth than the people making it intend.
llm: Oct. 7 was a bad day for Israel in Gaza.
Israeli special forces carried out a raid there, which went awry and left one Israeli officer and seven Palestinian militants dead.
The militant group Hamas, which controls Gaza, quickly stepped up rocket attacks on Israel, firing more than 400 projectiles at civilian targets.
One hit an apartment building in Ashkelon, killing a Palestinian laborer from the occupied West Bank who had been staying there.

Most of the rockets were intercepted by Israel’s Iron Dome anti-missile system or fell into empty areas, but several landed near Gaza border communities, forcing their residents to spend hours in bomb shelters.

In a report issued last week, the GAO-appointed investigator concluded that DOD had violated both TSCA and its implementing regulations when it withheld information on hazardous substance releases from military bases under the guise of national security.
The investigator further recommended that EPA require DOD to re-file all past submissions under the Emergency Planning and Community

human: As a child of mixed-race heritage, I often found that my hair was a source of tension between my mother and me.

llm: As a child, I was often at odds with my mother over how to wear my hair.

human: A streak of unexpectedly good news on inflation has continued in Britain, as the annual rate of price increases dropped to its lowest level in more than two years.
llm: A streak of bad economic data out of Britain, culminating with an unexpected slowdown in inflation, has raised the possibility that the Bank of England will be forced to ease monetary policy further than planned.
The Office for National Statistics said Tuesday that consumer prices rose 0.6% on the month and were up 3.9% from a year earlier, lowering the annual rate to its lowest level since November 2010.
Economists had expected the rate to hold steady at October's 4.5%.
Core inflation--which excludes food and energy prices--was unchanged at 2.7%.
The pound fell to $1.5839 after the release of the figures.

human: The Biden administration has proposed to ban all uses of trichloroethylene, an industrial solvent used in glues, other adhesives, spot removers and metal cleaners, saying exposure to even small amounts can cause cancer, damage to the central nervous system and other health effects.
llm: The Biden administration moved on Tuesday to ban the use of methylene chloride, a chemical that has been linked to cancer and is used in paint strippers.
The Environmental Protection Agency sent its proposed rule banning methylene chloride to the White House for review, according to an agency document obtained by Bloomberg News.
If approved as expected, the proposal would be published in the Federal Register and open for public comment.
It would take effect after a public hearing scheduled for January 2017.

human: The Lake City Army Ammunition Plant, built during World War II, has long been operated for the federal government by private contractors.
Over the past decade, a New York Times investigation found, the site has increasingly produced rounds for the commercial market as military demand has diminished.
llm: The Lake City Army Ammunition Plant has been manufacturing small arms ammo for decades.
It was first opened in 1941 to support World War II efforts, and has continued to produce various types of ammunition ever since.
The plant, located near Independence, Missouri, produces more than one billion rounds of small caliber ammunition each year.
We recently had a chance to tour the facility, where we learned about how the plant continues to innovate, even after all these years.
Here are four takeaways from our visit.

llm: A Confederate monument was taken down on Monday night in a public park in Gainesville, Fla.
The statue had stood since 1904 and depicted a soldier carrying a rifle.
In 2015, the City Commission voted to remove it.
Alachua County sheriff’s deputies removed the statue before dawn on Monday from its pedestal in the Bo Diddley Community Plaza, which is named for the blues musician who grew up in Gainesville.
A video of the removal showed the officers working with jackhammers, drills and torches to dislodge the bronze statue, which weighed about 135 pounds, from its base.
The statue will be stored until officials decide what to do with it.

llm: Doctors and patients have long known about the sexual side effects of antidepressant drugs.
Now new research has quantified the problem, showing that as many as three-quarters of men taking the drugs experience some degree of sexual difficulty.

human: Near the beginning of Todd Haynes’s new film, “May December,” there’s a moment that has become the subject of fascination.
Julianne Moore’s Gracie Atherton-Yoo is preparing for a barbecue.
She tells her teenage twins to be careful as they head to the rooftop with friends, and then she goes to the fridge.
The music swells.
A look of fear crosses her face: “I don’t think we have enough hot dogs.”
llm: Near the beginning of “The Other Woman,” Cameron Diaz, as Carly, a successful lawyer living in New York City with her hedge-fund manager boyfriend, Mark (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau), is at work when she receives a phone call from him.
She’s been invited to dinner by his brother and his wife; would she like to join them?
Sure, she says, happy to be included.
But then she pauses.
“I can’t cook,” she tells Mark.
“But I could buy some cupcakes.”

human: I’ve moved back to the United States twice since my birth.
Once as a child, after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Then again for graduate school.
I’d had the privilege of a youth — adolescence and young adulthood — in countries where being Palestinian was fairly common.
The identity could be heavy, but it wasn’t a contested one.
I hadn’t had to learn the respectability politics of being a Palestinian adult.
I learned quickly.
llm: I’ve moved back to New York City after 4 years in the Middle East, and am now a fellow at the Century Foundation.
I’ll be blogging here about my work there on US policy toward Israel/Palestine as well as other topics that interest me such as foreign policy, international relations, human rights, and more.

llm: Welcome to The 100th Edition of the Carnival of Genealogy: Our Ancestors’ Favorite Pastimes.
This edition is dedicated to my mom, who would have been celebrating her birthday today had she not passed away on April 29th.
She loved playing games and this would have been a great edition for her to read!
My mother loved board games and card games, especially Bridge.
I remember her sitting at our kitchen table in the evenings playing cards with friends and neighbors.
I also remember her teaching me how to play Canasta when I was young… what a challenge that must have been for her!
I think that’s why we both ended up being Bridge players later in life; it’s much easier to teach someone to play Bridge than Canasta

human: Mesoamerican archaeologists know it as Monument 9: a 2,600-year-old carving in stone of a jaguar’s gaping face, roughly five feet wide and tall and weighing one ton.

Nearly 60 years ago the relic was looted from the ruins of Chalcatzingo, an Olmec site south of modern-day Mexico City, and smuggled into the United States, where it disappeared into a network of private collections.
llm: Mesoamerican archaeologists know all about the painstakingly slow process of reconstructing ancient sites and cultures from fragments.
It’s a painstaking process that can take years or even decades to complete, often with only a few tantalizing clues as to what things looked like when they were new.

human: The thieves who broke into a Glaswegian museum in 1989 kept the heist fairly simple.
llm: The thieves who stole a painting from the Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum in Glasgow, Scotland, more than three decades ago might have thought they were getting away with an easy heist.
The painting, which depicts a Dutch landscape, was small enough to fit into a suitcase.
It wasn’t protected by any alarms or motion detectors, either.
But after police officers recovered the artwork from a Scottish home on Tuesday, the theft didn’t seem so simple anymore.

human: Days before the Iowa caucuses, former President Donald J. Trump is appearing twice in court this week — on Tuesday in Washington and Thursday in New York.
llm: Days before the second presidential debate, Donald J. Trump was holding court at his golf club in Bedminster, N.J., when a reporter asked him to defend his recent claims that the United States military was “a disaster.”
The Republican nominee waved away the question, arguing that he was only saying what others had said first.
“Well, I just heard today for instance that we are spending $6 trillion in the Middle East,” Mr. Trump told the reporters.
“Whether it is four or five, but it’s over there somewhere.
We have nothing.
Wounded warriors all over the place.
Nothing.”

human: Personal reflections, not grand statements, filled my most memorable albums of 2023.
It was a year when many of the best songs came from looking inward: at tricky relationships, at memories, at individual hopes and fears.
Yet in the music, introspection led to exploration: expanding and toying with sonic possibilities, enjoying the way every note is now an infinitely flexible digital choice.
For me, there was no overwhelming, year-defining album; this list could just as well be alphabetical.
Instead, 2023 was a year of artists going in decidedly individual (and group) directions to grapple with their own questions, risks and rewards.
llm: Personal reflections, not so much on the year in music (I don't really feel like I can speak to that), but on my listening habits and how they changed this year.
The biggest change is that, for the first time ever, I have no record player in my house.
For years now I've been a vinyl-first kinda guy, only buying CDs if there was something special about them (like being limited or having bonus tracks).

But now that I'm living with someone who prefers digital music (and doesn't care at all about physical formats) and since I've started working from home, I decided to go all-in with Spotify as my main source of music.

human: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a really smooth, understated solve from Hoang-Kim Vu.
It’s his second Saturday grid for The Times and ninth overall.
He nimbly switches between themeless constructions like this one and themed puzzles, which might be flashier (I think his Monday puzzle from September was among the more memorable grids of 2023).
However, this puzzle is loaded with charm — animal factoids, frothy love language, colorful expressions — and enough difficulty to make it satisfying to get through.
llm: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I can’t be sure, but I think that this is the first time that a Saturday puzzle has been themed around an anagram.
Today, we have two 15-letter entries (1 Across and 34 Down) whose clues are “Moonlight Sonata” and “Pomp and Circumstance,” respectively.
The entries themselves don’t seem to have anything in common with those musical pieces except for their length.
It’s when you look at the clues again that things start to make sense.

human: Alfred Hitchcock explained the nature of cinematic terror with a story about the bomb under the table.
People are sitting around a table having a mundane conversation about baseball when — boom!
— a bomb goes off, instantly killing everyone.
You’ve momentarily surprised the audience.
llm: Alfred Hitchcock explained that the best way to create suspense is to show an audience something they want badly, and then keep them from getting it.
That’s what I felt like when I saw this headline: “Goldman Sachs Bans Employees From Donating To Trump.”
I thought, wow, this is finally it — the big story that’ll destroy him once and for all.
And then I read the article, and realized Goldman Sachs was also banning their employees from donating to Hillary Clinton.

human: When Meta sued the Federal Trade Commission last week — the social networking giant’s latest effort to block new restrictions on its monetization of user data — it used an increasingly common argument against government regulators: The complaint alleged that the structure of the F.T.C. was unconstitutional and that its in-house trials were invalid.
llm: When Meta sued the Securities and Exchange Commission in federal court, the agency fought back with a motion to dismiss.
The SEC said Meta had not exhausted all its administrative remedies before filing suit and therefore lacked standing to sue.
It also argued that the plaintiffs were trying to get a court to do what they could have done administratively: force the SEC to take action on their petition for rule-making.

human: The word “Manodrome,” the title of a new film starring Jesse Eisenberg, is a riff on the “manosphere” — a catchall term for misogynist online communities including so-called incels and men’s rights activists.
If your first instinct, like mine, is to snicker, know that this self-important drama is devoid of humor.
llm: The word “Manodrome,” as in “an arena or stadium for the exhibition of men and their behavior,” is not yet listed in dictionaries.
It should be.
It has been used before, but only to describe something like a football game, where men are doing what they do best.

human: As the most important selling season for retailers approaches, job applicants may feel a chill.
llm: As the most widely recognized seasonal employment barometer, CareerBuilder’s annual holiday hiring forecast gauges how many retailers plan to add staff for the holidays, what types of employees they’re seeking and how much they will pay.
From August 13 to September 6, 2018, The Harris Poll surveyed 1,014 hiring managers at U.S. companies that hire seasonal workers during the holiday season.
